IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  This proposal will develop a rapid multi-relaxation imaging technique that can provide simultaneous three- dimensional T1, T2, and T1ρ relaxation mapping for quantifying tissue composition and ultra-structure using magnetic resonance imaging. The imaging technique incorporates a novel multi-relaxation mapping sequence using 3D golden-angle rapid acquisition and a novel physics-informed deep learning reconstruction and will be evaluated in a knee disease model. Our novel proposal would provide a new rapid imaging approach to non- invasively monitor disease-related and treatment-related changes in tissue composition and ultra-structure through multi-relaxation assessment and will have broad clinical applications for various diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Narrative Types 1 and 2 diabetes represent a global health crisis, and result in part or entirely from a reduction of insulin- producing pancreatic beta cells. Despite the existence of ~30 different commercially available diabetes drugs, none has the ability to induce human beta cell regeneration. We describe herein entirely novel and tractable pathways to human beta cell proliferation, and have identified multiple combinations of drugs that act via these pathways to induce human beta cells to regenerate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cancer immunosurveillance ascribes a role of cellular immunity in eliminating transformed cells. Cancer immunotherapy approaches exploiting such activity of conventional T lymphocytes have produced durable responses in a subset of cancer patients. Experiments proposed in this project will define a novel class of cancer immunosurveillance response mediated by tumor-resident cytotoxic innate lymphocytes and innate-like T cells, which can be targeted for therapy of a wide range of solid tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative COVID-19 is a severe threat to human health, caused by the novel coronavirus SARS-CoV-2. Infection with this virus can trigger an increase in blood glucose levels but the underlying mechanisms are not understood. We found that vascular cells in pancreatic islets, the organs that control blood glucose levels, express the receptor for the virus. Here we will study the effects of SARS-CoV-2 on islet vascular function and glucose metabolism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative When a taste is placed on our tongues, we must recognize that a taste is on the tongue, identify that taste, decide whether it’s palatable or not, and then either swallow it or expel it. This thought process can be observed to play out in the firing of neurons in taste cortex, but evidence suggests that cortex doesn’t work alone. We will rigorously test how the amygdala (the seat of emotion in the brain) and hypothalamus (the center that controls hunger and thirst) work with cortex, and with one another, to make taste decisions happen, and how these decisions get implemented by motor circuits—adding to a systemic understanding of taste that will help us fight against a spectrum of feeding-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Swallowing dysfunction is common in older adults, and leads to significant morbidity, including aspiration pneumonia, malnutrition, and dehydration, and is the leading cause of death in older adults with AD/ADRD. Unfortunately, the bedside swallow evaluation currently used by speech language pathologists and nurses to detect swallowing dysfunction is unreliable, especially in individuals with AD/ADRD. We propose to develop a sensitive smartphone-based clinical decision support tool that incorporates analysis of multiple characteristics of a patient's recorded voice and cough to determine their aspiration risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE JC polyomavirus (JCPyV), a prevalent human-only pathogen, causes life-threatening brain diseases in immunologically compromised individuals. The list of immunotherapeutic and chemotherapeutic agents linked to JCPyV CNS diseases is rapidly expanding; no anti-JCPyV agents are available. Using a mouse virus in the same family as JCPyV, we developed a tractable animal model to explore early stages in the pathogenesis of polyomavirus brain infections that precede development of irreversible lesions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PTSD prevalence is high and PTSD increases the risk of dementia. The proposed research will: a) investigate the impact of PTSD on the rate of domain-specific cognitive decline, b) test potential effect modifiers, including sex, of the relationship between PTSD and rate of cognitive decline, and c) determine the association between cognitive functioning and PTSD severity with and without Criterion A trauma. Successful completion of this project has important public health implications including indicating whether PTSD should be considered a target for the early prevention of cognitive decline that may lead to dementia and increasing understanding of sex differences in the relationship between PTSD and cognitive decline.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – RELEVANCE While a growing body of evidence demonstrates the presence of racial bias in algorithms, little is known about how racial bias in algorithms impacts disparities in public health insurance programs, such as Medicaid and Medicare. The central objectives of this project are to: (i) obtain causal estimates of the effect of risk-adjusted managed long-term care (MLTC) on different care utilization and health outcomes among dual-eligible beneficiaries in New York, separately by patient race/ethnicity; (ii) identify differences in the magnitudes of racially disparate impacts across other patient characteristics, including sex, age, health status, and local area; and (iii) identify differences in the magnitudes of racially disparate impacts across different types of plans. This research will help policymakers, healthcare organizations, providers, and patients understand how bias in risk- adjusted MLTC impacts patient health, identify the subgroups of patients most severely impacted, and learn about the plan features that contribute to curbing or eliminating racial health disparities in managed care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a growing demand in clinical and personalized medicine to measure many DNA sequences in a single sample. PCR-based diagnostic assays are widely used clinically for monitoring gene expression and detecting disease-related mutations and infectious agents due to their accuracy, simplicity, and fast turnaround time, but are only able to assess 4–6 DNA sequences per sample. This project is relevant to public heath because it will significantly increase PCR multiplexing to enable clinical assays (up to 30 sequences per reaction and hundreds per instrument run), providing highly sensitive, accurate, and reproducible clinical assay measurements while eliminating the need for complex, slow, and expensive genomic sequencing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults make up a growing portion of rural communities in the United States, but are experiencing a two- pronged challenge of an increasingly severe burden of chronic conditions and limited access to health care— both of which have the potential to exacerbate existing rural-urban health disparities. The goal of this proposal is to measure trends in access to care, chronic condition management, and rural-urban disparities in these outcomes among older adults in the United States, and measure the effects of a novel strategy designed to bolster rural health care delivery, known as global budgets, on these outcomes using a mixed methods approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We all develop from a single cell to a fully-formed human with trillions of cells, during which process the DNA duplex experiences various types of spontaneous damage. Incorrect repair of spontaneous DNA breaks can lead to various types of genome alterations and instability. Here, we develop and apply high-throughput single- cell sequencing technologies to study how the repair of DNA breaks causes error-free and mutational genome rearrangements, and to better understand effects from genomic contexts, genetic mutations and tissue-of-origin.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Tumor-associated macrophages play an important role in promoting tumor growth, angiogenesis, metastasis and immune evasion. However, how tumor-associated macrophages regulate anti-tumor immunity within the tumor microenvironment remains largely unknown. The proposed work will study the role of tumor-associated macrophages in inducing intraturmoral T cell dysfunction and develop novel strategies targeting tumor- associated macrophages for treating cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: OTHER PROJECT INFORMATION – Project Narrative - Relevance The NBER summer institute workshops in aging and health care provide an annual forum for researchers to present and discuss cutting-edge scientific research in this field, and to interact with other scholars in an environment that enhances their ongoing work. The substantive themes addressed in these workshops represent some of the nation’s biggest health challenges and opportunities. In each area, the potential for scientific findings that improve health outcomes is significant, and the opportunity to discuss research in progress enriches the scientific productivity of participating investigators.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In this proposal, we will examine the mechanisms by which inherited variants in the gene ETV6 contribute to development of B-acute lymphoblastic leukemia (B-ALL), the commonest childhood cancer and leading cause  of cancer-related death in children. Through these studies, we will define how ETV6 variants influence normal blood cell development and participate in progression to leukemia. This proposal has relevance to public health because it will improve our understanding of B-ALL and thereby inform the creation of new and more effective ways to classify, treat, and possibly also prevent this prevalent and at times deadly childhood cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: NARRATIVE  Alcohol-associated hepatitis (AH) is a form of subacute liver failure with high mortality and limited treatment options. We hypothesize that HNF4-dependent cholesterol toxicity is a critical pathogenic driver resulting in liver failure in AH. We propose to rigorously interrogate pathways of cholesterol homeostasis and test a strategy to restore cholesterol homeostasis by modulating the expression of HNF4α, the master transcription factor of liver cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mammalian gastrointestinal tract is home to a diverse community of microorganisms whose roles in human health and behavior are being increasingly appreciated, yet few tools are available for genetically modifying this crucial environmental niche with gene- and species-level control. The proposed project aims to develop a new platform technology for precision microbiome engineering that combines programmable, CRISPR RNA-guided integrases with broadly transmissible vectors for highly specific, in situ metagenome alteration. In addition to laying a foundation for future biological insights on host-microbiome metabolism, this work will reveal new therapeutic avenues for inactivating multidrug resistance genes in bacterial pathogens, a looming global health threat.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Defects in replication stress response, which promotes fork stability and genome integrity when DNA replication is challenged, can cause diseases associated with developmental abnormalities, premature aging and cancer predisposition. This proposal focuses on the functional characterization of replication fork components, to uncover new proteins and regulatory mechanisms that promote accurate DNA replication in the context of replication stress. Since replication stress drives cellular transformation, investigating replication stress response pathways can lead to critical drug discoveries targeted for cancer chemotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The role of functionally distinct hepatic T cell subsets in providing protective immunity from hepatotropic viruses, such as hepatitis C virus (HCV), or mediating liver pathology during inflammatory liver disease is poorly defined. Using a mouse model of an HCV-related virus we will investigate the functional properties and potential interplay of distinct type 1 and type 2 T cell and natural killer T (NKT) cell subsets during different stages of hepacivirus infection in vivo. Our results should reveal new concepts of hepatic T cell immunity with implications for the development of HCV vaccine strategies and new therapeutic options for liver disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Activating somatic mutations to estrogen receptor alpha (ERα) enable hormone therapy resistance and significantly contribute to breast cancer mortality. We recently identified a novel therapeutic structural interaction that correlates with improved anti-cancer activities for Y537S ERα, the most aggressive and drug-resistant of the known mutants. We will use a library of over 100 structurally diverse ERα-targeted small molecule antagonists to reveal the interplay between Y537S ERα structure, genomic actions, and anti-cancer activities to overcome hormone therapy resistance in breast cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Attention is critical in our everyday life and serves as an important building block of many of our more complex behaviors. The proposed research will identify the cellular and circuit level signatures of successful attention through examination of neuronal activity in typically functioning mice and mutant mouse lines with attention impairments. Results generated from this proposal will answer fundamental questions about how the brain supports attention and provide a basis for the development of effective therapeutics for attentional impairments across disease states.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Oxycodone seeking progressively increases after prolonged abstinence from drug self-administration. This proposal uses a rat model to investigate the role of March5 and associated mitochondrial dynamics underlying this “incubation of oxycodone craving”. These studies will advance our understanding of molecular mechanisms underlying oxycodone relapse and may help us uncover potential therapeutic targets for oxycodone relapse prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Cellular integration of hepatitis B virus (HBV) represents an alternative biological source for HBV surface antigen (HBsAg) that is closely associated with clinical outcomes in patients with chronic HBV infection. Currently, the contribution of HBV integration to HBsAg remains an elusive issue. A non-invasive method to quantitate integration-derived HBsAg, as proposed in the current application, would be extremely valuable in translational research, clinical trials, and patient management for the globally 257 million people infected with HBV.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Chronic pain from injury is a major source of disability and an enormous economic and social burden. There is a clear need to identify disease-modifying therapies that prevent or reduce chronic pain after injury, including major surgery. This P01 will study oxytocin as a potential disease-modifying agent across rodents and humans, identifying critical pharmacokinetic, physiological, and behavioral measures that contribute to mitigating chronic pain development and speeding resolution of pain after injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The effects of cannabis on the brain of people living with HIV are controversial, underscoring the need for well-controlled studies generating reproducible data from specific cannabinoids, brain regions, and specific brain cell types. The research proposed in this application harnesses advances in single cell methods to generate data from unique regions of the brain where neurogenesis occurs to improve our understanding of the effects of HIV and cannabinoids.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The Animal Core will provide essential services and facilities to the preclinical projects in a standardized and efficient manner, utilizing shared facilities, equipment, and personnel in a coordinated fashion. The services provided to each preclinical project include animal procurement, identification, transgenic colony management, surgical preparation and behavioral assessment. The Core will also standardize methods for collection of plasma and brain tissue for assessing oxytocin levels and for immunohistochemical verification of efficient viral vector transduction and ablation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will examine the pharmacology and neurobiology of systemically administered OXT in the setting of nerve injury. We have shown that acute and chronic injury produce opposite effects on sensibility and responsiveness of tactile (desensitization) and nociceptive (sensitization) mechano-sensory afferents and the abnormal response of these afferents are critical to the maintenance of the neuropathic state and its recovery after nerve injury. Our published and preliminary data suggest that oxytocin (OXT) may speed recovery from pain after injury by returning peripheral input to normal. These data suggest that OXT may be used as a disease- modifying treatment after traumatic injury. With a base on the strength of our preliminary results, we anticipate that this research will contribute to understanding the role of OXT in the modulation of both normal and abnormal peripheral inputs, how this modulation may affect the recovery after nerve damage (L5 SNL), driving central circuitry, nocifensive behavior and attention (Project 2). We also expect to provide information on these afferents physiological properties and OXT mediated modulation to guide a detailed translational study to be implemented in human patients (Project 3).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Scientific advances in addressing the rising suicide rate in the U.S. will require high-level interdisciplinary research that takes advantage of the increasing availability of big data to investigate the comparative effectiveness of alternative interventions prior to carrying out expensive and time-consuming large-scale controlled treatment trials or community interventions. The next generation of suicide prevention researchers will need to be comfortable using the advanced designs and analysis methods of comparative effectiveness research (CER) and appreciate the importance of addressing under-represented populations and recognizing the role played by health disparities in suicides and SRBs in order to address the rising U.S. suicide rate. We aim for our proposed Training Program in Comparative Effectiveness Research for Suicide Prevention to advance these goals by bringing together and cross training a talented group of epidemiologists and clinical predocs and postdocs who will become the vanguard of a new generation of sophisticated CER suicide prevention researchers.

PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Comparative Effectiveness Research for Suicide Prevention

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative CAR T cells have emerged as a promising cell therapy to enhance anti-HIV immunity and eliminate latently HIV-infected cells when combined with HIV latency reversal in a ‘kick and kill’ cure approach. However, CAR T cells are affected by immune exhaustion and the most effective latency reversal agents are associated with drug side-effects, including generalized immune activation. Our proposed study aims to investigate the mechanisms and therapeutic potential of autophagy inducers to enhance anti-HIV CAR-T cell function while reducing the toxicity of latency reversal agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Oxytocin has been shown to be analgesic under some circumstances in preclinical animal models, however most of these studies use dose-to-effect strategies and simple reflexive behavioral measures. In this project, we model oxytocin pharmacokinetics in rats and use targeted concentration infusion paradigms to determine the effects of oxytocin in complex behaviors modified by peripheral nerve injury. We also modulate endogenous oxytocin circuits using a transgenic rat that expresses Cre recombinase selectively in oxytocinergic neurons. Together with similar studies assessing the effects of oxytocin on primary sensory afferents in rats and humans, and on human oxytocin pharmacokinetics and primary afferent physiology in the program project grant, these studies will provide evidence for or against an important role for oxytocin in promoting recovery from injury and mitigation of chronic pain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Medicare Advantage (MA) program serves a growing number of Black and Hispanic beneficiaries, but evidence about the quality and equity of care in MA compared to the traditional Medicare (TM) program is limited. This study will use national MA encounter (i.e., utilization) and survey data, including a new national survey of Medicare beneficiaries, to examine racial/ethnic disparities in care between the MA and TM programs and among MA plans, and to assess patients’ experiences of equity and trust in Medicare plans and providers. This work will illuminate opportunities for the MA program to improve care for racial/ethnic minorities and for policymakers to explicitly incorporate equity into assessments of MA plan performance, with the objective of reducing racial/ethnic disparities in care among Medicare beneficiaries.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative  Physical injury, including surgery, can cause chronic pain, but this is less likely around the time of childbirth, and initial work suggests this is due to a protective effect of the neurohormone, oxytocin. This project within the P01 will translate recent observations and laboratory work in the other projects to people. We will determine how oxytocin is distributed in the brain and the periphery after intravenous injection and use this to test how and at what sites it alters perceptions of light touch, vibration, and pain from pressure or heat or cold. We will finish with studies with intranasal self- administered oxytocin to apply the findings and prepare for clinical trials in the future.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Sepsis and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) are both life-threatening disorders; the former caused by a dysregulated host immune response to infection and the latter a severe form of acute lung injury that may be non-infectious in etiology. In our animal models, neuro- inflammation develops in both conditions, and this alters ventilatory patterns. We propose to map changes in the respiratory network activity and brainstem neuro-inflammation due to septic and sterile injuries and test whether these changes can be reversed by central anti-inflammatory therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Therapeutic antibodies targeting the immune checkpoint glycoprotein, Tim-3, on tumor-infiltrating T- lymphocytes promote immune-mediated tumor cell killing and have thus entered cancer clinical trials. We found that Tim-3 monoclonals also inhibit antigen-presenting cell (APC)- and melanoma cell-expressed Tim-3, the latter of which precariously induces tumor-intrinsic growth and antagonizes benefit of T-cell-directed Tim-3 therapy. This research seeks to optimize Tim-3 treatment modalities by accentuating desired T-cell or APC- mediated immunity, while avoiding undesired effects of melanoma-Tim-3 blockade through cell type-directed targeting of Tim-3 glyco-epitopes and/or signaling pathways.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative: This study centers cell movements called convergent extension which are controlled by a set of proteins called the planar cell polarity (PCP) proteins. These experiments will be significant because convergent extension is essential for neural tube closure and limb morphogenesis, and failure of these movements results in a human birth defects such as neural tube defects and skeletal dysplasia. Thus, experiments proposed here will shed new light on mechanisms underlying human congenital anomalies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Computational speech analysis (CSA) has shown promise as a cost-effective, rapid screening for patients with neurocognitive disorders (NCDs) by objectively and automatically quantifying speech and language use; however, critical steps must be taken before these measures can become clinically useful. I have training and experience in the neurology of speech and language, but require additional training in computational linguistics and paralinguistics, longitudinal markers of disease including neuroimaging and neuropsychological measures, and design of novel technology for dissemination in order to bring CSA into clinical practice. In this project, we propose to investigate the utility of using CSA measures in two distinct patient groups, including a highly characterized group of research participants that includes healthy controls, Alzheimer's disease patients, and mild cognitive impairment patients (Group A), and a group of consented clinic patients with different NCDs (Group B) and to follow these two groups in prospective, longitudinal studies to correlate spontaneous speech measures with standardized linguistic, neuropsychological, and biological measures.

PHR: Project Narrative The IL-17 family of inflammatory cytokines plays important roles in the development of colorectal cancer (CRC). This project aims to uncover how IL-17 inhibits anti-inflammatory regulatory T cells to limit tumorigenesis in the colon. These studies will thus provide novel insights into how the IL-17-Treg circuit might be targeted to prevent or treat CRC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The clinical relevance of high insulin levels in breast cancer was revealed, paradoxically, by targeting the highly related type I insulin-like growth factor (IGF) receptor. The fetal isoform is expressed at high levels in cancer but expressed at low levels in insulin target normal tissues. This research will create inhibitors of insulin receptor (IR) with selection for the adult and fetal separate IR isoforms, reveal the mechanism of action of the fetal IR in cancer, and develop treatment strategies to combine IR antagonists with other agents targeting the IGF and insulin receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Reproductive health concerns are a long-standing unmet care need that face adults ages 18 to 49 years after a colorectal cancer diagnosis. Our study is powered to identify changes in gonadal function caused by colorectal cancer treatments and to investigate psychosocial dimensions of sexual health and fertility-at diagnosis and at multiple subsequent timepoints along the cancer care continuum-using a unique, prospective cohort of reproductive age patients with colorectal cancer. These findings will lead to incorporating reproductive health care in the clinical management of early-onset colorectal cancer, and ultimately improve outcomes for this growing population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) and subsequent aortic rupture can lead to sudden death and are a significant clinical problem with increasing prevalence and no known medical treatment. Our goal with the present proposal is to identify whether the defective clearance of dead cells (efferocytosis) by endothelial cells triggers a signaling cascade leading to thrombus formation, iron-mediated cell death, and pannexin-1 channel activation in the progression of AAAs. Importantly, the clinical translation of the experimental studies will be enhanced, by using our newly described chronic mouse model of aneurysm formation and aortic rupture, as well as analysis of patient AAA samples.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alcohol use disorder is a major cause of illness, disability, and death, and there are longstanding challenges in barriers to and disparities in care. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Human microbiome-derived bioactive molecules play an important role in mediating microbiome functions and host effects, but we have thus far only discovered a small number of these molecules. Here, we propose to systematically characterize the structure and function of three classes of diverse molecules that are widely encoded by the human microbiome but are currently understudied. Our findings will move us closer towards accurate prediction of microbiome function in health and disease, and allow us to identify potential entry points for targeted interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research program will examine the genetics of Aedes aegypti, the mosquito vector for a number of human disease-causing pathogens, including Zika, chikungunya, yellow fever, and dengue arboviruses. Dengue is the most widespread and significant arboviral disease in the world. The proposed investigation will promote the elucidation of novel strategies for mosquito control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Reinfection with seasonal influenza viruses has the potential to occur each year with waning pre- existing immunity and suboptimal vaccine efficacy. The goal of this proposal is to identify immune factors from prior infections and vaccination that correlate with reduced susceptibility to airborne transmission of seasonal influenza viruses in the ferret model. This research will provide a more relevant animal model that better mimics airborne transmission of influenza viruses within the human population and will better inform future universal vaccine strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The immune system is now known to play a central role, not only in the control of infection and the development of autoimmunity and allergies, but in both control and promotion of cancer, development of cardiovascular disease, appropriate neurological functioning in the brain, and chronic inflammation. the Interdisciplinary Training Program in Immunology at the University of Virginia School of Medicine is constructed to bring together faculty and trainees with diverse interests but a common focus on the immune system’s involvement in these processes, and to support them with access to cutting edge technologies. In so doing, we intend to develop the next generation of outstanding Immunologists who will continue to uncover the fundamental workings of the immune system, and the ways in which these can be harnessed in the service of improving human health.

PROJECT_TITLE: Interdisciplinary Training Program in Immunology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The studies described in this proposal will functionally characterize two highly conserved inter-organ communication systems that are essential for ensuring proper control of body size and function during an organism’s development and interactions with its surroundings. Identifying and characterizing these mechanisms is central to understanding many fundamental issues that underlie significant human health problems including obesity, endocrine abnormalities, and developmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Our studies will determine the full hematopoietic lineage plasticity of YY1-null pro-B cells, and their developmental pathway of developing alternative lineages. Mechanistic studies will explore the molecular mechanisms of YY1 control of lineage commitment. Defects in these processes can cause hematopoietic and immune defects, and our studies may define a new general mechanism for regulating lineage commitment and development that may be applicable to other systems, and that potentially could be used therapeutically.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Ticks are obligate hematophagous arthropods and ecto-parasites of every class of vertebrates in almost every region of the world. Despite the increasing information available on ticks, there is lack of molecular tools to understand the basis of tick phenotypes and tick-pathogen interactions. This proposal focus on understanding tick biology on molecular level by developing genome editing tools.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative We have designed small-scale robots using catalytic nanoparticles as building blocks that display automated and tether-free controlled motion with multifunctionality. These robots can locally kill, degrade and retrieve biofilms with high precision and efficacy. This pioneering approach combining nanotechnology and robotics principles will afford an unprecedented level of endodontic biofilm detection and treatment, and will generate the first instance of robotics devices for automated clinical application in the dental field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM) is a highly heritable trait that affects up to 1:250 individuals and is responsible for ~40% of cardiac transplants, yet causal variants are identified in fewer than half of patients, ~30-40% of tests return variants of uncertain significance (VUS), and modest number of genes have adequate genotype- phenotype data to inform medical management. Harmonizing data from five large biobanks, we will use sequencing data and innovative approaches we have developed that leverage segments of the genome shared due to recent common ancestry to: 1) define the contribution and clinical effects of known DCM genes, 2) assess the pathogenicity of candidate DCM gene and VUS, and 3) discover novel DCM risk loci. These aims will fill important knowledge gaps in DCM clinical genetics, improve the yield and interpretation of DCM genetic testing, and inform gene-based precision care and screening.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Both cerebrovascular and microglial dysfunction are common in Alzheimer’s Disease (AD) but microglial interactions with and potential modulation of neurovascular structure and function not been studied. This project will investigate specific roles for microglia, microglial Trem2 receptors and microglial regulation of astrocyte function as a novel mechanism for microglial-vascular interactions and neurovascular function that may be relevant in AD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Medications for opioid use disorder (MOUD) are an effective treatment in the community and among incarcerated individuals, yet they are offered in very few correctional settings nationwide. The criminal justice (CJ) system offers a unique opportunity to engage individuals in treatment initiation, given the high prevalence of opioid use disorder (OUD) in jails and prisons and the high risk of opioid overdose upon release. The study will compare treatment outcomes between extended-release buprenorphine (XR-B) to treatment-as-usual sublingual buprenorphine (SL-B) in a CJ setting and conduct a mixed-methods process evaluation which will characterize the facilitators of and barriers to the implementation of this novel treatment modality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Immunotherapies have been revolutionary for treating a variety of cancer types, but still many patients do not respond or become resistant to currently available therapies, highlighting the need for more effective melanoma treatments. Endogenous retroelement re-expression may be a strategy for rendering tumors more immunogenic and therefore more treatable through immunotherapies, but this remains understudied. This proposal will examine the role of factors controlling expression of ERVs in augmenting the anti-tumor immune response, which will improve our understanding of cancer immunology and may identify new targets for therapeutic development.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE TB-related morbidity and mortality is high in children, especially among those living with HIV, missed by respiratory sampling. We have developed a rapid and sensitive nanoplasmon-enhanced scattering (nPES) assay which directly detects M. tuberculosis-specific exosomes from as little as 1 L of serum. The proposed study will utilize cryopreserved specimens from children enrolled in well-characterized completed and proposed prospective cohorts with high HIV prevalence and intensive TB investigations to evaluate the performance of nPES Mtb-specific exosome detection for pediatric TB diagnosis and treatment response, including evaluation of a point-of-care prototype, and are poised to evaluate additional sample types including urine in future directions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Peripheral nerve injury is a large-scale problem that affects more than one million people per year in the United States. The investigators propose to design, fabricate, and validate a new class of nerve guidance conduits for the surgical repair of large defects in thick nerves by restoring their continuity and functions. The conduits can enhance nerve regeneration through a synergistic effect arising from uniaxially-aligned fibers, nanoscale grooves engraved on the fibers, and programmed supply of neurotrophic factors at a steady concentration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Air pollution (particulate matter < 2.5 um; PM2.5) exposure increases the risk for neurodevelopmental disorders (NDDs), yet the neural mechanisms underlying these associations are largely unknown. This research adopts a transdiagnostic approach to uncover mechanistic links between PM2.5 exposure and behavioral and neuroimaging phenotypes in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Findings will help identify critical windows of susceptibility and underlying mechanisms informing prevention and intervention efforts for these and other NDDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Defects in the internal organization of cells and the transport mechanisms of their proteins and membranes underlie the pathogenesis of many human diseases including cancer, neurodegeneration (e.g., Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, ALS), brain injury and metabolic disorders. This research program aims to advance our knowledge of how transport within cells is spatially controlled by a unique family of proteins called septins. The proposed research will advance basic knowledge of cell biology, which in the long-term will be used to design better treatments that can reverse or slow down disease and/or to regenerate ailing cells and tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Emerging adults (EAs) with type 1 diabetes (T1D) are a vulnerable population. While diabetes self-management and education (DSMES) is known to offer opportunities to develop self-management skills required to achieve and maintain short- and long-term diabetes outcomes, EAs are reported to have poor clinic attendance and in turn low participation in DSMES services. This proposal aims to test a novel approach to DSMES that incorporates technological and applied learning-driven methods delivered through group telemedicine visits to improve EA engagement in DSMES with the ultimate goal of improving diabetes outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is a seemingly paradoxical relationship between favorable midlife lipid profiles and high risk of Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) among Black Americans that has been severely understudied. Lipids play a vital role in neurodegenerative disease, and epidemiologic and metabolomic studies have identified commonly tested lipids (total cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and triglycerides) as well as sphingolipids (ceramides) as predictors of cognitive aging. Findings from this research will provide important insights into the relationship of lipids with ADRD among Black Americans exploring lifecourse genetic, psychosocial, and cardiometabolic mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Social and behavioral experiences have large and pervasive effects on health outcomes during midlife and older adulthood. Understanding the biological pathways by which psychosocial determinants operate promises substantial improvements in public health as well as savings in healthcare costs. This training program will prepare a new generation of researchers in aging to integrate research methods and findings that span from basic biological mechanisms to complex social phenomena.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative Led by Wake Forest since 2005, the Coordinating Center (CC) for the Pepper OAIC Program builds collaborations that produce synergy within the OAIC network and the aging research community. In this cycle, the CC fostered dramatic growth in the number and impact of OAIC collaborative projects. This proposal, led by a cohesive team of highly experienced leaders with complementary skills, will take full advantage of the increased funding provided in the new RFA to further enhance and extend the impact of the OAIC program by executing 4 Specific Aims, each of which were informed by our preliminary data and evaluations process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Project Narrative Because tonic and phasic irritability in childhood and adolescence predict somewhat different mental disorders and poorer functional outcomes across the lifespan, developing measures specifically designed to assess both the tonic and phasic components of irritability is paramount to continued empirical work in understanding, preventing, and treating youth irritability. By developing and validating a multi-informant rating scale for tonic and phasic irritability, the study will advance the goal of generating a reliable and robust assessment tool to predict illness onset and course in youth. Findings from the study will lay the groundwork for optimizing prediction of risk for specific forms of psychopathology, potentially aiding the identification of those most in need of services and indicating which interventions might be most effective and facilitate assessment of more specific treatment targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease (AD) is a devastating, fatal illness that by far is the fastest-increasing cause of death in the US and will affect as many as 1 in 45 Americans by 2047. The overall goal of this proposal is to study the cerebrovascular dysfunction which is a critical component in AD pathogenesis using a multimodal MRI/PET imaging approach. Successful completion of the current imaging study will yield much richer and more specific information about underlying vascular pathology in AD and advance our understanding of AD pathophysiology and evolution.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The mean age of ASD detection and treatment referral remains stable at the relatively late age of 4 years, likely because recommended screening practices are based on a parent questionnaire model, which has low sensitivity, and often only about 1/3 of toddlers who fail questionnaire-based screeners are referred for an evaluation by pediatricians. Eye-tracking, which generates biologically-relevant, objective, and quantifiable metrics of social and non-social visual attention patterns, is a technology that holds considerable promise as a tool to dramatically change how screening is implemented. In this proposal we test the efficacy of eye-tracking as a screening tool to detect ASD at 12, 18 & 24 month well-baby check ups as administered by medical staff in pediatric offices as standard of care and compare results to traditional parent-questionnaire screening approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Current HIV vaccines lack the ability to trigger Ab precursors to become broadly neutralizing antibodies that could provide protective vaccine immunity. The problem may in part stem from subtle but important differences between current vaccine Envs & authentic Env spikes on replicating virus surfaces: logically, the form of vaccine Env, including its context & carbohydrate shell, should be as close to a perfect match as possible. Another problem is that the prototype broadly neutralizing antibodies generated during natural infection generally make contacts with sugars on HIV, whereas vaccine antibodies generally avoid these sugars, severely limiting their potential for vaccine protection. It may therefore be crucial to find ways to improve the ability of vaccine NAbs to contact glycans. Here, we seek to identify new concepts to increase the breadth of vaccine-induced neutralizing antibody responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This trial uses internet technology and community methods to test the acceptability, feasibility and efficacy of NiteCAPP, a brief web CBT-I for rural dementia caregivers (CGs). It offers new understanding of how NiteCAPP improves CG sleep, arousal and inflammation and prompts downstream effects on other outcomes (health, mood, burden, cognition). Demonstration that rural CGs can use NiteCAPP to target sleep, arousal, inflammation and related concerns has important implications for rural CGs/PWDs, their families, clinicians and policymakers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Many different immune systems have been repurposed as valuable tools in science and medicine (e.g. antibodies and CRISPR). However, the mechanisms of many genetically diverse immune systems remain unknown, suggesting other valuable molecular tools may still be waiting to be discovered. This work aims to understand the structure and function of two different bacterial immune systems that have not yet been characterized, with the hope of identifying novel molecular tools for science and medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative We lack an effective vaccine against tuberculosis and have an incomplete understanding of those immune pathways by which humans mediate natural control over TB progression. Recently we utilized fluorescent fitness reporter strains of Mtb to demonstrate that restriction of Mtb growth in the mouse lung was linked, both functionally and differentially, to host macrophage lineage and metabolism. We propose building on these foundations to identify immune-mediated pathways of Mtb control that are active or impaired in cells recovered by bronchoalveolar lavage from HIV-1 uninfected and infected human donors in Blantyre, Malawi.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance In both humans and animal models, young females have lower blood pressure than young males; however, as females age their blood pressure increases. We have identified a mouse model (Olfr558 knockout) in which female mice do not increase blood pressure as they age. In these studies, we will work to uncover how Olfr558 modulates blood pressure in aging and menopause.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Generation and Description of Neuronal Morphology & Connectivity Brain connectivity and the intricate tree-like shape of individual nerve cells underlie cognitive and physiological functions, and are dramatically altered in almost all known neurological disorders. Using state-of-the-art information technology, data mining, and computational modeling, this project will synthesize, analyze, and freely share a massive amount of quantitative information on neuronal morphology and on the synaptic properties of an exemplary neural system responsible for spatial representation and autobiographic memories. These developments will enable the creation of detailed, biologically plausible, full-scale, quantitatively predictive neural network models to investigate the circuit dynamics of learning and related impairments for the long-lasting benefit of scientific advancement and public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Fostering Opportunities Resulting in Workforce and Research Diversity (FORWARD) Program is a key part of the American Gastroenterological Association's organizational commitment to expand the pool of physicians and scientists from underrepresented backgrounds and reduce disparities in digestive disease. The next phase of the program aims to retain a diverse research workforce in gastroenterology by preparing and aiding the transition of early-career individuals from underrepresented backgrounds to assume leadership positions within the professional association and in academic medicine. We will build on the successes of our initial five years through a comprehensive curriculum covering essential research skills such as manuscript writing and grant writing (with an emphasis on preparation of an NIH K or R01 grant application); leadership skills aimed at preparing and transitioning participants to roles within AGA committees and academic leadership; and intensive mentorship through a team-based approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative: Despite the discovery of new prevention tools, and the expansion of treatment, HIV-1 continues to spread. With no effective HIV-1 vaccine available, the passive administration of broadly neutralizing antibodies (bNAbs) for prevention is a promising alternative. This project aims to utilize samples from the first proof-of- concept antibody-mediated prevention (AMP) study in Africa to gain a deeper understanding of how HIV-1 diversity might affect prevention efficacy and to determine the clinical consequences of infection with bNAb resistant viruses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The early and accurate diagnosis of congenital abnormalities using prenatal genetic screens and diagnostic tests (PS&D) is pivotal for patients to make healthcare decisions that are informed by medical facts and their values about pregnancy, children, family, and reproduction. The goal of this study is to ensure that pregnant patients have the resources and support needed to access PS&D in an informed and evidence- based fashion by developing an innovative digital tool to support patients’ decision-making and contributing fundamental knowledge to advance decision science in a way that promotes patients' access to new prenatal applications of genomic science and technology. This study is significant because it will bridge the gap in existing data needed to overcome persistent barriers to patients' informed access to PS&D that remain unmet, addressing factors that have a critical impact on prenatal care quality, safety, and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Chronic wounds are responsible for $25 billion USD in annual expenditures in the United States and are the most common cause of lower extremity amputation. Diabetes is a major risk factor for non-healing wounds, and an excessive inflammatory phenotype of macrophage cells in the diabetic state is implicated as a causative factor that impairs tissue repair. In this project, a nanomedicine strategy will be developed to selectively deliver therapeutic agents to macrophages locally in wounds to inhibit their inflammatory phenotype and promote repair, while avoiding effects on structural cells in wounds as well as distant tissues.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Because helping address the needs of ADRD patients requires substantial long-term behavioral and social care supports not typically provided under traditional fee-for-service insurance, covering a broader set of services and coordination care for enrollees with managed care may be expected to improve patient outcomes while restraining health care use. However, little is known about the role of managed care in dementia care, including the extent to which ADRD individuals are using managed care products, the types of plans they use, whether caregivers influence such decisions, and whether managed care enrollment is associated with improvements in outcomes for individuals with ADRD or changes in the amounts and type of informal care received. We will assess managed care uptake and its impact on patients and their use of informal caregiving, using instrumental variables analysis with Medicare data plus national survey data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 1 Approximately 15-25 million people worldwide are infected with HTLV-1 with a small percentage developing adult T-cell leukemia. The cancer is aggressive and there is currently no effective treatment. This project focuses on a novel viral gene encoded by the antisense strand of the HTLV-1 genome, termed hbz, and the proposed studies will provide a significant advance in our basic knowledge of the role of hbz in transformation and disease and will have significant implications for therapeutic targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: PENNSYLVANIA STATE UNIV HERSHEY MED CTR
PHR: NARRATIVE Men and women infected with human immunodeficiency virus have higher rates of HPV16 infection, longer persistence of HPV16, increased incidence of head and neck cancer, poorer prognosis, as well as more recurrences after definitive therapy. The risk of HPV-associated oropharyngeal cancer are higher among HIV- infected patients in the HAART era compared to the general population. Generally, HPV infections are self- limiting, however, persistent HPV infection is a major risk to carcinogenic progression. Long intervals between initial infection and the development of cancer imply cofactors are involved. We hypothesize that HAART therapy is a cofactor increasing the cancer risk..

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE African Americans and Latino/Hispanic Americans have a higher risk of death from heart disease, and a disproportionally lower number of both minority groups are employed in the health professions and participate in clinical research. One approach to addressing these disparities is to increase the number of underrepresented minorities who pursue careers in the health professions. Thus, we will establish an intensive summer research education program to prepareand motivate underrepresented minority students to enroll in MD/PhD and PhD programs, building on the University of Pittsburgh’s track record in achieving success in such programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – PROJECT 2 Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma (ATL), an aggressive leukemia that is associated with hypercalcemia and osteolytic bone lesions develops in 2-4% of HTLV-1 infected individuals. We will investigate new roles for two bone-acting factors, regulated by the HTLV-1 viral oncogene Hbz, in reprogramming the bone environment. These represent therapeutic opportunities to target the significant bone loss in ATL patients, as well as affect progression of ATL tumors which are often resistant to standard chemotherapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diabetic foot ulcers (DFUs) and other chronic wounds are enormously costly worldwide health concerns that often necessitate amputation and are associated with a significantly increased risk of death. The purpose of this project is to develop gene-containing biomaterials that help control the behavior of critical cells within DFUs by harnessing collagen remodeling to stimulate reliably localized expression of key healing factors including growth factors and immunomodulatory cytokines. The proposed studies will identify design principles and mechanisms associated with these biomaterials in the DFU environment, which will ultimately allow their use not only for improved cutaneous repair, but also for multiple other applications in regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE- PROJECT 3 This project investigates the role of a cellular protein (CTCF) that binds to a specific site (CTCF-BS) in the integrated HTLV-1 DNA as well as many sites in the lymphocyte DNA; this interaction is known to introduce loops into DNA and affect expression of genes. We will investigate whether the CTCF-BS affects the ability of HTLV-1 to replicate, establish latency, a state in which the viral DNA is present in the cell but it is not copied into RNA and proteins, and cause leukemia and lymphoma in immunodeficient mice. These studies will elucidate the mechanism of action of CTCF in regulating HTLV-1 replication and transformation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The rate of ribosome synthesis is proportional to cell growth and proliferation rates. RNA polymerase I makes the ribosomal RNA and this step is rate-limiting for ribosome synthesis. This project will reveal unique properties of RNA polymerase I that may be targeted therapeutically to control cancer cell proliferation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: Project Narrative Acetylcholine (ACh) and dopamine (DA) are co-regulated in the striatum during salient events, but it is unclear whether they are regulated independently from each other, whether they mutually regulate each other, and whether their temporal co-incidence is important for cognitive flexibility. Studying striatal co-regulation of DA and ACh during flexible learning will give important insights in the role of both neuromodulators for learning and will aid our understanding of brain disorders with altered DA-ACh function including Schizophrenia and Parkinson disorder.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Tumor dormancy is a process whereby cancer cells enter an inactive state that enables them to survive environmental insults. This application aims to provide insight into tumor cell dormancy in uveal melanoma and compare to mechanisms that allow uveal melanoma cells to survive therapeutic attack at the metastatic site. Ultimately, our goal is to guide the development of more effective therapeutic strategies for uveal melanoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Obesity is one of the most common metabolic disorders in the world and the leading cause of Type 2 Diabetes. Our study aims to understand how the regulation of a microRNA, a small non-coding RNA, from the microvasculature regulates angiogenesis in adipose tissues and whether there is a correlation between improved angiogenesis and adipocyte function and obesity-induced insulin resistance. The results from our studies may have important translational implications and provide a new understanding for adipose tissue dysfunction in obesity induced insulin resistance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Narrative Adolescents in residential substance use treatment have high risk of relapse after discharge, but it is extremely difficult to engage these adolescents and their parents in continuing care. This study aims to improve the outcomes of adolescents following discharge from residential substance use treatment by offering their parents a novel technology-assisted intervention. Technology-assisted interventions have the potential for marked public health impact by extending the reach, duration, and scalability of evidence-based care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – CORE 2 The overall theme of the PPG is to analyze how infection with HTLV-1 induces proliferation of CD4 T cells, what cellular events occur during transformation and how the tumor cells interact with their microenvironment. After acute infection, HTLV-1 persists in the organism, eventually leading to oligoclonal and finally monoclonal proliferation and transformation of CD4+ T cells. Core 2 supports the Program Project Grant through the rabbit model, mouse xenograft models, mouse model with a human immune system (HIS mice).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative We use behavioral and neuroimaging measurements to extend our longitudinal investigation of children from the UC Davis MIND Institute Autism Phenome Project cohort into adolescence, with a focus on examining cognition, social functioning, and the emergence of depression in individuals with three phenotypes of intellectual functioning (IQ) from early childhood to adolescence—one with persistent intellectual disability (ID) (P-Low); one with persistently average or better IQs (P-High); and one with IQs improving from the ID to the average or better range (+CHG). We predict that P-Low will exhibit strengths in episodic memory, and low levels of depression, although we investigate whether this is a result of under-reporting; that P-High, while cognitively able, will experience the highest levels of depression; and that +CHG will show strongest cognitive and social development without some of the liabilities experienced by P-High.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Program Narrative Neurosteroids and cholesterol are important signaling molecules that modulate the function of integral membrane proteins. The proposed research will define the specific binding sites for neurosteroids on various forms of their major target protein, the GABA type A receptor and for cholesterol on lipid scramblases and lysosomal signaling proteins. The work will identify site-specific agonists and antagonists for the sterol binding sites and provide new insights into the biological role of neurosteroids and cholesterol as allosteric modulators of protein function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARATIVE The goal of this proposal is to develop and validate a new point-of-care test for early diagnosis and screening of talaromycosis, a leading cause of AIDS-related deaths in Southeast Asia. We will also assess the costs and opinions from stakeholders to inform policy development. The test may allow doctors to begin treatment earlier which can prevent disease from developing or from progressing further into fulminant stage, thus improving patient outcomes and reducing mortality.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Emerging studies show the existence of a black-white disparity in the incidence and prevalence of vascular cognitive impairment (VCI) as well as other Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRDs). Thus, it is important to identify factors contributing to this disparity. This proposal focuses on vascular and genetic risk factors associated with abnormalities in the small blood vessels in the brain. We will examine the prevalence of these abnormalities in black and white adults with stroke or transient ischemic attack and whether these risk factors contribute to the black-white disparity in VCI and ADRDs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Vitamin D deficiency affects over one billion people world wide and is linked to a myriad of health disorders, including neurodegenerative diseases, cancers, diabetes, and impaired immune function. Sunlight exposure converts a pro-hormone to the active vitamin D hormone in the skin, and therefore populations living at higher latitudes are more at risk. Using a dog model of the circumpolar north, this project will look at the effects of age, and dietary intervention on vitamin D status and its relationship with markers of brain aging, and metabolic syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Heterotrophic protozoans play critical roles in aquatic environments through their consumption of planktonic autotrophs that they capture and consume via an enigmatic endocytic structure known as the cytostome/cytopharynx complex (SPC). Intriguingly, the kinetoplastid parasite Trypanosoma cruzi also retains this ancestral organelle and uses it to endocytose extracellular host material in a manner analogous to its free- living bodonid relatives. Very little is known about how the SPC is formed or functions and this proposal seeks to continue our analysis of this feeding structure and characterize the molecular machinery responsible for cargo capture at the surface, signal transmission to initiate endocytosis and ultimately trafficking along the SPC for lysosomal digestion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) is an emerging Group 1 pathogen and the major cause of cancers in untreated AIDS patients. Successful KSHV replication requires it to control gene expression in the infected cell, which is broadly achieved via widespread destruction of protein coding RNAs. This grant is focused on revealing a how the viral nuclease responsible for this process alters RNA fate, and how the infected cell senses and responds to message depletion.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  This project will develop, optimize and evaluate a rapid 5-minute knee MRI protocol consisting of all clinical sequences and additional T2 mapping sequences, enabling imaging of the whole knee for both morphological and quantitative assessment of joint pathology. The proposed technique explores the acceleration of knee MRI by leveraging the latest deep learning technology combined with novel image acquisition and automatic processing. Given the increasing prevalence of knee osteoarthritis and the overall cumulative knee injuries, our novel imaging methods would offer a unique opportunity to improve joint health care, reduce healthcare costs, and benefit a large population that suffers knee pain and joint discomfort in the United States.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed training program will enable the applicant to apply generative adversarial network (GAN) architecture to widely available pre-operative evaluation notes and data from an anesthesia information management system (AIMS) to improve patient outcomes. The training will comprise the creation of (1) one GAN framework for generating realistic synthetic low-resolution AIMS data from patient profiles in pre- operative evaluation notes and (2) The second GAN framework for generating synthetic high-resolution intraoperative physiological data from low-resolution AIMS data and patient profiles. From this, the applicant aims to (1) investigate the feasibility of using GAN architecture to improve pre-operative risk assessment and (2) create a database for intraoperative high-resolution multivariate time series gathered from both low- resolution AIMS data and pre-operative evaluation notes, which can be used to train machine learning algorithms for a future real-time intraoperative clinical-decision support system designed to assist anesthesia providers deliver safer care.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Older adults from vulnerable populations, including those who face disparities in care, and those with complex multimorbidity and dementia, experience poor health and quality of life, and while their numbers are growing, the research workforce needed to address their needs is small. We propose an interdisciplinary research training program to enable scholars, especially those without formal geriatrics or gerontology training, to develop the skills needed to become independently funded researchers in this field and to conduct research that leads to improvements in the health and quality of life of older, vulnerable adults.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Members of the mechanosensitive ion channel family act as biological sensors by decoding mechanical stimuli to regulate physiological processes such as touch and food sensation, mechanical pain, and wound healing. The proposed study is relevant to NIH's mission because it will provide the molecular basis by which fatty acids modulate the response of mechanosensitive ion channels, including the PIEZO family. The proposed research is relevant to public health because combining dietary fatty acids might be a new strategy to ameliorate mechanical pain and accelerate wound healing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This is a collaborative project University of Pittsburgh Medical Center (UPMC) Children’s Hospital of Pittsburgh Heart Institute (CHP-HI) to study heart disease in children and young adults with other clinical core research centers within the NHLBI Pediatric Heart Network. The goal of this project is to develop new knowledge and understanding that will lead to improved diagnosis and new therapies to lessen the burden of both congenital and acquired heart disease in a diverse population of children and young adults. CHP-HI is eager to collaborate with other clinical centers, the data-coordinating center, the NHLBI staff, and industry partners to complete ongoing studies and initiate innovative new investigations.

PHR: NARRATIVE Congenital heart disease affects ~1% of live births and is the leading cause of mortality from birth defects; acquired heart disease affects thousands more each year. The Pediatric Heart Network is a multicenter research enterprise that has conducted 23 multicenter research studies including 12 clinical trials; 7 studies are currently recruiting participants. Boston Children’s Hospital has participated in the PHN since its inception in 2001 and here presents exemplary credentials to be a PHN Clinical Research Center in the next grant cycle.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Building on a portfolio of long-standing expertise at the interface of RNA biology and single molecule biophysics, we will apply advanced mechanistic enzymology approaches to a broad set of RNAs involved in the regulation of transcription and translation, thus seizing the opportunities that continue to arise from discoveries of functional RNAs. In addition, we will push the limits of our single molecule approaches to be able to probe increasingly complex biological machineries and mechanisms in which RNA secondary and tertiary structures govern the function of the cellular gene expression machinery .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Toddlers who are late talkers are at risk for continuing language impairments and also have high rates of mental health impairments, estimated to range from 30-70%, yet the precursors and trajectories of these conditions are rarely studied, especially in tandem. Here, we will use existing data and add new measures to our ongoing multi-cohort study to accelerate the pace of discovery to create risk calculators that can predict children’s late talking status, language, and mental health impairments. Crucially, we will examine promotive factors that help children’s positive development and employ a health-equity lens that ensures our risk calculators are accurate for children from historically marginalized and under-resourced environments who are often incorrectly missed or diagnosed.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Among Alaska Natives in Alaska, tuberculosis (TB) remains endemic in communities and is a leading cause of morbidity and mortality. Today, Alaska Native communities continue to have the highest rates of TB disease in the United States, and most TB cases occur in villages that remain far from health centers. In this proposal, we seek to evaluate the accuracy and feasibility of using several recent advancements for portable chest radiography and non-invasive tongue swab sampling for the screening and diagnosis of TB disease within Alaska Native communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE According to the estimates of the National Cancer Institute over 30,000 Americans will die due to hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) this year alone; however, regrettably, current therapies provide only limited clinical benefit, and thus, new and more effective therapies are urgently needed for treating HCC effectively. Using an integrative functional genomics approach (humanized NSG mice with human immune system and in vivo CRISPR screening), we have identified NSD3 as a driver and therapeutic target in HCC. The studies proposed in this application will have a significant impact on the biology and therapy of HCC by establishing NSD3 as a driver of HCC and by providing novel drugs for effective treatment of HCC patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As a Core Clinical Research Center for >20 years, Pediatric Heart Network (PHN) Utah has supported the mission to improve outcomes for individuals with congenital heart disease and pediatric acquired heart disease, and made particularly exceptional contributions to scientific discoveries, administrative activities, and training the next generation of researchers. Going forward, PHN Utah will bring participants from unique underrepresented groups as well as additional resources and expertise to address inequities in all aspects of research with the infrastructure and experience to lead a big data approach to collecting clinical, genomic, and social determinants of health data to empower equitable personalized outcome prediction. Based on its history of excellence, well defined leadership transition plan, and unique research infrastructure, PHN Utah is ideally poised to seamlessly move into the next cycle and increase their considerable contributions as a Clinical Research Center.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project uses cell-free Xenopus egg extracts to investigate how the spatial organization of the cytoplasm arises, and how the crowding and organization of the cytoplasm affects the basic biochemistry of life. Our experimental approaches are underpinned by theory and computation. Our hope is that the principles that underpin spatial organization and biochemical regulation in this one particular highly manipulable system will shed light on many others.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Pediatric Heart Network has established best practices for multi-center research in congenital and acquired pediatric heart disease. Collaboration among the Clinical Research Centers, the Data Coordinating Center and other stakeholders permits multi-center evaluation of medical, interventional, and surgical therapies; provides a training platform for fellows, junior faculty, and nurses; supports development of novel techniques and methodologies; and promotes dissemination of study results to improve the scientific basis for the care of affected individuals. In MUSC’s application to continue participation as a core PHN site, we provide compelling evidence of local expertise, a sustained track record of successful multicenter clinical investigation and development of junior investigators and propose a ground-breaking study in neonates undergoing cardiac surgery to examine the impact of environmental exposures on clinical outcomes and associated disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cells in epithelial tissues are connected by cell-cell junctions that sense mechanical forces and respond by activating signaling pathways, recruiting mechanosensitive proteins, and remodeling their connections to the cytoskeleton. Disruption of cell-cell junctions contributes to cancer cell metastasis and barrier function diseases such as inflammatory bowel disease. The proposed research will strengthen our understanding of how epithelial cells sense and respond to physiological forces to maintain, reinforce, and remodel their cell-cell junctions; therefore, this research will help us better understand the pathogenesis of cancer and barrier function diseases and potentially identify new targets for treating these diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Alterations of metal homeostasis are characteristic of multiple pathologies, including neurodegeneration and cancer. A reprogrammed iron metabolism is a key descriptor of malignant cells, which maintain increased iron acquisition and retention. With the long-term goal of improving the current understanding of iron dysregulation in human disease and its potential impact on cancer treatment, this research program focuses on the synthesis and biological evaluation of a new generation of selective molecular tools for intracellular iron binding.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacteriophages are the most numerous organisms in the biosphere and profoundly influence microbial diversity, bacterial pathogenesis, and biotechnological advances. Dynamic bacteriophage-bacterium interactions contribute to narrow patterns of host specificity by phages, driven by bacterially encoded defense systems, prophage-mediated defense systems, and plasmids. Elucidating these systems and their roles in phage host range will advance our understanding of microbial dynamics and fuel the development of phage-based therapeutics.
