IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cis regulatory elements (CREs), including enhancers and promoters, are required to drive cell-type specific gene expression and are therefore elegantly regulated by various chromatin associated proteins. We propose to uncover the biological roles and interplay of chromatin regulatory complexes and non-protein-coding RNAs (ncRNAs) within embryonic stem (ES) cells and during differentiation, focusing on those ncRNAs generated at both gene proximal and distal CREs. Together, these studies will uncover the mechanisms and wiring of gene regulatory networks responsible for directing cell fate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Antibiotic resistance and evasion of treatment are increasing at alarming rates for numerous important bacterial pathogens and represent a serious threat to human health. This basic-science grant uses the “superbug” Streptococcus pneumoniae as a highly tractable model to understand the dynamics and regulation of peptidoglycan cell wall synthesis in ovoid-shaped bacteria. New findings from this grant about the mechanisms and components of peptidoglycan synthesis have the potential to provide new targets and reveal vulnerabilities for future antibiotic and vaccine discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Membrane proteins face substantial hurdles as they fold and assemble in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER), but a dedicated quality control pathway known as ER associated degradation (ERAD) selects and destroys misfolded membrane proteins. Yet, how misfolded integral membrane ERAD substrates are prevented from trafficking beyond the ER in human cells, and how toxic aggregation-prone membrane proteins are destroyed are poorly understood. These knowledge gaps will be addressed by applying innovative tools, developing new models, and working with resident experts. In addition, most ERAD substrates were discovered in a nonsystematic manner; therefore, another objective is to apply a new computational-experimental pipeline to uncover previously uncharacterized amino acid variants that destabilize two ion channels, thus leading to the identification of “new” disease-associated ERAD substrates.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Heart disease is the leading cause of mortality among Yup'ik men and the second most common cause of death among Yup'ik women. This study will design and evaluate a culturally grounded, multi-level intervention focused on increasing intake of traditional foods and healthy market foods, decreasing intake of processed foods and increasing physical activity to reduce heart disease risk among Yupik adults. If successful, the intervention can be disseminated to other Yup'ik communities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Our research program continues in the tradition of exploring the enzymes and pathways of secondary metabolism and natural product biosynthesis for novel chemistry that may be of value for the betterment of human health and well-being. A particular emphasis is placed on the detailed mechanisms and evolution of radical-mediated chemical reactions leading to structurally unique antiviral (oxetanocin A and albucidin), antifungal (blasticidin S) and antihelminthic agents (hikizimycin) as well as the biosynthesis of high energy (ladderane) and antibacterial agents (oxazinomycin and albomycin). By investigating these and similar systems, we aim to establish the fundamental chemical principles by which these reactions occur and in particular how highly reactive radical intermediates are guided towards biochemically useful compounds.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proper three-dimensional organization of DNA within the nucleus is critically important for healthy cells, and alterations to organization are associated with developmental disease and cancer. This research program aims to better characterize the patterns of DNA organization that occur in healthy cells and to investigate how these impact important cellular processes such as gene expression, DNA replication, and DNA repair. A more complete understanding of how 3D genome organization functions within the cell will provide key insights into why this process is associated with human disease and may inform new therapeutic strategies.

Particular strengths are deep quantitative training with emphasis on Bayesian reasoning, to de- emphasize dichotomous (significant vs. not significant) thinking, and provide directly interpretable probabilistic frameworks that improve clinical decision making under uncertainty. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This postdoctoral T32 application is designed to train 3 translational science researchers at the postdoctoral level who will help build a community of clinical and translational scientists by leveraging the multi-institutional multi-disciplinary strengths of a Center for Clinical and Translational Sciences (CCTS) Clinical and Translational Science Award (CTSA) based at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston (UTH-H). Through the TL1 Training Core which preceded this application and was awarded as an educational arm of the CCTS CTSA, we have already successfully trained postdoctoral fellows who have gone onto productive jobs within the translational science spectrum. In this proposal, we will continue to train future leaders in translation science while integrating trainees from CCTS partner institutions across Texas, which will bring additional diversity to the T32 since these trainees draw upon the broad racial, ethnic, gender, economic and social backgrounds represented in Texas, and will enable the sharing of unique ideas and collaborative opportunities among our CCTS partners.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This predoctoral T32 application is seeking to train six translational science researchers at the predoctoral level who will build a community of clinical and translational scientists by leveraging the trans-institutional multi- disciplinary strengths of our Center for Clinical and Translational Sciences (CCTS) based at the University of Texas Health Science Center at Houston (UTH-H). Through a TL1 grant which preceded this application, awarded as the training core of the CCTS, we have trained 94 diverse and productive translational researchers, 57% of whom are female, 16% of whom are underrepresented and 31% of whom are faculty at domestic academic institutions. In the proposed training program, we will continue to train leaders in translation science while integrating trainees from CCTS partner institutions in south and east Texas, thereby bringing additional diversity to the T32 since these trainees will draw upon the broad racial, ethnic, gender, economic and social backgrounds represented in Texas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed research is to implement and evaluate a comprehensive community- level approach, Healthy Communities for Youth, that includes both a selective hospital-based prevention strategy, Emerging Leaders, and universal prevention strategies that increase Positive Youth Development opportunities through participatory action research, stakeholder education, community mobilization, and an overall focus on increasing community capacity for prevention. Key project aims are to evaluate the impact of Healthy Communities for Youth on community rates of youth violence using surveillance data and evaluate the impact of each violence prevention strategy on proximal outcomes including their impact on risk factors and protective processes related to multiple forms of youth violence.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR INJURY PREVENTION AND CONTROL
PHR: CYE PROJECT NARRATIVE: The proposed Center for Youth Equity (CYE) at Tulane University would be the first CDC-funded Prevention Research Center in the Gulf South explicitly focused on youth violence prevention, despite a significant need for such a resource—especially in states like Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama with the top homicide rates in the country. The CYE is relevant to public health because it will integrate, build upon, and transform interdisciplinary research, outreach, and training programs to create a synergistic hub and resource for youth violence and injury prevention in the Gulf South region. The proposed center is relevant to the mission of the CDC's National Center for Injury Prevention and Control because it aims to prevent and reduce violence, injury, and their resulting consequences and health disparities, particularly in a hard-hit city like New Orleans, Louisiana and the Gulf South region.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The incidence of multiple sclerosis (MS), one of the most common disabling neurological diseases in young adults, is rapidly increasing in the U.S. and other countries, particularly in African Americans and in women of all races. There is compelling evidence that vitamin D insufficiency is a modifiable risk factor for multiple sclerosis, but uncertainties remain on the levels of vitamin D needed to prevent MS in different groups defined by race, age, and gender. Purpose of this project is to fill these gaps and thus obtain the solid evidence that is needed to implement effective strategies for MS prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The incidence of esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC), a deadly cancer, has risen rapidly in the United States. In this study, we will characterize the primary driving forces transforming Barrett’s esophagus into malignant EAC using advanced epigenomic approaches. Furthermore, we will investigate the mechanistic basis of the strong association between obesity and EAC. Our results hold the promise to fundamentally transform the understanding of neoplastic evolution of esophagus, while simultaneously discovering novel driver genes, pathways and potential actionable targets for EAC.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: More than 42,000 individuals with spinal cord injury (SCI) are eligible for treatment in the VA Healthcare System, with direct healthcare expenditures exceeding $716 million/year. Bone loss is a hallmark of severe SCI that produces 20- to 100-fold higher fracture risk, with extended post-fracture hospitalization. Moreover, the risk for respiratory illness, venous thromboembolic events, pressure ulcers, urinary tract infections, and other medial comorbidities more than doubles in persons with SCI within 1-month of fracture, which contributes to the 30% higher 5-yr mortality risk that exists for those with versus without fracture after SCI. Despite these consequences, no physical rehabilitation regimen or pharmacologic therapy has been shown to consistently improve BMD recovery after SCI or to completely prevent bone loss at the most fracture prone sites in this population. These findings provide strong justification for studies that focus on identifying and optimizing strategies to improve skeletal integrity and reduce fracture incidence in Veterans with SCI.

It will comprehensively test four psychosocial pathways as potential mediators linking wealth to problem behaviors, as well as provide descriptive data about variations in wealth over time within a socioeconomically and racially/ethnically diverse group of families with adolescents. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Mosquitoes that prefer to live among and bite humans spread the most disease. Recent work suggests that populations of the dengue, Zika, chikungunya, and yellow fever mosquito Aedes aegypti are evolving a greater preference for human hosts in the rapidly growing cities of sub-Saharan Africa. This project is designed to test this prediction in the field, across urban-rural gradients in Ouagadougou, Burkina Faso and Kumasi, Ghana, and identify specific genes associated with this behavioral shift.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Closed head traumatic brain injury (CH-TBI) has been a major component of injury in Iraq and Afghanistan with lingering quality of life eroding disabilities such as spasticity, gait, balance, anxiety and cognitive disorders that produce a substantial health care responsibility. There are also rapidly growing concerns that TBI is a risk factor for lingering inflammation that can significantly increase the risk of progressive neurodegenerative disorders in the future. Accordingly, there is an urgent need to increase our understanding of injury-induced long-term disability mechanisms, and to test the safety and efficacy of therapeutic measures that target these mechanisms utilizing approaches that have excellent potential for rapid translation. The proposed studies focus on TBI- induced microbleeds mediated neural, vascular, and inflammatory injury and their treatment. Translation of these findings may provide safe and effective intervention strategies that can significantly benefit the veterans’ health care system.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Asthma remains one of the most important challenges to pediatric public health in the United States affecting millions of children and adults, particularly in vulnerable urban populations; the molecular, environmental and genetic bases for this burden remain incompletely understood. We will contribute extensively to the Childhood Asthma in Urban Settings Clinical Research Centers Network (CAUSE) as a Clinical Research Unit through successful implementation, scientific expertise, and training of the next generation of NIH funded investigators skilled in asthma. Based on our previous work on novel NOTCH4 mechanistic pathways on airway inflammation, we will specifically examine the role that NOTCH4 signaling acts to regulate airway inflammation and increases asthma severity and loss of asthma control in urban school children, enlightening our understanding of pathways and mechanisms that may pave the way for future targeted novel biomarker driven approaches and improve the lives of vulnerable urban children with asthma.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative PIWI-interacting RNA (piRNA)-mediated silencing of transposable elements is critical in preserving the integrity of the genome in germ cells, with the loss of the piRNA pathway leading to sterility and potentially aging and cancer. Recent studies indicate that piRNAs are expressed in a sexually dimorphic manner and yet the mechanisms by which this occurs remains poorly understood. In this proposal, I aim to characterize the sex- specific transcription complexes that uniquely drive the expression of male and female piRNAs and explore the surprising molecular link to the transcription of snRNAs of the spliceosome.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Advancing current rehabilitation approaches is limited by an inability to robustly identify individual-specific differences in gait impairments. In this project, we aim to develop a sensitive, data-driven, consistent tool using continuous, multi-joint gait dynamics to characterize individual-specific differences in stroke gait and evaluate individuals’ potential to improve their ankle push-off with exposure to a single session of functional electrical stimulation (FES) delivered during fast walking (FastFES). Understanding individual-specific gait impairments is necessary for the development of tailored rehabilitation approaches to potentially correct the high variation of gait impairments amongst stroke survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project narrative Hereditary spastic paraplegias (HSP) are inherited disorder of long central axons in the corticospinal tracts. More than half of all affected families currently remain without a definite diagnosis because the underlying genetic factors that cause their disease have not been identified yet. Our study aims to use whole genome sequencing in exome -negative patients to identify these unknown HSP genes. We also plan a large SPG4 modifier study. This will ultimately allow to devise strategies to treat these diseases.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE PIWI-interacting RNAs (piRNAs) are expressed in a sex-specific manner across many species, including human. Understanding how sex-specific piRNA expression regulates germline gene expression is paramount to advancing our knowledge of piRNA-mediated regulation beyond transposon silencing and improving therapeutic strategies for infertility. Using C. elegans as a model, the proposed research will define regulatory machinery underlying sex-specific piRNA expression and identify endogenous gene targets of piRNAs to provide a deeper understanding of piRNAs in germline development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Viral diseases remain a leading cause of death worldwide, necessitating an increase in training in virology. The complexity and diversity of persistence and pathogenesis mechanisms utilized by viruses pose major challenges to the development of effective vaccines and chemical or immune-based treatments of viral diseases. A goal of the training program is the recruitment of undergraduates and recent Ph.D. graduates in related disciplines (biochemistry, biological sciences, cellular and molecular biology, etc) into advanced studies in mechanisms of viral persistence and pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative About 1.6 million people in the U.S. have type 1 diabetes, who face the daily threat of developing dangerously low blood glucose episodes, potentially resulting in confusion, life-threatening cardiac events, or even death. Despite using advanced diabetes technologies such as continuous glucose monitors, many patients continue to develop these devastating episodes due to sub-optimal management of low blood glucose events. This research project will expand knowledge of type 1 diabetes patients’ beliefs that prevent them from treating low blood glucose episodes; resultant insight will be applied to develop and pilot test a patient-centered behavior- changing program to improve patients’ self-management of low blood glucose episodes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Deciphering the interplay of transcriptional enhancers and gene expression within three-dimensional chromatin architecture is a fundamental challenge in molecular biology, and to answer these questions, minimally-pertubative, localizable tools that enable real-time, high-resolution analysis are needed. The proposed research details a genetically-encodable, photo-controllable tool that can be used to map the molecular interactome of three-dimensional chromatin structures within live cells with high spatiotemporal resolution. Successful completion of the proposed research will uncover causative impacts of higher-order chromosomal architecture on gene regulation, and their role in cancer development and progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Abnormal mucociliary clearance (MCC) is a critical component of cystic fibrosis (CF) lung disease, especially in the presence of infection with pathogens such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Separating the effects of infection and inflammation have been difficult with currently available in vitro model systems. We have recently developed a novel CF rat model that enables the study of mucus in the presence and absence of infection and inflammation, allowing for detailed identification of the underlying mechanism, in a way that is directly relatable to the human phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE African-American women have strikingly high rates of cardiovascular disease (CVD) morbidity and mortality, and this is especially true at midlife. Theoretical and non-human primate models suggest that social stressors and ovarian aging may play a role, and the science proposed in this application is designed to examine these associations in a cohort of African-American women. The mentoring and training proposed in this application is designed to foster a supportive environment for the careers of junior patient-oriented researchers interested in social exposures and CVD risk in vulnerable groups of women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite advances in screening, colorectal cancer remains a leading cause of cancer-related death due to a high recurrence rate after initial treatment and a dismal 14.3% survival rate of patients with recurrent disease. Improving survival from colorectal cancer requires the ability to develop effective biomarkers for early detection of recurrent/pre-metastatic disease. We leverage computational approaches to integrate imaging and –omics analyses to establish and validate a non-invasive biomarker for risk of metastases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Subjective clinical assessments of patient risk in HPV-associated oropharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma (OPC) could be improved with our novel objective liquid biopsy assay of the inflammatory fluid that collects in Jackson Pratt surgical drains. We believe we can use this proximal liquid analyte to sensitively detect tumor-shed cell-free HPV (cf-HPV) and comprehensively characterize tumor homing effector immune cells. We predict the integration of surgical drain fluid cf-HPV analysis with leukocyte immunophenotyping will predict patient pathological risk and patterns of recurrence, and could eventually be used to prospectively select candidates for treatment de-intensification clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alphavirus infection causes a robust innate immune response in host cells, including global protein translation shutoff, to reduce viral replication and prevent spread. However, alphaviruses have evolved unclear mechanisms to continue effective viral protein synthesis under conditions of translation shutoff. This proposal seeks to identify the mechanism by which alphaviruses initiate translation and modulate the host translational shutoff response with the goal of identifying novel targets for antivirals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Studies of fundamental cell death mechanisms provide unique opportunities for molecularly designed cancer therapeutics. The BCL-2 family proteins are central regulators of cell death and validated anti-cancer targets. We propose to investigate the molecular mechanisms by which BCL-2 family proteins regulate cell death with the hope that our study will enable novel targeted therapeutic strategies that specifically trigger cell death in cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The human gut microbiome plays an important role in human health by producing drug-like small molecules. Despite the importance of microbial metabolism to human health and disease, little is known about the metabolic strategies that underlie production of drug-like small molecules by the gut microbiota. This project will define the pathways microbes in the gut use to make these molecules and develop new tools to study the metabolism of genetically intractable gut bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Intestinal schistosomiasis is a disease caused predominantly by Schistosoma mansoni and capable of causing notable sequelae including severe liver fibrosis, portal hypertension and often-fatal oesophageal bleeding. Its impact is most severe in poor, often hard-to-reach, communities in sub-Saharan Africa. The Uganda Schistosomiasis Multidisciplinary Research Center brings together international partners to build expertise and understanding of the underlying determinants of severe schistosomal morbidity, addressing each stage of the parasite’s life cycle; and to develop an integrated model for identifying appropriate interventions for prevention and management of this important disease.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative  In species with distinct sexes, gonad development is informed by the activity of autosomal, and in some cases sex chromosome-associated, gene products. Even in organisms in which sex is determined by inheritance of sex chromosomes, disruptions of autosomal-regulated mechanisms and environmental influences can be detrimental to sexual development and negatively impact reproductive health. Thus, understanding the pathways regulating sexual development has important implications for reproductive development, health, and fertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Despite the clinical success of PD-1 blockade in treating multiple cancer types by alleviating suppression of anti- tumor T cell responses, the majority of cancer patients do not achieve durable remission. The proposed research will investigate metabolic pathways involved in the regulation of anti-tumor T cell function and responsiveness to PD-1 blockade. The goals of our studies are to identify the metabolic requirements of effective anti-tumor immunity and to define novel metabolic intervention strategies that may synergize with PD-1 blockade.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Most children with cancer survive because they are given intensive treatments, but unfortunately, these treatments are associated with distressing symptoms. To address this problem, we developed the Symptom Screening in Pediatrics Tool (SSPedi) so that children receiving cancer treatments can communicate their bothersome symptoms, and Supportive care Prioritization, Assessment and Recommendations for Kids (SPARK), a web-based application that links identified symptoms to supportive care guidelines for symptom management. To establish that these tools improve the lives of children newly diagnosed with cancer, we will conduct a trial that randomizes 20 pediatric cancer institutions and measures the impact of three times weekly symptom screening, symptom feedback to healthcare providers and the development of care pathways for symptom management to improve total symptom burden, fatigue and quality of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative CRISPR-Cas9 systems are frequently found in pathogenic bacteria, where they defend against phages but also prevent the horizontal transfer of antibiotic resistance genes and toxins. Here, we explore novel functions of Cas9 as a non-canonical transcriptional regulator, which could contribute to bacterial pathophysiology and inform new generations of regulatable Cas9 tools for the treatment of genetic diseases. We also study the heterogeneity of CRISPR-Cas immunity in single cells, which will have implications for the survival of human pathogens under stress and their treatment with phage therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Moderate noise that does not necessarily affect audiometric thresholds can nevertheless cause significant hearing impairments by damaging cochlear synapses. We have found that female mice are overall less susceptible to such damage but female susceptibility varies through the estrous cycle with lowest susceptibility when progesterone levels are highest. In addition to progesterone, we have identified other treatments that promote regeneration of the synapses after noise exposure in mice that are potential therapeutic targets for this type of hearing impairment in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative Frequent binge alcohol drinking is a significant risk factor for developing an alcohol use disorder (AUD). Understanding how excessive alcohol use engages the brain is critical for discovering potential treatments, however, it is not known how alcohol differentially impacts the brains of males and females. This project uses a mouse model to investigate how the nucleus accumbens core impacts ethanol reward and binge-like drinking in both males and females.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Gene rearrangements involving receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) represent a frequent and diverse set of oncogenic driver alterations across human cancer, and resistance to tyrosine kinase inhibitor (TKI) therapies are inevitable for most patients with advanced cancers and the major cause of mortality. We recently discovered that notable RTK fusion oncoproteins form their own pathogenic subcellular compartment, membraneless cytoplasmic RTK protein granules, to coordinate oncogenic RTK and RAS signaling. This proposal will test therapeutic approaches that exploit the unique signaling properties of this cancer-specific biomolecular condensate.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The alarming antibiotic resistance of current pathogens and the emergence of new disease agents have made clear the necessity of increased fundamental scientific investigation into all aspects of infectious diseases. The purpose of the Washington University Training Program in Infectious Diseases/Basic Microbial Pathogenesis is to help fulfill this need by recruiting promising young investigators to this field and training them in outstanding research programs with preeminent investigators who collaborate across multiple disciplines to perform infectious disease research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This Racial/Ethnic Disparities in Heart Failure: A Cross-Cohort Collaboration study will evaluate the magnitude and potential causes of racial/ethnic and sex disparities in incident heart failure and its subtypes and their prognosis in over 130,000 men and women from 10 pooled cohorts. We will evaluate the impact of hypothetical lifestyle and clinical risk factors interventions on reducing the racial/ethnic disparities in developing HF. In addition using unsupervised machine learning phenomapping techniques, we will evaluate subtypes of HF and their prognosis, including models stratified by race/ethnicity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Infection with enteric pathogens such as Salmonella, Campylobacter, Shigella, or Yersinia are leading causes of morbidity and mortality worldwide. Although in most individuals the infection resolves, approximately 5% of patients develop a painful form of inflammatory arthritis known as reactive arthritis (ReA). In this application, using Salmonella as a model, we will elucidate the mechanisms by which enteric pathogens trigger autoimmunity and ReA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: U01 Project Narrative Despite extensive research into and highly promising outcomes from cancer immunotherapy, immune-related adverse events remain unpredictable, potentially severe, possibly permanent, and—particularly with combination immunotherapy regimen—relatively common. Our proposed research will capitalize on our team’s years of experience in the genetic and molecular characterization of autoimmune diseases, as well as a previously assembled cohort of hundreds of patients treated with immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy for cancer, to perform, analyze, integrate, and validate biomarkers for the prediction of immune checkpoint inhibitor efficacy and toxicity. These findings may ultimately be used to guide patient selection, treatment, and monitoring, thereby impacting public health at a high level in both the near- and long-term.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Bronchiolitis obliterans syndrome (BOS) is an irreversible obstructive lung disease and a significant cause of morbidity and mortality in hematopoietic stem cell transplant (HSCT) recipients. HSCT patients are often referred for pulmonary evaluation only after significant respiratory decline due to the relative insensitivity of spirometry, especially in young children, and as a result, BOS is often undiagnosed until the disease has progressed beyond the point where therapy will significantly improve the disease course and outcome. The proposed research will identify novel biomarkers for early diagnosis of BOS post HSCT and establish a dynamic prediction model for BOS to provide a platform for testing future preventive and therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The pacemaker cells that reside within the cardiac inflow tract are essential for setting the rhythm of the heartbeat. Despite their importance, the mechanisms responsible for establishing an appropriate number of specialized pacemaker cells at the inflow tract are not yet understood. Identification of the genetic pathways that regulate inflow tract formation has the potential to improve our comprehension of the causes of congenital heart disease and may inspire new strategies for regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The long-term survival rate in cardiac transplantation is poor, and immune-mediated damage remains as the primary cause of chronic graft failure. This study addresses major knowledge gaps in the mechanisms by which the gut microbiome induces immune modulation that could prolong immunologic quiescence to improve graft survival. This is a fundamental step towards novel advances in diagnosis and preventive therapeutics against graft rejection to improve health and quality of life, all of which are within the mission of NIAID.

ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative Intestinal fungi are an important component of the microbiota, and recent studies have unveiled their potential in modulating inflammatory disease. Nonetheless, the mechanisms governing immunity to gut fungi (gut mycobiota) remain unknown. In this proposal, we will study a network of immune cells in the gut, called phagocytes, with superior capability to sense, interact (phagocyte) and respond to fungi during health and during intestinal disease.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Kidney cancer is among the most common malignancies in both men and women. It is highly prevalent in the Veteran population as analysis of VA Central Cancer Registry Data indicates that cancer of the kidney is among the most common tumor types. Kidney tumors undergo extensive changes in their metabolism as compared with the normal kidney. These includes alterations in the metabolism of amino acids, the basic building blocks of protein. Notably, these changes are found in other tumor types that commonly impact Veterans. The goal of this proposal will be to determine how these changes occur in kidney tumors and their biologic significance. Specifically, we will determine how these changes accelerate tumor growth. We will also determine how these changes contribute to metastasis, an event that portends a poor prognosis for patients. The overarching goal will be to identify novel strategies that can be translated into the clinic to improve the outcomes of Veterans with kidney cancer.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Reducing suicides and premature mortality among youth with depression has been identified as a national priority and an important goal for health systems, yet no studies have examined the impact of pediatric depression care meeting quality standards on important patient outcomes such as depression recurrence, self- harm, suicide, and overall mortality. In response to FOA PAR 17-264, the proposed research uses national Medicaid data linked with mortality data for youth aged 10 to 17 with a new episode of Major Depression to examine determinants and consequences of guideline concordant depression care. Evidence from this study will inform and guide more effective clinical practices and policies for the care of children and adolescents with major depressive disorder.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Improving Quality and Outcomes for Low Income Children with Depression in the US

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Control of immune defenses in the intestine is critically important for human health. We anticipate that this work will offer fundamental insights into pathogen sensing and immune control of importance to all metazoan hosts, including humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Twenty-five percent of individuals in the U.S. have a chronic rheumatic condition including arthritis and many have increased risk of severe COVID-19 from these conditions, related comorbidities or immunosuppressive medications. COVID-19 vaccination hesitancy persists in this population, particularly among Black individuals who suffer disproportionately from serious infections and poorer outcomes compared to White individuals. Our community-academic partnership will design, implement and evaluate an intervention that trains community leaders with rheumatic conditions to disseminate vaccine-related information through their social networks in Black communities to promote racial justice in vaccine uptake.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The paradigm-shifting discoveries in RNA modiﬁcations have added RNA to the picture of dynamic regulation of gene expression through reversible chemical modiﬁcations. Successful transcriptome- wide proﬁling of RNA modiﬁcations can signiﬁcantly advance the frontier of epitranscriptomics research and associate epitranscriptomic variations with human health and diseases. The aim of this proposal is to develop bioinformatics infrastructures and computational tools for epitranscriptomics studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The novel coronavirus 2019 (COVID) pandemic is the most significant Public Health crisis of the past century, and African-Americans are disproportionately impacted-- with rates of COVID-19 infection and mortality that are 2 to 4 times higher than those in Whites. Because most research on COVID-19 has focused on the physiological consequences of the disease, we know almost nothing about the psychosocial impact of COVID- 19, particularly in the most vulnerable groups. The goal of the proposed project is to examine the impact of COVID-related psychosocial stressors on vascular aging in a cohort of African-American women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The goal of this basic research proposal is to characterize a novel enzymatic activity whose loss we find to be associated with neurodegeneration in mice and humans, and to determine to what extent this activity plays a protective role against cytotoxicity. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE If humans lose their reproductive cells (i.e. eggs and sperm) they become infertile, in contrast, some animals regenerate their reproductive cells and reproductive organs. This project’s goal is to uncover the mechanisms of reproductive cell and tissue regeneration by identifying the cell types and genes involved in this process. Through its focus on reproductive cell regeneration, stem cell activity, and cell reprogramming, our project will contribute to our fundamental knowledge of reproductive and stem cell biology and will inform regenerative medicine approaches.

IC_NAME: AGENCY FOR HEALTHCARE RESEARCH AND QUALITY
PHR: Project Narrative As tragically evidenced by COVID-19, epidemics can surge dramatically, change continually, and significantly strain health systems, for example with the SARS-CoV-2 virus (to-date) infecting over 250 million worldwide, killing over 5 million, and impacting safe equitable care, including makeshift rooming, equipment and staff shortages, rationed care, and other crisis management. As in past epidemics, affected regions and states were unprepared to handle unpredictable and significantly differing local surges in timing, severity, duration, and re- currence, with broad agreement of the need to be better prepared for future epidemics, including how best to leverage facility-level operational models to safely manage care capacity surges. This project thus will refine, evaluate, and study the use, accuracy, and impact on patient, staff, and system safety of novel facility-specific 30-day ahead rolling bed, equipment, and staff surge capacity models, evaluating performance under a wide range of past and future scenarios via both retrospective COVID-19 data from varied health partners and pro- spective computer simulation of future epidemics.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Epidemic Surge Model Use to Improve Patient, Staff, and System Safety and Resiliency
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Healthcare Patient Safety and Quality Improvement Research[HSQR]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Innate immune signal transduction pathways are major targets of bacterial toxins and effector proteins. This proposal examines the ability of a family of bacterial type III effector proteins to hijack human signaling enzymes. Gaining a deeper understanding of how these bacterial effectors hijack components of the host inflammasome using biochemistry, X-ray crystallography, and in vivo models will lead to a more complete knowledge of numerous pathogenic mechanisms and may reveal new aspects of signal transduction in the human host cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a devastating, fatal illness that will affect more than 10 million Americans by mid-century. The ε4 allele of the Apolipoprotein E gene (APOE4) is a common, potent risk factor for AD, found in more than half of patients. The current study will aim to understand how local genetic variants near APOE4 (and other AD-relevant genes) alter the structure and amount of the gene’s protein and how that impacts AD risk.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE  Acquired resistance to ticks is commonly known as “tick resistance”. This proposal seeks to elucidate the antigens in Ixodes scapularis saliva that contribute to the development of tick resistance and characterize the host response to these antigens. This will lead to important new information that can be used to develop a novel vaccine to prevent Lyme disease and, potentially other tick-borne infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We will use random germline mutagenesis and a panel of 38 FACS and immunization screens to discover genes necessary for immune cell development and function. An advancement from the previous R01, this renewal application incorporates new computational tools that will improve our ability to identify causative mutations and to discover functional links between proteins, thereby delineating molecular pathways. We will also focus on understanding the mechanisms of several mutated genes linked to mRNA and tRNA regulation, vesicle trafficking and release, and transcription, which were previously unknown to function in immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Medication for opioid use disorder (MOUD) is the first-line treatment for opioid use disorder (OUD), and although difficulties sleeping are highly prevalent, persistent, and connected to negative treatment outcomes in persons receiving MOUD, treatment options for sleep problems are limited. The present study will develop and test a mobile application to meet this treatment need for an easily disseminated, evidence-based, behavioral sleep intervention for those receiving MOUD. This approach to treatment has the potential to be expanded and significantly impact sleep problems, which are common across all types of substance use disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We will develop generalizable and potentially transformative methods to selectively target the RNA repeat expansions that cause >30 incurable neuromuscular diseases and genetically-defined dementia. Indeed, we will expand the repertoire of drug action to: (i) exploit RNA repeat structures to synthesize their own drugs in only disease-affected tissues; (ii) recruit endogenous nucleases directly to RNA repeat expansions selectively; and (iii) harness the activity of natural RNA decay pathways to eliminate the disease-causing RNA. These studies could establish a completely new paradigm for studying human disease pathology caused by toxic structured RNAs and will deliver molecules to study RNA biology and tools to inform target engagement in situ and in vivo.

PROJECT_TITLE: Design of precision small molecules targeting RNA repeating transcripts to manipulate and study disease biology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative diseases resulting from nucleotide triplet expansions, such as HD and ALS, lack any disease-modifiying therapy. We will establish a first-in-class paradigm for the use of in vivo gene editing for these diseases - allele-specific excision of the disease-causing expansion - and reduce it to preclinical and regulatory practice. To this end we will (i) develop a mutually synergistic suite of CRISPR-Cas9 preclinical leads for both mutant HTT and mutant C9ORF92; (ii) using multiple innovative viral and nonviral delivery formulations, perform IND-enabling preclinical pharmacology, toxicology, CMC, and biodistribution studies; (iii) advance an AAV-formulated CRISPR-Cas approach for HD to IND, and for ALS - to pre-IND.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: OVERALL PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood cell production is the result of distinctive, heterogeneous individual primitive cells collectively generating mature cell offspring and when one of those primitive cells acquires a mutation, we propose that how it will behave depends on features present in the cell of origin and how the mutation affects cell signaling. Specific molecular features of the mutant clone may then provide predictive information about the pathogenic potential of a clone. Further, the metabolic alterations accompanying modified cell behavior can reveal exploitable vulnerabilities to guide testable, low intensity approaches to reducing clonal burden.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Navigating an environment requires constantly sensing and integrating information from surroundings in addition to generating coordinated motor commands. Understanding the neural mechanisms of the entire transformation process from multisensory integration to motor execution is critical to understand and treat diseases with impaired sensory-motor coordination, such as cerebellar ataxia, a deficit that manifests as a poorly tuned control system. This proposal will leverage advantages of a highly tractable model system, the fruit fly, to determine how sensory systems collect and integrate diverse information and how it guides navigational decisions and generate fast motor outputs in the nervous system, ultimately discovering the neural circuit motifs shared by many species including humans.

ORG_NAME: FOX CHASE CHEMICAL DIVERSITY CENTER, INC
PHR: NARRATIVE Herpes Keratitis is the leading cause of corneal blindness in the USA and the world. The significant emergence of acyclovir-resistant herpes virus in eye infections necessitates the development of a new, safe and effective drug. The goal of this research is to prevent loss of vision by continuing the development of a novel, n0n-toxic drug that specifically targets herpes virus that infects the eye.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is an aggressive breast cancer type with few treatment options and poor prognosis. A defining characteristic of TNBC is loss or inactivation of a protein called p53. We identified a drug combination that targets TNBC cells when where p53 is lost or inactivated, and we want to test this drug combination against TNBC tumors in mice and determine the mechanisms involved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: We have previously monitored brain and behavioral development in nearly 300 autistic and typically developing children in the MIND Institute’s Autism Phenome Project. Up to 4 MRI scans have been carried out when the child is between 3 and 12 years of age and we propose to do an additional scan between 14-17. We have discovered that subgroups of children with autism have different, altered patterns of brain development. We have also found that 69% have serious anxiety symptoms and nearly 30% of children improve in symptom severity whereas 18% increase and about 50% stay the same. We propose to evaluate brain and behavioral changes as these children enter adolescence. The goal is to enable more effective targeted treatments for defined subgroups of individuals with autism.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in the United States and is responsible for more than a third of all deaths each year. CVD risk factors develop in young adulthood and impact a person's risk for CVD events later in life. This study will use advanced statistical methods to combine data from 20 longitudinal studies in order to better understand CVD risk factor trajectories across the life course and their association with CVD on a diverse sample of the United States population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Human papillomaviruses are causative agents in a number of ano-genital and oral cancers; HPV causes 5% of all cancers. There are no therapeutics that target the virus to assist with the alleviation of this disease burden and the focus of this application is to enhance our understanding of the HPV16 life cycle in order to identify novel therapeutic targets. We have discovered a novel cellular complex, WRN-SAMHD1-MRN, that regulates the HPV16 life cycle and will dissect the role of this complex in regulation of HPV replication levels and fidelity; we will also investigate how HPV influences host DNA replication and the innate immune response.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section  The proposed research is relevant to the public health because AKI, increasing in incidence, represents a major public health concern with high human and financial costs. Other than supportive treatment through dialysis, there are no established therapeutic interventions to improve survival, limit injury, or promote recovery in patients with AKI. Upon conclusion, we will provide new insights into how systemic HIF-2 activation affects postischemic kidney injury and repair through tryptophan metabolism, and this discovery will create novel therapeutic opportunities in the field of AKI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Recent studies have shown that endothelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EndMT) is potentially the key driving force behind the development and progression of atherosclerosis. We have now identified a metabolic step that seems critical to the control of EndMT, and for which we are developing new therapeutic approaches. The proof of this discovery will open new therapeutic possibilities for treating diseases such as heart attacks, stroke, pulmonary hypertension and peripheral vascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  During the last ten years, it has become apparent that deregulation or disruption of proteins residing at the Intercalated Disk (ICD), the unique membrane microdomain that mediates the mechanical and electrical coupling of cardiomyocytes, leads to cardiac defects and development of severe or lethal cardiomyopathies. The proposed studies will provide important and novel information about the modulation of a major component of the ICD, N-cadherin, via the enzymatic activity of the obscurin Ser/Thr kinase domain 1. Elucidating the molecular mechanisms that underlie cell-cell adhesion and communication in cardiac muscle during normalcy will allow us to understand how these are altered or compromised during congenital heart disease, and thus enable us to develop new, effective, and targeted therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Household food insecurity during infancy is a risk factor for later childhood obesity. In this pilot and feasibility study, we will randomly assign infant-parent dyads with household food insecurity to either 1) the Food FARMacia mobile food pantry intervention with self-directed meal preparation support or 2) self-directed meal preparation support. In addition to examining feasibility, acceptability, and satisfaction, we will estimate intervention effects on infant weight characteristics and explore potential mediators to inform a subsequent full- scale trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Healthy cognitive processing is associated with well-defined oscillatory neuronal activity, and some aspects of brain oscillations have been reported to be disrupted in any of the major psychiatric and neurological diseases. Selectively targeting brain oscillations for treatment could thus profoundly improve cognitive function in disease. To provide a foundation for such therapies, our objective is to show to what extent brain stimulation affects local neural computations as well as long-distance communication between brain regions, and our studies will therefore provide a neurobiological foundation for further developing invasive and non-invasive brain stimulation therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative RORgt+ group 3 innate lymphoid cells play an important role in infection/inflammation. The proposed experiments will provide novel insights into the role of iron metabolism in ILC3s, and the Ahr-CD71 axis in regulation of RORgt+ cell maintenance and function under the steady state and during infections. Infectious diseases have been increasingly exacting a substantial toll on health in US, and the knowledge gained in this study will help the development of new therapeutic strategies by exploiting the Ahr-CD71-iron axis in ILC3s to combat infection and control inflammation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This program addresses a critical need of the field of gerontology for scholars who combine quantitative expertise with immersion in science on aging. Such scholars are crucial because cutting-edge research on aging involves complex data on persons' biological and clinical characteristics, physical and social environments, and health care utilization. Only with such scholars' leadership can data be collected and analyzed so as to yield valid scientific discoveries on improved outcomes for our older population.

PROJECT_TITLE: Epidemiology and Biostatistics of Aging

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Alternative splicing is a major mechanism that generates the diverse proteome during development and is frequently disrupted in many human diseases. We develop a new technology, SHARCLIP, to build a transcriptome-wide structure-interaction map for pre-mRNP complexes on which alternative splicing occurs. This technology and resource will help understand mechanisms of splicing-related diseases and empower future RNA-targeting therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Ultra-high dose rate radiotherapy a.k.a. FLASH radiotherapy has shown the potential to drastically reduce the normal tissue toxicity without compromising tumor cell killing. However, the delivery of FLASH is hampered by the limitations inherent to existing radiotherapy platforms. We propose to develop a groundbreaking new X-ray system ROAD to achieve the needed FLASH dose rate for significantly improved cancer radiotherapy efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The apicoplast organelle is required for the survival of malaria parasites in humans and for parasite transmission to mosquitoes. Our goal is to identify and characterize parasite genes responsible for maintaining the apicoplast using forward and reverse genetics approaches. These studies will identify novel proteins essential for the survival of malaria parasites and have significant implications for the development of therapeutics targeting blood stage malaria parasites and parasite transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research is relevant to a variety of diseases that affect the public health, including hypertension, pulmonary hypertension, and atherosclerosis. Specifically, we plan to focus on unique metabolites (small-molecule products of human metabolism) that can modulate the function of an important cell type in the blood vessel that contributes to these diseases, the vascular smooth muscle cell. Our plan is to study the effects of these unique metabolites on vascular smooth muscle cell metabolism and function, with the hope that we can identify potential novel metabolic therapies that can prevent or treat these common global cardiovascular diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE HIV persists in a latent state in CD4+ T cells in patients on antiretroviral therapy (ART). We have recently shown that latent virus can be reactivated by targeting the non-canonical (nc) NF-κB pathway in SIV-infected, ART-treated rhesus macaques. In this proposal, we aim to pursue a deeper and broader understanding of the latency reversal induced by ncNF-κB signaling and its potential to reduce persistent reservoirs using an innovative “kick and kill” approach. The knowledge we gain may bring us closer to an HIV cure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Desmosomes are classically considered to provide mechanical support to the epidermis by connecting stress-resisting intermediate filaments to sites of cell-cell adhesion through the essential anchoring protein desmoplakin. But desmosomes are much more dynamic than this classic definition implies. Here we will determine what controls desmoplakin dynamics to create desmosomes with different properties during early and late stages of epidermal regeneration, and how interfering with these dynamics contributes to skin disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Regular exercise improves the quality of mitochondria, the power plants, in skeletal muscle with profound health benefits; however, the underlying mechanism(s) remain poorly understood. We have recently discovered physical association of a nutrient/energy sensing enzyme AMPK with mitochondria and obtain preliminary data to show its importance in getting rid of bad mitochondrial. This project will employ the state-of- the-art technologies to elucidate the regulation and function of this mitochondria-associated AMPK, which will help development of effective therapeutics to treat and prevent chronic diseases, such as diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance Statement Emerging pathogens, antibiotic resistance and the danger of pandemics from deadly infectious agents clearly demonstrate that infectious diseases continue to represent a serious worldwide threat to human health. Although it is clear and well documented that new therapeutics are urgently needed to combat this threat, the development of such therapeutics and the necessary basic research to support this development are failing to keep pace with this need. St. Jude Children’s Research Hospital has developed a superb translational research infrastructure well suited for therapeutic development, and this T32 program has been designed to leverage this infrastructure to train top-tier postdoctoral fellows with the necessary skills to lead independent research programs in the discovery of infectious diseases therapeutics.
PROJECT_TERMS: Communicable Diseases;design;Development;Therapeutic;Training
PROJECT_TITLE: Training in the Design and Development of Infectious Disease Therapeutics

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because optimizing treatment parameters based on individualized neurophysiology is broadly applicable to clinical populations who may benefit from improvements in function and psychosocial outcomes via adaptive brain reorganization. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NIDCD’s mission which seeks fundamental knowledge about the nature and behavior of living systems and to reduce the burden of illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE While ALS is characterized by the degeneration of “lower” motor neurons in the spinal cord and “upper” motor neurons in the cerebral cortex, the mechanisms that cause this selective vulnerability are unknown given that most disease-related genes are broadly expressed in many cell types throughout the nervous system. The proposed research program will utilize cutting edge molecular, cellular, and anatomical techniques to ask how the endogenous molecular and bioenergetic properties of upper motor neurons may lead to pathology by directly comparing them to a highly related but resilient neuronal population during disease progression in animal models of ALS and in tissue from ALS patients. The results obtained from this work will provide a better understanding of the molecular and cellular pathways that underlie the differential susceptibility of these cell types and identify novel therapeutic targets for clinical intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative While a great deal of progress has been made in identifying biomarkers that signal a preclinical phase of Alzheimer’s disease (AD) that occurs after the onset of pathophysiological processes (e.g., amyloid deposition) but prior to the appearance of clinical symptoms, biomarker positivity does not correspond to level of cognitive functioning in preclinical AD, nor does it provide prognostic information about the timeline for future cognitive and clinical decline. There is a critical need for inexpensive and easily administered methods of detecting and staging AD as it runs its course from the preclinical to symptomatic stages. This project will evaluate the ability of two novel cognitive markers – Visual Sensory Binding (VSB) and Visual Short Term Memory Binding (VSTMB) – to detect AD pathophysiological processes and predict impending decline in AD biomarker-positive individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: A cell's carbohydrate coat serves as an identification card (ID) for the host to detect pathogens, virus-infected, cancerous or other diseased cells. As critical directors of immunity, dendritic cells display many different proteins that can recognize the carbohydrates on normal or disease-causing cells to inhibit or activate immune responses. This project focuses on deciphering these critical dendritic cell “carbohydrate-ID checkers” influence immune responses and on co-opting them to regulate immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Many of the individuals who die by suicide are not clearly identified as such by Medical Examiners, and their causes of death are often categorized as undetermined with implications for state and national statistics of suicide and for understanding of the causes of suicide and accidental death. The proposed study aims to improve detection of suicide deaths by using large linked data sets, latent class analysis and psychological autopsy to better distinguish suicide among decedents whose cause of death is currently categorized as “undetermined” and to pinpoint variables that can be used to better identify such cases. In addition to improving the statistics of suicide at state and national level and identifying characteristics that will aid Medical Examiners in identifying suicide and accidental overdose deaths, the study will contribute to a better understanding of real world relationship between drug use and suicide and their impact on individuals, families, peers and society, as highlighted in NIDA’s current Strategic Plan.

PHR: Project Narrative Loss of the methylthioadenosine phosphorylase gene (MTAP) is one of the most frequent genetic alterations found in human cancer. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Blood cells are derived from bone marrow progenitor cells and released into circulation, where they play key roles in oxygen transport, immune response, and blood clotting. In the proposed research, we assemble the largest collection of participants with blood cell traits and whole genome sequencing and apply rigorous scientific methods to interrogate genome-wide structural variation and functional characterization of the blood cell associated structural variants. Results generated from this research may contribute to a better understanding of blood cell biology and pave the way for new research into precision medicine for blood diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Major gaps remain in our understanding of how the immune system recognizes and limits the growth of pathogens at the epithelial border and this proposal will provide new insights into how the CD40-CD40L interaction directs mucosal immunity to infection. The proposed studies leverage a newly tractable pathogen model that shows remarkable specificity to ECs and provides robust in vivo readouts of infection, control, and protection. The mechanisms discovered in the course of this program will be broadly relevant to the study of diseases of the intestinal tract of infectious, inflammatory and malignant etiology where CD40L has been implicated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Environmental toxicants, such as arsenic in drinking water, pose a significant risk for causing skeletal muscle myopathies and reduced regenerative capacity, as well as reduced contribution of muscle metabolism to systemic homeostasis; processes that are among the greatest factors contributing to declines in functional mobility and strong predictors of mortality. If successful, these studies will identify clinically relevant and immediately tractable strategies to reverse pathogenic muscle metabolism and maintenance from chronic arsenic exposures. The implication would be reduced arsenic-induced metabolic and cardiovascular disease burden, as well as reduced global burden of muscle quality decline that is an ever-increasing concern in aging populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MS Falls InsightTrack is a live, accessible, mobile personal health library for people with multiple sclerosis (MS) that in the short term, will increase the tracking of falls and their reporting to clinicians, provide insight into reasons for falls and strategies to prevent them (including community-level determinants), and support patient and clinician behaviors designed to reduce the incidence and severity of falls. A significant innovation is the closed loop that delivers patient-generated data (from wearables and patient self- reports) into the clinician's workflow, then returns these data, processed and integrated with relevant clinical and community-level data in actionable visualizations, back to patients. In the longer term, the human-centered design and modular nature of the technological build, which uses SMART-on-FHIR standards and integrates with the Epic EHR, will ensure the tool is accessible to diverse patients, can be generalized to other conditions characterized by fall risk, and can be widely scaled for any number of conditions or wearable technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI) has a profound impact on morbidity and mortality of surgical patients. Evidence suggests that the occurrence of myocardial ischemia-reperfusion injury follows a circadian pattern, with more severity of injury in the early morning. The current project aims to better understand the crosstalk between hypoxia (HIF2A) signaling and circadian rhythm (BMAL1) pathways to define novel strategies for the treatment or prevention of myocardial IRI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – CENTER OVERVIEW The Diabetes Research Center at the University of Washington has a long-standing tradition and record of facilitating scientific investigation aimed at informing on how best to treat and prevent diabetes, obesity, and related disorders. Through its biomedical research cores, Pilot and Feasibility Program as well as its Enrichment Program, it will continue to support over 120 scientists in the Greater Seattle area and beyond who are pursuing basic, translation and clinical investigation in these areas.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: TEXAS TECH UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIS CENTER
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the current project is to evaluate SLC6A14 as a viable drug target for PDAC, characterize autophagy and macropinocytosis induced in response to SLC6A14 inactivation, and to test the efficacy of a combination therapy that concurrently targets SLC6A14 and autophagy/macropinocytosis for a better therapeutic outcome in PDAC. This will be achieved by genetic deletion or pharmacological blockade of Slc6a14 in KPC mice, characterizing autophagy and macropinocytosis in SLC6A14-inactivated human PDAC cell lines and KPC tissue samples, and by testing combination therapy in human PDAC cell lines and orthotopic implantation mouse models of PDAC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research has shown that adherence to evidence-based asthma guidelines leads to improved outcomes, yet critical gaps remain in the implementation of these guidelines, particularly among minority and low-income youth. Schools represent a crucial point of intervention, as demonstrated by school-based asthma programs that have addressed individual components of the guidelines with promising results. This proposal aims to develop, implement, and evaluate a pragmatic, multi-component asthma program that builds upon existing targeted interventions to fully implement the asthma guidelines and integrate them in school practices to foster sustainability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Telomere proteins are not only essential for genome integrity and cell proliferation in a kinetoplastid parasite Trypanosoma brucei but also regulate antigenic variation, a key pathogenesis mechanism enabling T. brucei to establish a long-term infection. Importantly, T. brucei uses PolIE, a novel telomere protein and an A family DNA polymerase, to coordinate telomere G- and C-strand DNA syntheses, which is completely different from that in higher eukaryotes where OB fold-containing telomere ssDNA binding factors regulate the telomere end processing. In this project, we will investigate the mechanisms of T. brucei telomere end processing and its regulation, which will not only greatly improve our understanding about telomere protein evolution but also contribute to future development of anti-parasite agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patients with glioma often have seizures, a neurological condition that greatly reduces quality of life. A specific genetic mutation in the glioma cells, involving isocitrate dehydrogenase 1, predisposes patients to seizures. The work proposed here is aimed at understanding why this tumor mutation causes seizures, and how to better control these seizures in glioma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Pregnant women and children are exposed to a mixture of chemicals. We will investigate the impact of prenatal and postnatal exposures to chemical mixtures on child cognition, attention/executive function, externalizing and internalizing behaviors, and brain imaging. We will use two well-characterized birth cohort studies in the U.S. and Canada to identify the impact of a single chemical, interactions between chemicals, and joint effect of multiple chemicals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcriptional profiling of Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDA) patient specimens recently identified two main disease subtypes termed Classical and Basal, with the Basal subtype correlating with increased resistance to chemotherapy, a higher propensity to metastasize and shorter overall survival of patients. We recently identified a master regulator of the Basal subtype of PDA, the GLI2 transcription factor, that drives aggressive features of this disease. Our proposal will determine how GLI2 controls maintenance and induction of Basal identity in two important and clinically relevant contexts: resistance to KRAS* pathway suppression and during metastasis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Data derived from electronic health records (EHR) provide tremendous opportunities for clinical and translational research. A key challenge remains that the reproducibility of findings across studies is limited, which raised a fundamental concern on the value of these researching findings. The overarching goal of this proposal is to develop a rigorous bias correction tool through modern knowledge engineering and data-driven statistical modeling, for enhancing the reproducibility of EHR-based clinical findings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Children born several months before term are at increased risk of developing a devastating disease of the retina (retinopathy of prematurity, ROP) and of longterm adverse visual outcomes (AVO) including blindness. The central goal of our project is to design and plan for a large multi-center cohort study in which the relationship between sociodemographic, biological, and clinical risk factors, and ROP/AVO can be elucidated in detail. The specific aims of the project are (1) to finalize the member list for the study consortium, (2) to develop the study protocol and Manual of Procedures, and (3) to outline and perform preliminary and feasibility studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is progressive neurodegenerative disease with a complex etiology likely dominated by accumulation of environmental insults. There is increasing data that chronic, age-related inflammation plays an important role in AD progression. We propose to create a more physiologic mouse model to study AD and other neurodegenerative diseases by exposing AD mice to repeated infections to seed the brain with potentially pro- inflammatory tissue resident memory T cells that might alter AD progression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This project is focused on the identification of novel intracellular inputs to stress-activated signaling pathways. These inputs are critical to elicit the normal cellular responses to a wide variety of chemical and physical stress conditions, including heat shock, environmental toxins, and genotoxic stress. Such cellular responses help to maintain cellular integrity, metabolism, and genomic stability and are important in the treatment and prevention of cancer and other diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Allergic asthma is a chronic inflammatory disease of the lungs without cure. Repetitive allergen exposure in the airway leads to the generation of pathogenic immune memory and the excessive production of allergen specific IgE antibodies that mediate inflammation in the airway. In this proposal, we probe the development of memory B cells (MBCs) in allergic lungs and their systemic dissemination to understand the characteristics of pathogenic MBCs as well as test strategies to intercept the systemic dissemination of pathogenic MBCs to halt the progression of allergic inflammation.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This program trains exceptional predoctoral and postdoctoral students as researchers in the demography and economics of aging. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Basic scientists have many discoveries that could benefit the prevention and treatment of substance abuse, but they are generally not trained in how to commercialize their research. This training program will rely on years of experience to train basic scientists to think like entrepreneurs and award them with a Certificate of Entrepreneurship. All materials will be available to interested trainees and together we will work to improve the care of our patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative We propose to study risk factors for Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (AD/ADRD) in the Kenya Life Panel Survey (KLPS), a unique, richly phenotyped cohort of Kenyan adults who have been followed since childhood, and who were participants in a randomized child health intervention (school-based deworming). This project proposes an additional field interview, the KLPS Round 5 Aging Module (KLPS-5A) (when participants will be 35 to 43 years old) to collect detailed “midlife baseline” cognition and aging-related health data (including biomarkers), and information on AD/ADRD risk factors, where a novel aspect is the ability to link these midlife measures to rich existing longitudinal data from childhood and early adulthood, including on cognitive performance. Another notable feature is the ability to utilize experimental variation from the randomized child deworming program, which has been documented to meaningfully affect adult living standards as well as several risk factors for dementia, to better understand pathways over the life course and the scope for public health interventions to reduce AD/ADRD risk.
