IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Narrative: The proposed research aims to determine the treatment effects, utilization patterns, and potential barriers of transcatheter left atrial appendage occlusion devices and specific oral anticoagulants in persons living with dementia (PLWDs) and atrial fibrillation (AF), and how the net clinical benefits vary by dementia severity, frailty, fall risks, and advanced kidney disease. This study is relevant to public health because it will generate direct benefit-to-risk data to inform optimal stroke prevention strategies in PLWDs with AF. Our study will also produce a novel and generalizable prospective monitoring program for newly marketed medical devices and pharmacotherapies with detailed treatment effect heterogeneity evaluation needed for personalized prescribing decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance: Family caregivers of patients with Alzheimer’s disease (AD) frequently experience conflict with the health system when they act as patient advocates (e.g. negotiating treatments, tests, bills), which can cause increased stress, burden, and anxiety. We will tailor, optimize, then pilot test a negotiation and dispute resolutions (NDR) training program, commonly used in business schools, for family caregivers of patients with AD. Teaching NDR to family caregivers has the potential to improve caregiver wellbeing, burden, anxiety, and ultimately improve the care of the adult with AD.

IC_NAME: FOOD AND DRUG ADMINISTRATION
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Over the last several decades, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and pharmaceutical industry have partnered with the U.S. Congress to promote and advance improvements in the efficiency and rigor of drug development and regulatory review. Such collaborative efforts have been established in recurring five-year reauthorizations of the Prescription Drug User Fee Act (PDUFA) and Biosimilar User Fee Act III (BsUFA III). The Robert J. Margolis, MD, Center for Health Policy at Duke University proposes to support the FDA in achieving its PDUFA and BsUFA commitments through rigorous collaborative research and convening activities, building on Duke-Margolis and FDA’s fourteen-year track record of developing and delivering trusted, high-impact stakeholder engagement and research deliverables on priority regulatory and public health issues.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Cooperative Agreement to Support Regulatory Research Related to the 2022 Prescription Drug User Fee Act and Biosimilar User Fee Act (U19)

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Finding new and more efficient ways to build complex, bioactive, secondary metabolites (natural products) is important as it may lead to improvements in human health by identifying alternatives to existing medications to address, for example, pain and diseases associated with inflammation. Our goals are to develop new strategies and methods to efficiently construct complex secondary metabolites by functionalizing carbon-hydrogen, carbon-nitrogen and carbon-carbon bonds, which form the core of many organic compounds. Traditionally, these groups have been viewed as inert, especially when they comprise the skeletons of molecules. We will also use carvone, a readily available and sustainable agricultural byproduct, as well as piperidines and heteroaromatics, which are found in many pharmaceuticals and agrochemicals, as starting materials for many of our syntheses. Our efforts will accelerate advances into new chemical space to address human disease.

PROJECT_TITLE: Renewal: Strategies and Methods for Complex Molecule Synthesis
STUDY_SECTION_NAME: Maximizing Investigators’ Research Award B Study Section[MRAB]

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Due to the significant advances in modern cataract surgical technique over the last 30 years, the risk of cataract surgery is now considered low enough that some have questioned the need for anesthesiologists and nurse anesthetists in the operating room to provide continuous intraoperative monitoring and intravenous sedation (a.k.a., “monitored anesthesia care” or “MAC”). However, we do not know which patients would be harmed if anesthesia professionals were removed as a component of routine cataract surgery. This study will help identify high-risk patients who would still benefit from monitored anesthesia care during cataract surgery while creating new knowledge about how best to implement potential changes in the type of sedation offered to patients who are undergoing this procedure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Autism spectrum disorders is the most common, heritable, childhood-onset neuropsychiatric disorder. Understanding the genes and molecules critical for normal brain development will provide insight into the etiology of autism and related developmental brain disorders. These proposed studies will identify important genes for brain development and elucidate the functional and mechanistic role of specific genes in cortical development and physiology that can be targeted for the treatment of autism and other neurodevelopmental disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT In this renewal application, we will identify how specific combinations of variants in the genetic background confer risks for distinct developmental, cognitive, and behavioral phenotypes among individuals with the 16p12.1 deletion, ascertained from large families with developmental delay as well as cohorts for schizophrenia, autism, and unselected populations, and compare results with data from cohorts of other rare CNVs such as the 16p11.2 and 15q13.3 deletions. The interactive effects of the 16p12.1 deletion with the genetic background across diverse phenotypic ascertainments will be functionally validated within distinct neuronal subtypes using Drosophila melanogaster models and quantitative neurological assays using zebrafish models. This work will provide a fundamental understanding of the relative effects of common and rare variants towards the clinical outcome of complex disorders, and will develop a novel functional approach to accurately determine the effects of genetic interactions towards neuronal phenotypes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Individuals with age-related neurodegenerative disorders often experience declining neuromuscular function that may be linked to accelerated biological aging, but clearer knowledge of these degenerative processes is needed to guide the development of new, effective therapies. The predoctoral (F99) phase of this award will use robust mouse models to thoroughly investigate neuromuscular dysfunction when faced with genetic disease, aging, and injury, as well as use of gene therapy as a treatment strategy. The K00 portion of this award will investigate cellular reprogramming of the motor unit as a way to improve longevity and resilience when faced with genetic disease, aging, and injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Proper control of RNA stability is key for correct gene expression, and requires fine-tuning at every level of a given mRNA life. The proposed research aims at characterizing how post-transcriptional modifications, in particular m6A, may control RNA turnover in the context of cellular stress using viral-induced RNA-decay as a model.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer's disease is highly heritable, yet the genetic factors that contribute to its pathogenesis remain unclear; thus, identifying such risk factors is critical for understanding the disease pathology and developing potential therapeutics. While severe mutations in CAPICUA (CIC) cause intellectual disability, a less severe mutation is associated with Alzheimer's disease. This study aims to evaluate if the less severe mutation in CIC can potentiate Alzheimer's pathology, providing a framework for how partial impairment of a gene that causes intellectual disability can serve as a risk factor for Alzheimer's disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative  Patients and families with limited English proficiency experience substantial barriers to communication in the healthcare setting, leading to medical care that is less safe, less efficient, less effective, and inequitable. Professional interpreter use has repeatedly been shown to improve outcomes and reduce disparities, yet it remains widely underused. This study will test two discrete, scalable implementation strategies for improving professional interpreter use in primary care, while collecting detailed information about mechanisms of action and costs that will be applicable to many sites of care and contribute meaningfully to the goal of reducing communication-based disparities. .

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Most precision medicine initiatives have not yet reached the clinic and are still yet to deliver effective individualized treatments for common diseases. The outcomes of this project will allow us to better characterize heterogeneity in complex disorders by identifying cell type-speciﬁc transcriptional mechanisms underlying disease phenotypes, and developing accurate and robust disease-risk stratiﬁcation methods. These risk prediction methods will be portable to different population ancestries, and the approach will be initially applied to asthma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative  An expansion of a sequence of six DNA bases in the C9orf72 gene is the most common genetic cause for neurodegenerative diseases amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD), and the same mutation has been associated with other neurological diseases. Although these diseases are becoming an increasingly relevant public health challenge in our aging society, the mechanisms underlying most of these neurodegenerative conditions remain poorly understood. The biochemical, molecular, and genetic studies outlined in this proposal could lead to novel therapeutic interventions for these neurodegenerative diseases, for which effective treatments are still lacking.

ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: Chronic Kidney Disease is predominantly a result of initial injury to the glomerulus, the filtration system in the kidney. Dysregulated signaling between injured visceral and parietal epithelial cells is a major contributor to glomerular dysfunction and eventual kidney failure. In this research proposal, we aim to investigate the mechanisms mediating this cellular crosstalk in glomerular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Atypical femoral fractures (AFFs) are a rare but devastating side effect of long-term bisphosphonate (BP) treatment. The mechanisms driving BP associated AFFs remain elusive. The current collaborative grant seeks to investigate the contribution of bone matrix and bone remodeling to the development of AFFs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative This project explores the potential effect of ketamine, an N-methyl-D-aspartate glutamate receptor (NM DAR) antagonist, to enhance fear memory extinction and reconsolidation using an intensive 4-day exposure therapy. Together with traditional symptoms reduction approach we combine neuroimaging and psychophysiology biomarkers to further validate the intervention. The work will facilitate the development of shorter and more robust treatment for PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will measure levels of a brain nicotinic receptor in people exposed to trauma, half of them with PTSD. Relationships of these receptors with PTSD symptoms and fear learning will be investigated. The findings will advance the basic neuroscience understanding of factors contributing to distinct symptoms, informing future development and evaluation of pharmacotherapies for people with PTSD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE MicroRNAs (miRNAs) are small non-coding RNA molecules that function to suppress synthesis of a number of proteins in the cell. We have identified miRNA candidates (miR-138 and miR-181a/b-1) that regulate bone formation. These studies will determine the mechanism by which these miRNAs control bone production and address the therapeutic potential of modulating their activity in vivo to attempt to enhance bone fracture repair or inhibit abnormal bone formation (heterotopic ossification).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE  Clinical interventions such as supplemental oxygen and CPAP for babies born prematurely predispose to chronic lung diseases such as wheezing and asthma which remain major health problems throughout childhood and beyond. The primary goal of this proposal is to understand how the initial exposure to oxygen and CPAP affects structure and function of developing airways even after these interventions are stopped, with the focus on novel piezo channels that sense the mechanical stretch imposed by CPAP on the airway. We believe that piezo channels can then promote airway hypercontractility and excessive growth of airway cells, all resulting in a thicker, more reactive airway while the baby and the lungs are growing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent preclinical studies demonstrated that FLASH radiation therapy at ultrahigh dose rates can substantially reduce normal tissue toxicities while maintaining the same tumor response as seen following conventional radiation therapy. As an absolute prerequisite, ultrafast time-resolved FLASH dosimetry is extremely challenging and currently not feasible with commercially available dosimetry methods. The proposed first-of-its- kind ultrafast dosimetry system will provide clinics worldwide a unique, accurate, and robust solution to the research, implementation, and quality assurance of precision FLASH radiation therapy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT SUMMARY Alzheimer's disease (AD) affects half the US population over the age of 85 and despite decades of research, reliable treatments for AD have not been found. The overarching goal of our proposal is to generate multiscale genomics (gene expression and epigenome regulation) data at the single cell level and perform fine mapping to detect and validate causal variants, transcripts and regulatory sequences in AD. The proposed work will bridge the gap in understanding the link among the effects of risk variants on enhancer activity and transcript expression, thus illuminating AD molecular mechanisms and providing new targets for future therapeutic development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: CUNY GRADUATE SCH AND UNIV CTR
PHR: Project narrative This project will provide scientifically validated information on plants used for gynecological conditions by Caribbean women in New York City as well as other women globally who use these plants. Cross-cultural comparisons of women’s health practices within the larger Caribbean community in NYC will offer scientific feedback to these communities about their cultural healing traditions while contributing to the international dialogue on intercultural health. The results of this study will also be relayed to doctors and medical students to promote cultural competency through the Car-Lo E2 program at the New York Botanical Garden as well as a bilingal monograph that will be given back to the Caribbean community in NYC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Recent studies strongly suggest that molecules originating from symbiotic microbes can actively contribute to host immune development and regulation, nonetheless, the study of structures and functions of bioactive molecules is still lacking. Herein, we aim to understand how gut symbiont-derived lipids (BfaGCs) are recognized by the specific host protein CD1d. We will investigate how the CD1d-lipid complex can induce immunomodulatory functions of a specific subset of T cells (natural killer T cells) and can protect the host from excessive inflammation. This project will provide valuable knowledge on the host-microbiota interaction mechanism and will enable future development of immunotherapeutics from symbiotic microbiota-derived metabolites.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: Older sexual and gender minority (SGM) patients are at risk for receiving  inequitable end-of-life care; those with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are  at particularly high risk. Failure to collect and integrate sexual orientation and gender identity  (SOGI) data to identify patients’ informal support systems may have adverse health  consequences for SGM older adults, particularly for those dependent on informal caregivers to  provide in-home support and assist with activities of daily living. The goal of this K01 is develop  a novel training for hospice staff in person-centered communication that includes SOGI data  collection to promote authentic end-of-life care for SGM patients and their caregivers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cardiovascular diseases such as heart failure and arrhythmia are the leading cause of death in the U.S. While mathematical modeling has proven to be a useful tool in studying intracellular Ca2+ signaling in cardiomyocytes, current models fail to account for changes in Ca2+ release channel expression and subcellular remodeling that occur in heart failure. We propose development and experimental validation of new models of intracellular Ca2+ release that more accurately reflect Ca2+ signaling in failing ventricular cardiomyocytes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: Six million Americans suffer with atrial fibrillation (AF), a heart rhythm abnormality that is a major risk factor for stroke. Despite this, only 60% of eligible AF patients receive treatment, and this gap is even larger for African- Americans with their use ranging 10-22% less compared to Whites and Hispanics. Within the context of an ongoing collaboration between two large learning health systems, we propose to develop and test the impact of a storytelling intervention in African-Americans through a pilot and feasibility trial in African-Americans not on AC and measure recruitment and retention rates as well as fidelity of and satisfaction with our storytelling intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Physical function limitations among older cancer survivors is associated with multiple negative health outcomes, representing a critical problem in public health. This study will implement and assess the efficacy of the first online dietary and resistance training intervention to improve older cancer survivors’ physical function and improve associated health outcomes (muscle strength, dietary quality, health-related quality of life, self-efficacy, weight management). The expected outcomes of this study will inform the development of large-scale trials and have implications that can lead to efficacious behavioral interventions in health promotion for older cancer survivors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aging is associated with deficits in cognitive control, an executive function central to mental health. We propose new experiments to distinguish the psychological and neural processes underlying cognitive control dysfunction in older adults including those with mild cognitive impairment. The results will contribute to our understanding of the effects of aging on cognitive function and may help advance research of many age-related clinical conditions including Alzheimer’s disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Many individuals living in endemic areas are partially protected against malaria but the mechanisms underlying this lower susceptibility remain poorly understood, especially as they relate to Plasmodium vivax. We propose to use novel genomic approaches, including the characterization of parasite gene expression at a single cell level, to study how P. vivax parasites invade and grow within red blood cells in Cambodian patients. Our studies will generate novel insights on the parameters regulating P. vivax blood stage infections and provide immediately-relevant clinical information to better control this important human pathogen.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Adaptive neurotechnologies interact with the nervous system to provide new therapies for a wide variety of neurological disorders. The development of these technologies is complex, time-consuming, and costly. In this project, we propose to provide and to widely disseminate a software resource that greatly simpliﬁes the development process, and thereby accelerates the realization of new adaptive neurotechnologies that will improve diagnosis and treatment of many devastating neurological disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Narrative Dementia with Lewy bodies and Parkinson’s disease are characterized by the a-synuclein accumulation, but the downstream pathophysiological mechanisms are not known. Our data indicate that a-synuclein perturbs lysosomal degradation by blocking the transport of hydrolases to the lysosome. Here, we examine the mechanism of this process and develop novel methods to restore lysosomes in these disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative: A neurocomputational model of age-related differences in navigation Declines in spatial navigation often accompany advanced age and with a growing aging population, understanding the basis for age-related navigation differences is urgent. Therefore, developing experimental paradigms and models that can account for age- related differences in navigation is important to predicting who may be at risk for getting lost or having trouble finding their medicine, either as part of healthy or pathological aging. More generally, a deeper understanding of age-related declines in navigation is necessary to developing effective therapies that can help individuals with way-finding difficulties.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR DENTAL, ORAL, AND CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative Enormous and unacceptable oral health disparities exist across vulnerable and underserved populations, cleft lip and palate remains a common birth defect, oropharyngeal cancer is rising in young adults –related to HPV, and we’ve yet to harness the true diagnostic value of salivary biomarkers or leverage the tremendous genomic medicine advances for oral health improvement. Dental caries remains one of the most common diseases of childhood, periodontal disease prevalence estimates have recently been revised upwards to nearly half the adult populations after a more thorough full-mouth exam methodology; and oral health consequences of the use of e-cigarettes remain largely unknown. The biologic impact of SARS- CoV2 on the craniofacial complex is a new critical area of exploration from potential sites of infection, transmission, and for reservoirs as well as the long-term impact on oral health from post-acute sequelae SARS-CoV-2 infection (PASC) or long-COVID and we must have a well- trained, diverse dental, oral, and craniofacial health research workforce to address these challenges, to serve as the catalyst to develop appropriate strategies and further the translation of dental, oral, and craniofacial research.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatment with dolutegravir from conception has been associated with increased risk for neural tube defects, which has created uncertainty over the use of dolutegravir in the treatment of women of reproductive age living with HIV. Dolutegravir has also been associated with excess weight gain, a known risk factor for neural tube defects, suggesting that dolutegravir-associated metabolic alterations could contribute to the increased risk for neural tube defects. We will study the association of dolutegravir use in pregnancy with maternal and fetal metabolic alterations and the contribution to fetal defects, using murine in vivo and embryo culture models, and clinical samples from a pregnancy study in Botswana.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autoimmune diseases, which constitute a broad range of chronic illnesses, cause significant morbidity and mortality in the US and worldwide. Here we seek to understand how inhibitory pathways restrain enhanced TCR signaling strength to achieve peripheral tolerance and prevent autoimmunity. New mechanistic insights into peripheral tolerance regulation hold promise for improving or identifying new therapeutic strategies to treat spontaneous autoimmune diseases or to prevent autoimmunity resulting from cancer immunotherapy with checkpoint inhibitors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Opioid drug abuse is associated with worsening of neurocognitive deficits and other neurodegenerative effects seen with HIV infection. This grant proposes to use two in vivo models to examine the complex interplay of opiate-HIV-antiretroviral drug exposure on the central accumulation of drugs (antiretrovirals and morphine), blood-brain barrier function, and neuroimmune function in these mice. Gaining a better understanding of this dynamic interplay, with specific focus on antiretroviral brain concentrations, will improve the current therapeutic approaches for the opiate-using HIV population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: The thesis and F99 phase of this proposal investigates a nanomedicine-based approach to drive the peripheral nerve regeneration and functional recovery, while also working to limit neuromuscular degeneration resulting from the loss of nerve function by creating new neurons within the muscle to promote and preserve healthier state. The applications of genetic and cell-based therapies extend well beyond the study of nerve regeneration and will be applied to neurodevelopmental disorders in the K00 period. Completion of the F99 phase will provide professional, intellectual, and technical training in preparation for the transition to the postdoctoral phase (K00) of the award.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it investigates how a class of cell type known as cellular senescence drives age-dependent intervertebral disc degeneration that results in low back pain. The proposed studies aim to elucidate the molecular and cellular mechanisms through which cellular senescence promotes disc aging and identify therapeutic drug interventions to mitigate age-dependent intervertebral disc degeneration at the systemic and local disc tissue level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE: Training the next generation of academicians in gastroenterological sciences continues to be the primary goal of the UCLA NIH T32 GI training program which has a long, productive history over the last 48 years. Through state-of-the art, multidisciplinary scientific approaches provided by a diverse faculty of 34 dedicated, experienced, and successful mentors and a highly supportive administrative platform, we strive to continue our recruitment, research mentoring, and nurturing of outstanding trainees including women and under-represented minorities from adult and pediatric GI fellowships, the UCLA STAR program, the UCLA General Surgery residency, and other UCLA post-doctoral programs. The breadth of training is from basic science and translational research to clinical and health services research with an emphasis on didactic training through UCLA graduate school programs and with major institutional resources to sustain the excellence and productivity of this important training program.
PROJECT_TERMS: Gastroenterology
PROJECT_TITLE: Gastroenterology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pancreatic beta and alpha cells couple nutrients with insulin and glucagon secretion and abnormalities in nutrient signaling can lead to defects in insulin and glucagon secretion in the pathogenesis of diabetes. The signaling mechanism that regulates the tight link nutrient sensing and the insulin and glucagon secretion characteristics of beta and alpha cells are not completely understood. In this study, we aim to characterize how amino acid sensing mechanisms regulate the function and mass of beta and alpha cells during normal conditions and diabetes development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will identify molecular mechanisms regulating the development and maturation of astrocytes, one of two classes of non-neuronal cells in the brain that play essential roles in health and disease. Despite recognition of the critical and diverse roles astrocytes play in brain function, the mechanisms and principles governing their identity and function remain poorly understood. Gaining insight into the molecular signaling programs regulating astrocyte identity and function will facilitate the development of novel therapies targeting these cells for restoration or repair in the injured or diseased brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Title: Ion Channel Function and Regulation of the Polycystin-1/2 complex in Kidney Physiology and Polycystic Kidney Disease Project Narrative: Despite the clear linkage between polycystin-1/polycystin-2 (polycystin-1/2) ion channel protein complex and polycystic kidney disease (PKD), the function and regulation of this complex and the role of its ion channel activity in kidney cyst formation is largely unknown. This multi-PI project will provide critical insights into the fundamental molecular mechanism of the polycystin-1/2 channel function and regulation, and discover its requirement in ensuring normal kidney development and preventing cyst formation. It is expected that the proposed studies will lead to a better understanding of PKD pathogenesis and help form the basis for targeting the polycystin-1/2 channel for preventive and therapeutic purposes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative. Alzheimer's Disease (AD) and AD-related dementias (ADRDs) are crippling neurodegenerative disorders whose onset strongly correlates with aging. There are compelling reasons to believe cellular senescence (effectively, cell aging) and retrotransposons (selfish DNA) may drive or exacerbate AD and ADRDs by inducing a state of chronic stress (inflammation); more research is needed. We will analyze the role of LINE-1 retrotransposons in senescent cells and Alzheimer's / ADRD afflicted brain tissues, gathering additional evidence to support or refute the hypothesis that LINE-1 is a causal agent in Alzheimer's / ADRD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: We will develop a novel clinical informatics approach to assist clinicians as they diagnose and treat a number of brain diseases. Our aim is to model, analyze, and quantify brain blood vessels to improve accuracy and sensitivity during detection of cerebrovascular diseases (CVDs), such as intracranial aneurysms, intracranial vascular stenosis, vasculitis, and vasospasm. As CVDs affect a large population each year and cause high rates of morbidity and mortality, the proposed project will lead to a computer-aided detection tool for clinicians to use as they interpret cerebral angiography to benefit patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Epilepsy is the fourth most common neurological disorder in the U.S. and affects over 50 million people worldwide. This project addresses the critical need for a point-of-care test to diagnose Neurocysticercosis in patients with epileptic seizures, as this parasitic infection is responsible for about one third of all epilepsy and is the major cause of adult epilepsy worldwide. In Phase II we will refine this assay into a manufactured product, carry out a validation study to support a de novo submission to FDA, and prepare for scale up and commercial launch of the assay.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The proposed research is directly relevant to public health and aligned with the NIA’s mission because it addresses molecular patho-mechanisms underlying endo-lysosome dysfunction in Alzheimer’s disease and the contribution of this dysfunction to the development of amyloid plaque pathology. Based on our novel mechanistic hypotheses, which are directly relevant to development of therapeutic strategies, our proposed work utilizes a range of current techniques (including use of an iPSC model and proteomics on isolated axons) to determine the molecular mechanism by which the adaptor protein complex, AP-4, regulates axonal autophagic, lysosomal transport and maturation, and protects neurons from amyloidogenic pathways. Outcomes from our proposal are expected to fully serve the NIA’s mission by aiding in development of therapeutic strategies for Alzheimer’s disease and by providing novel mechanistic insight into other age-related neurodegenerative diseases known to have a lysosomal component to their pathology.

PHR: Project Narrative  The proposed research will significantly advance public health by advancing technical approaches that will greatly expand access to the repertoire of biologically active natural products (NPs) produced by fungi. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This study will evaluate the effects of a parenting intervention for Hispanic sexual minority youth in preventing/reducing drug use and depressive symptoms. It will also examine whether the intervention improves parent social support for the adolescent, parent acceptance, family functioning, and whether it reduces general stress and stress associated with being a Hispanic sexual minority. The knowledge expected to be gained from this study has the potential to transform the type of prevention programs that are disseminated to communities to improve the health of Hispanic sexual minority youth.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Filoviruses are among the deadliest pathogens known to humans. The Ebola virus disease outbreak in West Africa (2014-2016), caused by the Zaire Ebola virus, resulted in over 28,000 cases and 11,000 deaths. In addition to Ebola virus, a related filovirus called Marburg has caused five outbreaks in the past 10 years with high fatality rates. This proposal is aimed at developing effective immunoprophylactic against Marburg virus for protection of first responders during outbreaks of Marburg virus disease. We have generated several antibody drug candidates that protect against Marburg infection. Under this proposal we will engineer the lead antibody to acquire long term durability after injection and we will perform animal efficacy studies. This study, if successful, will set the stage for clinical development of an effective therapeutic for human use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it contributes to a program of research focused on significantly improving the communication abilities of children with language impairments, including children with fragile X syndrome and children with developmental language disorder (DLD). The proposed study will track language production and comprehension over time in school age children, considering the unique impact of one aspect of cognition (executive function). Given the prevalence of DLD (7-13% of school age children), and the significant overlap in the language phenotype between fragile X and DLD, this project addresses the NIDCD's mission to improve the lives of individuals with communication disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: TRIM-NHL proteins control gene expression, development, and stem cell fate, and their dysfunction causes neurodevelopmental diseases, infertility, and cancer. We study Drosophila Brain tumor (Brat) as a model, and seek to identify its regulatory mechanisms, network of target genes, and functions in development of the brain and germline. The results will improve the understanding of TRIM-NHL biological functions and disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This project seeks to understand the pathways and mechanisms of DNA repair and mutagenesis in mycobacteria. These studies will both elucidate basic mechanisms of DNA repair in bacteria, but also inform our understanding of how mycobacterial pathogens, including M. tuberculosis, the causative agent of the disease tuberculosis, evolve antibiotic resistance. The long term goal of these studies is, through basic understanding of mycobacterial DNA repair pathways, to validate DNA repair as a therapeutic target for mycobacterial infections, thereby advancing efforts to control tuberculosis and other mycobacterial infections.

PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section  Acute kidney injury is a common illness among hospitalized patients throughout the world. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Aging and rejuvenation: An ant model to study the regulation of longevity Project narrative:  Ant colonies consist of nearly genetically identical individuals that exhibit different morphology, play distinct behavioral roles in the colony, and vary dramatically in their lifespan. In the absence of the queen, the non-reproductive workers of the ant Harpegnathos can transition into reproductive pseudo-queens (gamergates), accompanied by a five-fold extension of their lifespan and this can be fully reversed if gamergates are induced to transition back to the worker status. The extreme alteration in the degree of aging that accompanies the caste switch, combined with the experimental amenability of Harpegnathos, makes it an ideal system to characterize the molecular dynamics of aging, rejuvenation, and reproduction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Treatments for autoimmune diseases such as multiple sclerosis (MS) are not selective enough to target the specific T cells responsible for driving inflammation, neurologic injury, and associated disability. We will optimize a newly developed, unique chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell technology to exclusively eliminate autoreactive lymphocytes in an animal model of MS. Further, we will undertake in vivo experiments to develop CAR T cells for pre-clinical translation to humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The chemistry we are proposing will allow improved access to molecules of importance in biomedical research in both academia and industry. The ligands, catalysts, techniques, and strategies that we have developed for carbon-heteroatom and carbon-carbon bond formation are regularly used by those in discovery and process groups in the pharmaceutical industry for the preparation of new biologically relevant compounds and are also widely used in academia. The methods we are devising enable chemists to rapidly and reliably prepare molecular analogs that manifest increased potency and reduced side effects as compared to the initial lead compounds, allows for faster, more economical, and efficient drug discovery and development, thus leading to an improvement in human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Anxiety disorders are among the most prevalent childhood psychiatric disorders yet the mechanisms underlying the development of anxiety remain elusive. This proposal examines the neurodevelopmental origins of behavioral inhibition, a risk factor that increases the odds of developing an anxiety disorder by four-fold. By identifying changes in brain connectivity that are linked to behavioral inhibition and the moderating contribution of inhibitory control, this research will generate knowledge that can be used to identify developmentally-sensitive targets for intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE This project will investigate the role of cardiac neural crest cells in the mammalian heart development using mouse models and genomic technologies. We will also understand the mechanism by which these cells make cell fate choices as they form the cardiac outflow tract, aortic arch and adjoining arterial branches. The genes that we will investigate are associated with human congenital heart disease, so that we hope, in the future, to translate discoveries in mouse models to human patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The project will develop and sustain an integrated knowledge base of key research resources, including antibodies, cell lines, organisms and digital assets, indexed by the Research Resource Identifiers (RRID), persistent identifiers currently used by authors to uniquely identify which research resources are used within their studies. Our proven dissemination approaches will encourage biomedical scientists worldwide to use identifiable and validated research resources in their research, leading to measurable improvement and progress toward more rigorous and reproducible biomedical research, one of the major challenges of today’s biomedical science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unplanned ICU admissions from the acute care floor are common and associated with appreciable morbidity and mortality; despite these impacts, little is known about mechanisms underlying these admissions. The proposed research will address this knowledge gap by identifying factors and mechanisms contributing to unplanned ICU admissions and then connecting these factors and mechanisms to key patient- and family- centered outcomes. We will use this fundamental knowledge about unplanned ICU admissions to develop interventions to improve care for seriously ill patients and their family members.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement Structural racism and discrimination negatively shape the health of older sexual and racial minority men, including those living with HIV. The manner in which structural racism and discrimination affect the various subgroups within this population (along race, ethnicity and HIV status), is expected to vary, yet it is poorly understood. This proposal is in response to NIH’s funding opportunity “Understanding and Addressing the Impact of Structural Racism and Discrimination on Minority Health and Health Disparities” and attends to the Office of AIDS Research Strategic Plan of addressing HIV comorbidities, complications, and health disparities. The purpose of this study is to assess the relationships among health, structural racism and discrimination, stigma, resources, and biomarkers of health and aging in older men of four ethno-racial groups: African American, Latinx, Asian American, and white— and across HIV status. The findings of this study may help understand how structural, individual, and biological factors differently affect the health of older men and the ways in which prevention efforts may be improved.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antigen-specific CD8 T cells are key players in adaptive immunity and have transformative applications as cell therapies. Yet isolating these cells is challenging because of their receptor diversity and rarity. We propose to develop DNA-gated cytometry for multiplexed sorting of Ag-specific CD8 T cells to overcome current challenges.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research will offer insights into the key fundamental processes that enable cells to repair and tolerate damage to their genetic material in response to environmental mutagens. These processes are responsible for the mutations that lead to cancer and a variety of human genetic diseases. The proposed research should also lead to the development of new classes of drugs to inhibit these processes that could have significant therapeutic applications.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Narrative The project aims to develop specialized HIV-1 genomics laboratory training modules at BHP to build capacity for laboratory professionals and university students on HIV-1 genomics, and HIV-1 cure-related research in Botswana and the region. The proposed project will increase the human capacity for conducting advanced HIV-1 genomics research and establishing local capacity for HIV-1 Reservoirs studies to contribute toward HIV cure-related research in southern Africa. Successful implementation of this project will also result in the establishment of a core facility and center of excellence for pathogen genomics, and support future NIH- funded HIV-1 cure projects. 1

PHR: Project Narrative: The experiments described in this proposal are designed to increase our understanding of the mechanisms and regulation of essential mRNA processing reactions, and how they are coupled to and affect other nuclear processes such as transcription. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: The HIV Center will advance the goals of the US National HIV/AIDS Strategy, the NIH, and UNAIDS to End the HIV/AIDS Epidemic (EHE), by stimulating and supporting research that targets the US and global communities most affected by racial, social, and health disparities; mental health challenges; and health inequities. We will build and expand on our history of interdisciplinary HIV research – leveraging emerging knowledge bases and new and continuing community, scientific, and health department partnerships --to promote research focusing on individual, social, and systemic barriers to actualizing the power of biomedical advances in HIV prevention and care for the most vulnerable. We will identify and rapidly respond to new trends in viral epidemics supporting research-practice partnerships that foster innovation, train the next generation of scientific leaders, including those from under-represented groups, increase understanding of drivers of the epidemic, and foster translation of clinical and research findings to prevention and care settings for maximum equitable public health impact.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: Project Narrative This study is relevant to public health because it represents a novel strategy for identifying, based on prior risk exposure patterns, those who benefit from family interventions and those who may need additional or alternative intervention. Once these families are identified, interventions can be tailored to produce maximum benefit for families experiencing various combinations of risk factors. The project aligns with Goal 3 of NIMH’s Strategic Plan to advance the prevention of mental illness by improving methods to match interventions to individuals and populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Neurodegenerative diseases including Alzheimer’s disease and Progressive Supranuclear Palsy are characterized by abnormal tau protein accumulation and do not currently have disease modifying treatments. Analyzing whole genome sequencing with novel genomic and genome informatic methods may identify rare genetic risk factors that lead to these diseases. The shared or unique rare genetic risk factors of Alzheimer’s disease and Progressive Supranuclear Palsy may become future therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: SANFORD BURNHAM PREBYS MEDICAL DISCOVERY INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal will transform the study of brain science and its diseases, particularly Alzheimer’s disease and its related dementias, through the study of a new, fundamental phenomenon: somatic gene recombination (SGR). SGR generates myriad, previously unassessed genomic cDNAs (gencDNAs) that have functional implications for biology and diseases of the brain. The proposed studies have the potential to link AD and ADRDs mechanistically, as well as identify novel biomarkers and near-term therapeutics, based on the identified enzymology required for SGR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Aging of the reproductive tissues increases susceptibility to numerous age-related comorbidities and mortality and thus has relevance well beyond implications for procreation. While numerous advances have been made in studying organismal aging, the area of reproductive aging has not received adequate attention for education, research and discovery, especially at an institutional level. This application proposes to create an educational, research and mentoring program focused on reproductive aging to establish it as an institutional goal at the University of Pittsburgh and beyond.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The proposal entitled “Impact of prenatal inflammation on developing human brain” will study the consequences of (co-) exposure to maternal inflammation due to bacterial or viral infections toxins on developing human neuroimmune system using human iPSC-derived cerebral organoids co-cultured with microglial cells. Studies using iPSCs have been limited in sample size and lacked diversity, often derived from a single race/ethnical group. Here, we will collect samples from a diverse ethnical and racial group of healthy individuals, representative of the proportions found in the U.S. population, that will help us better understand the health disparities and interventions both in populations and in specific subgroups, identifying new therapeutic targets leading to more efficient therapies from which the majority of the population in the US could benefit from.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Alzheimer disease (AD) and related disorders (ADRD) are the most common causes of cognitive impairment in older individuals, with no effective long-term treatment or prevention. Examining genetic and biomarker profiles of older, cognitively unimpaired individuals will provide insight into AD/ADRD protective biological mechanisms. This will be done leveraging and building on our unique family-based longitudinal cohort of mid- Western Amish individuals.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Diffuse midline gliomas with the H3K27M mutation, which includes the previously named Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG), are the most aggressive primary malignant brain tumors in children with the median survival of this group about one year after diagnosis with no effective therapies available. Recent studies have identified somatic mutation of the H3F3A gene that encodes the histone H3 variant, H3.3, which results in lysine 27 to methionine change (K27M) in the encoded protein H3.3 in most DIPG tumors. The planned studies will not only make basic scientific discoveries aimed at understanding the molecular basis of tumorigenesis, but also lay the foundation for molecularly targeted therapies for this deadly disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Youth from low socioeconomic groups are at a systematic disadvantage in the provision of diabetes care, particularly diabetes technology which is associated with improvement in diabetes-specific outcomes. Thus, we urgently need studies to understand and ameliorate the persistent worsening of disparities of diabetes management and outcomes in youth from low socioeconomic backgrounds. This proposed research will (1) improve representation of diverse youth in the literature, (2) address the gap in knowledge of barriers and promoters in publicly insured youth, and (3) identify and address factors of worsening disparity in diabetes technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative / Public Health Relevance Triple negative breast cancer (TNBC) is a highly lethal form of breast cancer, that disparately affects African American (AA) compared with Caucasian American (CA) women with more than 2-fold increase in death rate in AA, even after adjusting for socioeconomic position, age at diagnosis, and treatment modalities. Recently, we discovered that this disparity may be the result of increased oncogenic activity of the YB1 gene signaling and its associated signaling pathways, which contribute to therapy resistance and the aggressiveness of TNBC tumors in AA women. Our innovative proposal has the potential to lead to new YB1-targeted treatment options, predict those patients who would benefit from these targeted approaches, and provide a biomarker for progression and therapy resistance of TNBC in AA women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: NARRATIVE:  The proposed project is relevant to public health because it will establish brain-computer interface (BCI) access to an existing line of augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) systems providing a voice to those who otherwise are isolated from their family members and society. The combined AAC-BCI system will provide precise language production supported by a broad network of clinical support personnel for those who cannot communicate through physical movements. This will fulfill the mission of the NIH to reduce disability and enhance health by improving the quality-of-life for those with the most extreme physical impairments by creating an AAC-BCI device designed for compatibility with established communication, product delivery, and funding mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative This study will contribute to the understanding of the causes of the most common form of neurodegeneration: Alzheimer’s disease. If the hypothesis of this project is true, somatic mitochondrial mutations will be supported as a link between aging, neurodegeneration and mitochondrial dysfunction and that will contribute to elucidate how external factors contribute to Alzheimer’s disease and how to prevent it. Understanding the contribution of mitochondrial mutation to Alzheimer’s disease can be applied to develop preventive strategies that enhance mitochondrial function, promote successful aging, and improve early detection and quality of life of Alzheimer’s disease patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mounting evidence suggests that age-related hearing loss (presbycusis) is linked to cognitive decline and de- mentia risk in older adults, yet the underlying mechanisms are unknown. By identifying specific shared genetic and environmental influences on age-related changes in hearing abilities, cognition, and putative blood bi- omarkers for dementia, our study will reveal novel biological candidates for the determinants of aging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) are leading causes of disability and often result in communication deficits that can complicate ADRD caregiving and clinical care. The study team will work with stakeholders to develop and design a personalizable Assistive and Alternative Communication (AAC) device that relies on information technology (IT) and touchscreens to promote communication and personhood for persons with dementia. This study will integrate the AAC into an existing health IT intervention that already facilitates clinical communication between caregivers and healthcare providers and will evaluate use of the modified IT among triads of dementia caregivers, persons with dementia, and healthcare providers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Faithful segregation of chromosomes underlies genome integrity in all organisms. This proposed research aims to identify the mechanisms by which broadly conserved structural maintenance of chromosomes (SMC) complexes organize and compact replicated chromosomes in the cell. Our studies have the potential to uncover the general principles of chromosome packaging and segregation relevant to all domains of life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: PALO ALTO VETERANS INSTIT FOR RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Antimicrobial resistance (AMR) is an increasingly prevalent and serious problem worldwide. A more detailed understanding of how AMR develops and spreads within the human gut microbiota in response to antibiotic exposure would enhance strategies for antibiotic stewardship. We will characterize the evolution and dissemination of antimicrobial resistance genes in the human gut microbiota before, during and after antibiotic exposure in vivo, as well as in complex microbial communities derived from stool samples of the same individuals in vitro, with the goal of identifying factors and conditions that will reduce the spread of AMR, leading to optimized antibiotic use and preservation of efficacy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project examines for the first time whether traditional Samoan age beliefs and a newly-identified CREBRF gene variant predict greater cognitive resilience including lower risk of dementia. To accomplish this, we will interview older Samoans because there is evidence that they tend to have a high level of cognitive resilience, traditional age beliefs are still prevalent among them, and close to half have the CREBRF gene variant, whereas less than 1% of non-Samoans have it. Our research is relevant to the National Institute on Aging’s mission of improving the cognitive health of older persons by examining novel determinants of cognitive resilience in diverse cohorts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Fear-related disorders such as Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) are often characterized by an inability to inhibit and extinguish fear memories leading to pathological expression of fear-related behaviors. For progress to occur with targeted rationally-designed therapeutic approaches, a greater understanding of the neural circuitry mediating fear inhibition and extinction is needed. This proposal uses cell-type specific modulation of cells within the amygdala to advance our understanding of circuitry underlying fear behaviors and will provide unique avenues for therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The pathological hallmark of Lewy body diseases is the presence of Lewy bodies (LBs), which are composed of abnormal aggregates of the alpha-synuclein (α-syn) protein. We propose to investigate whether natural killer (NK) cells have the capacity to protect neurons by clearing α-syn aggregates and modulating inflammation. The completion of our study will yield ample novel data to interrogate NK cell function in age-related neurodegenerative diseases and provide a rationale for potential immune cell target strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Up to 1 in 5 US children experiences a communication disorder before age 6, causing long-term social, emotional, behavioral, academic, physical health, and mental health risks. Early Intervention improves outcomes; however, children from racial, ethnic, and/or linguistic minority populations, including those living in rural areas and/or poverty, have less access to timely, accurate identification and high-quality communication disorder treatment. Using stakeholder engagement methods and data from over 100,000 children in five states, we will identify key sources of structural racism and discrimination for children with communication disorders in the Early Intervention system and use findings to develop actionable practice and policy recommendations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) is a highly effective user-controlled HIV prevention strategy, with tremendous potential for high impact to reduce incident HIV infections among at-risk African women if delivered with high coverage and taken with sufficient adherence. In this highly innovative study, we propose to catalyze integration of optimized universal screening and counseling for HIV risk behaviors and PrEP provision for at-risk women accessing public health family planning clinics in Kisumu, Kenya – a region with an HIV prevalence of up to 28% among young women– using step-wedged randomized design. We hypothesize that family planning clinics will offer a cost- and time-efficient, less stigmatizing, and sustainable woman-centered ‘one-stop’ access point for PrEP and FP services, with culminating in great reach and impact for PrEP of reducing incident HIV infection in this setting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative Precision mental health offers a way to optimize therapeutic benefit of existing treatments by using individual difference characteristics to select the treatment predicted to work best for a given patient. Existing precision mental health research has been unable to capture the complexity of clinical phenomena like treatment response and produces models that do not generalize well to new data; however, contemporary machine learning approaches are well-suited to overcome these limitations. The project at the center of this training grant will apply machine learning to build a precision mental health model from clinical and genetic individual differences that guides treatment selection for cigarette smoking cessation, reducing the personal and public health burden of cigarette smoking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF SOUTH CAROLINA AT COLUMBIA
PHR: The escalating number of older adults suffering from Alzheimer's disease and related dementias (ADRD) has existed as an urgent public health crisis worldwide. This project applies novel methodology to determine if day- to-day variability and volume of lower-intensity lifestyle activities are joint intervention targets to sustain cognitive function in vulnerable older adults. Verifying these putative lifestyle behavioral targets is essential to establish evidence-based foundations for developing achievable, sustainable, and ecologically-valid strategies to sustain optimal cognition and reduce ADRD risks in late life.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Nutrition, hormones and other environmental factors act during development to affect individual susceptibility to obesity throughout life. As the master regulator of energy balance, the hypothalamus plays a central role in such ‘programming’ of obesity; maternal nutrition impacts energy balance in the offspring, effects that persist throughout life. In this project we propose to carry out a brain-wide analysis of how maternal exposure to high fat diet during lactation impacts the organization and function of neural circuits that are known to regulate energy balance, with direct implications for environmental modification of body weight and metabolic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE Sleep-wake disturbances are associated with important adverse outcomes in older persons, including cognitive and functional decline. These disturbances are under-diagnosed in older persons due to the poor sensitivity of existing sleep questionnaires, the frequent co-occurrence of multiple disturbances, and the burdensome nature of objective sleep testing. We propose to develop and test age-appropriate, comprehensive subjective and objective sleep assessment tools to facilitate identification of older persons with sleep-wake disturbances.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative South Africa estimates 80% of their population has TB infection, and 14% of the population lives with HIV, with an estimated 5-15% of South Africans at high risk of developing TB disease from recent infection or immunocompromised status. Therefore, utilization of routinely collected data to optimize the comprehensive TB care cascade – screening, evaluation, diagnosing, linkage to care, treatment, and TB-free survival – is important to assess at the clinic level to improve clinic flow and patient outcomes. The proposed study will leverage an evidence-based implementation science strategy, the Systems Analysis and Improvement Approach (SAIA), and recent TB cascade analyses piloted in the proposed site, to adapt and evaluate the effectiveness of SAIA-TB using a stepped wedge crossover cluster randomized trial across 12 clinics in rural Eastern Cape, South Africa.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The burden of cancer among children disproportionally affects low- and middle-income countries, which accounts for over 80% of global childhood cancer cases and deaths. One of the main reasons impacting these poor outcomes is the lack of a strong health system, which impacts timely access to care along the care continuum, including timely diagnoses, referrals, and reaching care. The purpose of this project is to identify barriers and facilitators to access to cancer care for children in Tanzania and design a tailored intervention through implementation science methods.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TX MD ANDERSON CAN CTR
PHR: Narrative The goal of this proposal is to develop statistical methods to compare different treatment options for patients with chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), to decide whether or not to receive a stem cell transplant, and if yes, what is the best time to receive it. Many different chronic diseases like CML have multiple treatment options, with some of them being aggressive and others mild. Our methods and software are widely applicable to them for conducting individual risk predictions, as well as optimizing treatment decisions for these patients to maximally prolong their survival, which will be validated through our proposed application to a study for chronic kidney disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative Both guarding and micturition reflexes require coordination of the bladder (BL) and external urethral sphincter (EUS) muscles, which is mediated by neural circuits in the brain and spinal cord. After complete spinal cord injury (SCI) voluntary control over micturition is eliminated. Recovery is possible if L4/L3 segments are not damaged, but suppression of the EUS guarding reflex is incomplete leading to detrusor-sphincter-dyssynergy (DSD) and inefficient voiding after SCI. Various therapeutic approaches have been employed to reduce DSD, but currently available treatments do not give fully satisfactory results and may be accompanied by side effects. Furthermore, sexual dimorphism in anatomy and function of the lower urinary tract (LUT) suggests differences in the spinal neural circuits of male and female which in turn may require different approaches to DSD treatment in males and females. Therefore, development of targeted DSD treatment requires better understanding of neural control and intimate mechanisms of intraspinal regulation of EUS and BL activity, which will help to design future therapeutic methods. This project is aiming to fill the gap in knowledge about the spinal circuit responsible for EUS relaxation during voiding and about the post-SCI involvement of a recently discovered LUT- related propriospinal circuit. New knowledge about sex-related differences in structure and function of these circuits in spinal intact (SI) and SCI animals will reveal critical points in gender- oriented therapies to cure LUT dysfunctions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE As people age they lose the ability to heal from injuries or diseases like osteoarthritis, partially due to a reduced ability of old stem cells to differentiate and an inhospitable tissue environment that no longer supports repair. To address this, we propose to 1) activate SIRT6, a sirtuin that can epigenetically reverse age-associated changes in stem cells and 2) inhibit apoptosis signal regulating kinase 1 (ASK1), a protein associated with cell death and inflammation, in the tissue environment. We will test the ability of this novel dual strategy to enhance stem cell differentiation and promote a more regenerative tissue environment in articular cartilage defect models of aged animals.

PHR: Project Narrative We seek to understand the mechanisms underlying timing of developmental events in the cerebral cortex. Our approach leverages unbiased single cell sequencing resources and innovative technologies for studying developmental lineage relationships to study the timing and mechanisms underlying the onset of astrogliogenesis in the cerebral cortex. If successfully, this project will provide understanding of when and where distinct subtypes of human astrocyte emerge, establishing a framework and identify experimental model system for studying the developmental mechanisms underlying astrocyte subtype specification from cortical progenitor cells.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Chronic constipation affects 10-20% of the population and leads to 2 million gastroenterology referrals each year in the US. We will apply behavioral economics, user-centered design, and implementation science to develop a novel clinical care pathway to rapidly triage patients to effective and targeted therapy for constipation using a recently validated point-of-care diagnostic device. This work will allow more patients to receive efficient and appropriate care and will help patients avoid unnecessary tests and repeated trials of ineffective and costly laxatives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Identifying the genetic basis of complex traits that affect survival and reproduction in natural populations can have important implications for human health since most diseases are genetically complex. Pinpointing individual genes responsible for variation in complex phenotypes and linking that variation to fitness in natural populations is more easily accomplished in short lived, sessile organisms than in human populations. We propose to use manipulative genetic and ecological field studies to causally link genes to variation in complex traits and fitness in natural populations of yellow Monkeyflowers, an emerging ecological genomic system. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: The transcription factor FoxP3 plays a key role in the differentiation and activity of T regulatory cells, which protect against autoimmune disease and immunopathology. Our recent analysis of FOXP3-deficient IPEX patients and mice brought novel insight on the mechanisms of this disease, and on molecular aspects of FOXP3 function. We will build on this foundation and dissect the molecular and functional defects of FOXP3 revealed by these mutations, furthering our understanding of IPEX disease and its determining factors, and providing molecular details on this mysterious but essential transcription factor.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to dynamically advance understanding of American Indian (AI) culture as protective against substance use, inform future substance use interventions, lend to efforts to promote insurance coverage for traditional healing, and guide theoretical frameworks of AI health. This work will be guided by Community-based Participatory Research to 1) codify community conceptualization of one AI ceremony and its protective functions relevant to substance use; 2a) determine how cultural engagement through this ceremony confers protection against substance use; 2b) develop a menu of strategies to support community implementation of one AI ceremony; and 3) examine the neurocognitive correlates of the ceremony and associated stimuli relevant to substance use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The premise of this project is that acyclic CB[n] – with their high binding affinity, straightforward synthesis, and outstanding biocompatibility – are ideally suited for development as in vivo sequestration agents for toxic substances from the gut and the bloodstream, as (targeted) drug delivery agents, as components of sensing ensembles, and as model systems for the SAMPL challenges. We propose to systematically vary the structural features of acyclic CB[n]-type receptors, study their molecular recognition properties in buffered water toward selected drugs / toxic substances, and engage with chemical and biological collaborators to demonstrate their utility in biomedical applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The endoplasmic reticulum is a ubiquitous cellular organelle that plays a central role in lipid metabolism. The three projects in this proposal investigate how cells generate and regulate subdomains within the endoplasmic reticulum that maintain cellular lipid homeostasis. Gaining insight into these processes is critical for understanding how defects in them contribute to several disease states, particularly obesity, type 2 diabetes, and atherosclerosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATVE This Academic Learning Health System Scholars Program (aLHSSP) will provide the next generation of translational scientists with the methodologic and professional skills to a) conduct rigorous research in the complex environments of health systems, and b) disseminate and implement findings from such research into practice. The aLHSSP will offer a postdoctoral training experience that will lead to a Master of Science in Learning Health System Science; Scholars will also conduct a mentored research project that addresses a pressing health system issue. They will be guided by teams of experienced and committed faculty who are subject-matter experts and well-grounded in the principles of effective mentoring.
PROJECT_TERMS: Postdoctoral Fellow
PROJECT_TITLE: CTSA Postdoctoral T32 at Wake Forest

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The Wake Forest (WF) Clinical and Translational Science Institute (CTSI) K12 Program is a component of the WF CTSI and shares its overall vision of catalyzing our health system’s transformation into an exemplary Learning Health System. To develop a highly trained workforce of scientists prepared to accomplish this vision, the CTSI K12 Program will provide a rigorous training and team mentoring program for outstanding early-career faculty with a focus on 1) promoting a deep understanding of the translational science process; 2) developing expertise in the eight learning health system science competencies central to an Academic Learning Health System; and 3) continuing to expand on the strengths of our CTSI KL2 Program and of our collaborations with other CTSA hubs to exchange learning experiences and share highly successful training models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The Wake Forest Clinical and Translational Science Institute (CTSI) seeks to create a model for advancing translational science in a large academic health system with activities grounded in a culture of accountability for enhancing diversity, equity, and inclusion. Development of such a model would have great impact on human health given the rapid consolidation of academic and non-academic health systems in the United States and the challenges in conducting research in busy practice settings. Overcoming roadblocks and challenges associated with translational science in environments of the size and scope of large medical centers will greatly accelerate the development of effective techniques for the prevention and treatment of disease.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of this proposal is to benefit health through the creation of a center (the Hub) that will catalyze new research, training, and community outreach. Our first theme, From Lab To Life, highlights our focus on accelerating the translation of basic biomedical discovery to possible clinical application. Our large ICTR includes the universities and health system in Maryland that have the most research activity. We expect to leverage these organizations to create high impact research that can move Maryland to better health outcomes and health equity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs) are an attractive therapeutic strategy because they can deliver cytotoxic compounds directly to cancer cells, and two ADCs were recently approved for use in metastatic bladder cancer. Radiation is the backbone of a curative, bladder-sparing treatment approach for localized bladder cancer, but the combination of ADCs and RT has not been investigated in any bladder cancer context. We will test the hypothesis that radiation upregulates ADCs targets on bladder cancer cells and leads to a synthetic lethal combination between ADCs and radiation that could be harnessed to improve bladder-sparing treatment outcomes for bladder cancer patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cellular senescence is a key mechanism driving age-related bone loss and other aging co-morbidities. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative The Hedgehog and Wnt cell-cell signaling pathways govern critical processes in embryonic development, adult stem cell maintenance, regeneration, and in the pathogenesis of several human cancers and birth defects. We propose to use biochemistry, structural, cell and chemical biology, to elucidate essential mechanisms that govern how the Hedgehog and Wnt ligands are released from producing cells, how they are delivered to their receptors, and how the signals are transduced in target cells. These studies will have broad impact on human health, by advancing our understanding of how certain types of cancer and birth defects develop, and by defining novel targets and strategies for cancer therapy.
