IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Unlike humans, many animals can regenerate large portions of their body after major injury by using conserved genes and molecular pathways in unique ways. The goal of this proposal is to use the simple and highly regenerative animal Hydra to uncover the regulatory mechanisms that connect injury to the regeneration of new structures. Defining these mechanisms in regenerative animals is a key to ultimately harnessing these powers for therapeutic medicine.

PHR: Narrative The UAMS K12 program is designed to build a diverse cohort of successful translational scientists that can develop and test translational science innovations that will drive real world solutions to enhance health equity for rural and underrepresented populations. The program emphasizes gaining experience and expertise in Translational Science through interdisciplinary training opportunities, mentored research projects, individualized training, and education of mentors. The program will leverage the unique resources available through the TRI to produce a successful and diverse cohort of investigators that will produce Health and Societal Benefits for rural and underserved populations.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  We propose a new T32 Postdoctoral Training Program focused on Health Sciences Innovation and Entrepreneurship (HSIE) Training Program, which will offer mentored research training to postdoctoral fellows in the Colleges of Medicine, Nursing, Pharmacy and Public Health. This inter-professional training will be coupled to didactic and experiential learning to equip trainees with the skillset to catalyze research discoveries into health care applications. Program graduates will be uniquely positioned as translational scientists to succeed as academic investigators or pursue other exciting career options that depend on scientific and operation principles of the translation process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Title: Defining microtubule cytoskeleton regulatory pathways in development and disease P.I. Kassandra Ori-McKenney Project Narrative: DYRK1a kinase has been implicated in a range of intellectual disability disorders and neurodegenerative diseases. Little is known about the molecular network of this kinase and the distinct roles it plays during different cellular functions, but we have found that DYRK1a regulates the microtubule cytoskeleton by directly phosphorylating several microtubule-associated proteins (MAPs). This proposal seeks to delineate the pathways that orchestrate the dynamic microtubule cytoskeleton by combining live imaging of cellular and organismal systems with in vitro biochemical reconstitution assays. The overall goal of this project is to elucidate the multifaceted mechanisms of the DYRK1a-MAP network in regulating essential microtubule-based processes in order to provide insight into the contribution of this pathway to multiple human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The efficient subcellular localization of specific RNAs is a widespread process that is important for the proper functioning of diverse cell types across a wide range of organisms. Despite this, our understanding of the molecular language that underlies the regulation of this process is quite sparse. This proposal uses genome engineering, subcellular fractionation, single molecule imaging, and high-throughput sequencing to dissect the rules that govern how RNAs are distributed within cells with a focus on discovering RNA cis-elements and RNA-binding trans-factors that regulate the process.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Damaging more than just the skin, burn injury can lead to infection and multi-organ failure, often involving damage to the intestine and shifts in the gut microbiome dysbiosis, which allows translocation of bacteria and bacterial products into the circulation and triggers excessive inflammation in the lung and the brain. Nearly half of all adult burn patients consumed alcohol prior to sustaining their injuries and, and since alcohol intoxication and burn injury independently effect the gut microbiome, subjects with the combined insult of alcohol and injury have heightened inflammatory responses and worse outcomes. This MIRA renewal grant will allow us to 1) further examine alterations in the intestine after burn injury an determine if these changes contribute to aberrant inflammatory responses in the lung and the brain and 2) identify interventions to accelerate restoration of intestinal homeostasis using our clinically-relevant model of alcohol intoxication and burn injury and in burn patients who are at risk of developing failure of critical organs like the lung and the cognitive dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The GATeway to tHe wEst consoRtium (GATHER) is a collaboration between Washington University School of Medicine/St. Louis Children’s Hospital and the University of Colorado/Children's Hospital Colorado aimed at continuing progress in pediatric heart disease care and outcomes as a Pediatric Heart Network (PHN) Clinical Research Center. The consortium brings together unique expertise and resources to complement those of the PHN and draws from a geographically diverse population in the Midwest and Mountain regions of the U.S. with a strong commitment to enhancing diverse perspectives in study populations and training junior investigators. The GATHER consortium aims to develop a multi-center prospective registry, PROSPECT-HF, to study practice variation and response to guideline-directed medical therapy in pediatric and single ventricle heart failure (HF) and to embed clinical trials of novel HF therapies. As the prevalence of HF in children grows without a significant improvement in outcomes, this proposal offers a paradigm shift in the way that HF therapies are studied and administered in children and may offer insight into how to individualize HF therapies in this population.

PHR: Narrative Drugs can cure disease and reduce suﬀering. Unfortunately, for some patients drugs cause unacceptable side eﬀects or do not work at all. Our research focuses on discovering the reasons for variation in individual drug response. We use computational methods to combine molecular, cellular and clinical data to gain a deeper understanding of how drugs work in order to enable more precise prescribing decisions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Molecular machines that function in DNA repair maintain integrity of the genome by promoting faithful repair of the most genotoxic DNA lesions and faithful genome replication. Defects in their regulation can lead to genetic instability and chromosomal rearrangements causing cancer, aging, and diseases associated with progressive expansion of repeated sequences (including Huntington's disease, myotonic dystrophy and Fragile X syndrome). Understanding the fundamental molecular mechanisms of how DNA repair is regulated and its dysregulation will reveal features, which can be exploited in developing novel therapeutics.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This proposed study will investigate the function of lysosomal membrane transporting proteins and lysosomal protein quality control system. Our discoveries will shed light on the development of new treatment strategies for LSDs and neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Mutation and recombination are the sources of all genetic variation, the fuel of evolution, and the ultimate cause of heritable diseases as well as of many cancers. This proposal describes a set of research projects aimed at understanding how and why these fundamental genetic processes differ among humans and across species.

PHR: Project Narrative The purpose of this study is to test the protection of mitochondria and retinal ganglion cells in adult mice with high-density aromatic peptides (HDAP) following optic nerve crush. This approach has novel potential to optimize mitochondria functions and to minimize oxidative stress that occurs following neural trauma.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Disproportionately high rates of early substance use among American Indian (AI) youth put them at greater risk for developmental disruption and long-term health consequences than their non-AI peers. Social network researchers have examined adolescents’ social networks and used them to enhance prevention; these efforts, however, have not reached AI communities. This longitudinal mixed methods study will collect social network data at the individual and community level to explore the structure and function of AI adolescent social networks and examine how network features relate to risk and protection for substance use, suicide, and exposure to violence over time.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative My proposed research program will provide technologies to extend the reach of optical microscopy, from subcellular dynamics up to entire model organisms. At the same time, we will bridge these different scales through smart microscopy, which autonomously adjusts temporal and spatial resolution to efficiently (in terms of time, amount of data and sample irradiation) explore a specimen. If successful, these technologies may prove transformative in biological and biomedical research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE All animal cells use microtubules during division to create the mitotic spindle and during differentiation for cell polarity, shape, and transport. The proposed research will define the mechanisms that control how microtubules become spatially organized to carry out these fundamentally different processes. An understanding of the mechanisms that control microtubule organization should provide therapeutic insight into the growing number of specific birth defects and human cancers that have been linked to defects in the microtubule cytoskeleton.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The overall vision of Stanford’s CTSA-supported research “Hub” is to transform clinical, translational, and science of translation research and education (CTSRE), by making CTSRE more effective and efficient at discovery, clinical, translational, and science of translation research and education to serve the health needs of diverse individuals. In the next seven years, we believe the Stanford CTSA can best achieve this vision by capitalizing on our greatest strengths, namely a) educating and training the next generation of clinical, translational, and science of translation researchers; b) developing and implementing across all elements of our CTSA the principles of the science of translation, including rigor and reproducibility (SPORR), team science, health policy, and Research Equity, Accessibility, Diversity, and Inclusiveness (READI); and c) developing and implementing innovative, data driven, and clinical operational approaches to accelerate, scale, and diversify our translational research and science of translation efforts. We aim to employ state-of-the-field evaluative approaches to determine the effectiveness and maximize the impact of our Stanford CTSA CTSRE efforts locally, regionally, nationally, and across our networks, including the CTSA consortium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Genetic exchange between species, or hybridization, has made major contributions to the genomes of species across the tree of life, including our own. We propose to characterize the consequences of hybridization from the single gene to the genome-wide scale. We will build maps of genetic incompatibilities caused by hybridization, investigate the molecular mechanisms through which incompatibilities act, and discover variables impacting the outcomes of hybridization at a genome-wide scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The overall objective of the proposed work is to test how individuals respond to repeated bouts of social success or defeat and the neurological and physiological mechanisms underpinning these long-term changes. By coupling together a novel mechanistic framework, Bayesian updating, with high-resolution behavioral tracking and molecular techniques in a powerful naturally clonal vertebrate model system, this work will provide comprehensive insight into the patterns and mechanisms of social status gain and loss. This work has implications for understanding how the effects of positive and negative social experiences can ripple forward through the lifetime of an individual.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (from parent grant): Mammalian cells use biological zip codes to transport mRNAs, which encode the information for the synthesis of proteins, to specific locations in the cell, so that proteins are made in their appropriate location. This RNA localization process is critical to early development, learning and memory, and at the level of the individual cell, to the secretion of hormones and neurotransmitters as well the cell surface localization of proteins functioning in signaling and cell-cell communication. The findings from this study are expected to reveal new mechanisms of RNA localization and identify conserved pathways that may be dysregulated in diseases of development, metabolism, and ageing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Homeless people have a 3.5-fold higher prevalence of cigarette smoking in comparison to non-homeless people, contributing to 2-fold higher rates of lung cancer and 3- to 5-fold higher rates of tobacco-attributable death. To advance the public health objective of improving smoking cessation in socioeconomically disadvantaged populations, we will conduct a community-based randomized controlled trial to assess the effect of financial incentives on smoking abstinence among adult smokers at Boston Health Care for the Homeless Program. The findings of this study could inform tobacco treatment efforts for the 934,000 people served annually in US Health Care for the Homeless programs.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Infectious diarrhea is a growing public health issue in the United States and globally a major cause of death in children under 5. We have identified an evolutionary conflict between mammals and bacteria that cause diarrhea by targeting the host receptor guanylyl-cyclase c, which maintains fluid balance in the gut. The goal of this project is to expand our study of this conflict and identify inhibitors of the bacterial toxins to guide potential treatment of infectious diarrhea.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: VA EASTERN COLORADO HEALTH CARE SYSTEM
PHR: The Inflammatory Bowel Diseases (IBD), including ulcerative colitis (UC) and Crohn’s disease (CD), are diseases of the gastrointestinal tract that result from abnormal immune responses to luminal antigens in genetically-susceptible individuals. IBD represents a disease with among the highest hospitalization rates within military veteran populations (>100,000 hospitalizations from 1975-2006), high readmission rates with incidence of IBD are on the increase in some populations. A recent study of more than 100,000 military service members estimated the incidence of IBD to be 2-10 times greater than non-service members, with a striking relationship between IBD incidence and the number of life stressors. The studies proposed here are designed to harness information from novel inflammation-related metabolic pathways that promote tissue healing in representative models of human IBD. It is our hope that results from these studies will provide new therapeutic options for military patients with IBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cancer immunotherapies have demonstrated significant clinical success for subgroups of patients with varying malignancies. However, due in part to their systemic administration, therapeutic limitations include immune- related adverse effects and diminished efficacy due to poor tumor penetration. This proposal seeks to engineer immunotherapeutic probiotic bacteria that target primary cancers and associated metastases and locally deliver immunotherapy and adjuvants to stimulate systemic antitumor immunity with minimal side effects.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health as it addresses an important gap in understanding relational health risks that affect child health and development. The purpose of this exploratory mixed-methods study is to develop knowledge of post-separation abuse and examine how post-separation abuse impacts children’s health needs and flourishing outcomes. This research is relevant to NICHD’s priority to understand the developmental impact of adverse childhood experiences, identify opportunities for intervention, and ensure that all children have the chance to live healthy, safe, and productive lives.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: While sexual dimorphisms have been reported in the adipose tissue’s metabolic adaptation to environmental temperature or nutritional challenges, the sex-specific mechanisms regulating adipose tissue’s responses are not fully understood. This research proposal aims to test whether estrogen-initiated ERα signaling in the ventrolateral region of the ventromedial hypothalamus contributes to sex dimorphic regulation of adipose tissue metabolic adaptation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INST AND ST UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT Strokes occur when blood flow to the brain is disrupted – a condition that is one of the leading causes of death and disability in the United States, affecting ~800,000 patients every year. It is critical therefore to gain a better understanding of scenarios involving the abrupt loss of blood flow and associated mechanisms that translate changes in physical forces into intracellular signals, especially with respect to the components of brain blood vessels, namely pericytes and endothelial cells. The ultimate goal is to identify molecular and cellular mechanisms that will inspire the design of novel stroke therapies and build upon established ones to improve patient outcomes.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM) is a highly aggressive brain tumor associated with extremely poor prognosis and survival. Although relatively rare in the US general population, GBM is the third most common cause of cancer death in the US active-duty military. Increased GBM incidence in US Veterans has been attributed to the toxic exposures to Agent Orange in Vietnam and burn pits in Iraq and Afghanistan. Despite significant advances in GBM therapy, the 5-year survival is only 7.2% in the United States. These existing treatment challenges highlight an urgent need for novel therapeutic strategies targeting therapy-resistant cancer subpopulations. Identification and selective targeting of tumor cells, which are resistant to current therapy, may ultimately lead to successful abrogation of clinical tumor growth and improve the quality of life and survival of patients suffering from GBM.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Trans-arterial chemoembolization (TACE) is the most commonly used therapy for patients with unresectable hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). TACE is a minimally invasive procedure that involves placing a catheter into the artery in the liver that feeds the tumor, administering chemotherapeutics and then blocking the artery with embolics in order to kill tumor cells by depriving them of essential oxygen and nutrients. While TACE has a proven survival benefit, local recurrence is common, and long-term survival rates are poor. Prior studies demonstrate that HCC cells survive the oxygen and nutrient deprivation through autophagy, a process of cellular self- eating, to provide nutrients required for survival. The proposed project will leverage this dependency to develop a novel approach to TACE that integrates autophagy inhibition to improve therapeutic response by increasing tumor cell killing and enhancing anti-tumor immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Peripheral arterial disease (PAD), an illness commonly found in the elderly and caused by arterial occlusion in the lower body, affects more than 200 million people worldwide and is associated with high rates of morbidity and mortality. To reduce these complications and improve the quality of life for PAD patients, our research aims to develop novel biodegradable nanoparticles to deliver therapeutic agents that specifically protect cells under ischemic stress conditions, facilitate the formation of blood vessels under hypoxia, and facilitate noninvasive multimodal imaging methods, such as fluorescent and photoacoustic imaging, to monitor the progress of this therapeutic intervention. The impact of our research is significant as these new nanoparticle platforms could be used to deliver any therapeutics locally, treat this disease effectively, and monitor the treatment noninvasively by imaging.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epithelial ovarian cancer (EOC) is the leading cause of gynecologic cancer-related deaths in the United States. EOC is a genetically heterogeneous disease, and therefore it is imperative to develop novel therapeutic strategies based on patients’ genetic makeup such as overexpression of an oncogene CARM1. This proposal will lay a critical foundation to establish the use HSP70 inhibitors in CARM1-expressing epithelial ovarian cancer and if successful it will have an immediate impact on ovarian cancer patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The Ras pathway is one of the most commonly deregulated pathways in human cancer, yet there are still no effective therapies for Ras-driven tumors. In this application we will be studying two genetically distinct Ras-driven malignancies. Specifically, we aim to elucidate an important mechanism by which these Ras-driven cancers are protected from MEK inhibitors and will use this insight as a basis for developing and testing rational combination therapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Improving our ability to predict and prevent the onset of serious mental illnesses (SMI) will require mapping the relationships between underlying pathogenic factors, early markers of SMI, and clinical progression across development. Towards this end, we will establish a new cohort of 3,000 children and early adolescents enriched for SMI risk in the Paisa population of Colombia, and analyze the relationships between clinical and neurobehavioral signs and symptoms in childhood, individualized genetic risk profiles, and longitudinal clinical outcomes. Through this work, we aim to improve SMI prediction, prior to full illness onset, and further our understanding of how psychiatric phenotypes relate to one another and underlying genetic risk factors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mitochondrial electron transport chain (ETC) is an essential metabolic pathway in humans, and its disfunction causes debilitating and fatal diseases with no current treatments. The goal of this proposal is to understand, at the atomic level, the mechanism and regulation of mitochondrial ETC complexes and supercomplexes. Defining how the enzymes function and can be regulated in diverse contexts will provide the basic science foundation for future strategies in drug development and treatment of metabolic disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The innate immune system serves as the first line of defense against pathogens, including coronaviruses. The research proposed in this application will characterize innate immune sensors and downstream pathways that are involved in the response to SARS-CoV-2 infection. These studies will inform the development of future therapeutic interventions to prevent the morbidity and mortality of COVID-19 as well as other diseases associated with inflammatory cytokine release.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Infections with drug resistant Gram-positive bacteria pose a serious threat to patients in clinical settings. A key to controlling and preventing pathogenic outbreaks is to understand how bacteria evade attack by antimicrobial compounds. In this work we will combine structural and functional analyses to understand how membrane protein complexes called “Bce modules” sense and provide resistance to antimicrobial peptides in Gram-positive bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Program Director/Principal Investigator (Last, First, Middle): Gantz, Bruce J. PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERVIEW, CORE A, CORE B This research has the potential to develop a better understanding how the brain processes speech amongst challenging listening situations by parsing out critical issues from all levels of the auditory system and as it relates to understanding in the real-world. We investigate the influence of factors, such as higher order cognitive processes (e.g., working memory and executive functioning), with high potential to understand speech in noise abilities among individuals with hearing loss. Understanding the effect of these abilities on communication and socialization during real-world listening and its influence on psychosocial well-being could have long-term impact on cognitive stability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Assembly-line polyketide synthases are multifunctional catalytic machines responsible for the biosynthesis of structurally complex and diverse natural products including many antibiotics. The objective of this research is to advance a fundamental understanding of the structure, mechanism and evolution of these enzymatic assembly lines. We also seek to test our understanding of these assembly lines by decoding a polyketide synthase commonly found in isolates of Nocardia associated with nocardiosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed projectdevelops a self-sustainablepower source (SSPS) for intracardiacpacemakers using swine models. The SSPS integrates a stretchable, frequency-tuning implantable nanogenerator with a miniaturized supercapacitor and regulating electronics, which can automatically and consistently power a pacemaker by harvesting energy from heartbeats. This project will establish the technology framework necessary to move rapidly to in vivo intracardiac implantation and the testing of SSPS for powering intracardiac pacemakers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT 1: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed study is relevant to public health because it aims 1) to determine functional benefits of two techniques of reducing intracochlear trauma caused by cochlear implant surgery, and 2) to better understand the relationship between genetic variations and peripheral auditory function. Results from this study will have a broad impact on the field by 1) providing the scientific foundation for shifting the current clinical practice for cochlear implant patients by implementing Dex-eluting electrode array or robotics-assisted electrode insertion as part of standard clinical care, and 2) laying the groundwork for developing effective, evidence-based clinical practice guidelines for managing cochlear implant patients based on their genetic etiologies. This project is relevant to the mission of NIH because it seeks fundamental knowledge about the nature of electrical hearing and strives to apply this knowledge to reduce disability in patients with cochlear implants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Medulloblastomas are one of the most common pediatric brain tumors, and they have not benefited from recent dramatic advances in treating cancer by activating the immune system. Our study proposes developing a detailed molecular and cellular understanding of how these tumors interact with the immune system. Through computational modeling of these data, we will seek approaches that could alter the immune system to benefit medulloblastoma patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT 2: PROJECT NARRATIVE Project 2 investigates the auditory cognitive mechanisms that are responsible for perceiving and attending to acoustic patterns over frequency and time. We will assess cochlear implant users’ performance and cortical activities for auditory cognition tasks operating over the various timescales from words to sentences including the grouping of coherent spectro-temporal patterns, auditory working memory, endogenous attention, and how the performance and neural activities change over time. The outcome of this study will characterize auditory cognitive mechanisms in CI users that apply to speakers of any language of any ability, and with neural measures that can be realistically applied to clinical populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed training program will prepare students to be leaders in the field of pharmacological sciences. Integrative Pharmacological Sciences Training Program (IPSTP) trainees will receive in-depth training in the science of drug discovery, in vivo pharmacology, and computational pharmacology. Also, trainees completing this program will make important contributions to our understanding of the causes and treatments of human illness. Students will graduate from the program prepared for a range of scientific careers in academia, industry, and government.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project is consistent with NIDCD’s focus on improving language interventions for young children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD), including those who are minimally verbal. Findings will improve our ability to offer empirically supported clinical recommendations regarding adult linguistic simplification, thereby advancing evidence-based practice and maximizing long-term outcomes in children with ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: PROJECT 3: PROJECT NARRATIVE Project 3 investigates the cognitive mechanisms by which cochlear implant users process speech more efficienctly, a necessityfor real-world listening in challenging environments. It investigates a range of modifiable and predictive factors including real-world experience, language skills, listening effort, cortical integrity, and integration across ears, and it links these factors to eye-tracking measures of language processing efficiency and ecological momentary assessment of real-world outcomes. This will improve cochlear implantation criteria, suggest new standards for assessment outcomes and foster new avenues for improving post-implantation outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Economic vulnerability and racial disparities contribute to African-American young adults being disproportionately infected by HIV. The proposed intervention applies a peer-driven microenterprise model adapted for underserved U.S. communities and integrating text messages informed by behavioral economics to test the efficacy and mediating and differential effects on the reduction of condomless sex and increase in uptake of pre-exposure prophylaxis in high-risk, economically-vulnerable African-American young adults. Microenterprise reduces HIV risk through increased economic stability via jobs and employable income- generating skills that is hypothesized, in turn, to decrease financial distress associated with high-risk behaviors, while increasing resources to access HIV services.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE ADHD is a common and debilitating disorder that contributes to increased chance of deleterious risky behaviors that emerge or exacerbate in adolescence, leading to long-term negative outcomes such as addiction or incarceration. This grant proposes a comprehensive, longitudinal, multilevel (neural, behavioral, clinical) and multimodal (functional MRI, diffusion MRI) study in youth with ADHD across the transition to adolescence. By incorporating innovative brain network analytic tools and sophisticated longitudinal modeling techniques, this proposal will characterize developmental trajectories and identify childhood features that contribute to increased risk for negative outcomes in adolescence, leading to biomarker development for earlier detection of risk and more targeted treatment models for ADHD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The p53 tumor suppressor pathway is a central mechanism that prevents cancer development in mammals. In this proposal, we investigate a set of novel genes, called cis-regulatory long noncoding RNAs, which we believe to be mediators of p53 function. Using a series of rigorous genetic tools, elegant functional assays, and state-of-the-art molecular and biochemical approaches, our goal is to perform comprehensive characterization of cis-regulatory long noncoding RNAs and their roles in cancer processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We are using the metazoan model organism C. elegans to explore how non-coding RNA sculpts gene expression programs, drives heritable epigenetic states, and directs antiviral and transposon defense. We rely heavily on forward genetic screens, which pragmatically cannot be done in most other systems, to help us understand these biological processes, about which little is known. We hope and expect that the work we do in C. elegans will provide a framework upon which others can build to develop novel treatments for disease in people.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Brain metabolism, central nervous system (CNS) metabolism, and neuronal excitability are interdependent, and dysregulation of CNS metabolism is implicated in numerous neurological disorders, including Alzheimer’s Disease, epilepsy, Parkinson’s disease, and brain injury, but the mechanistic connections between CNS metabolism and disease are poorly understood. The unique, multidisciplinary Center of Biomedical Research Excellence (COBRE) on CNS Metabolism (CNS-Met) proposed here is a strategically designed, sustainable framework that promotes leading-edge research focused on the role of metabolic mediators of brain function and disease, with an emphasis on encouraging research excellence from Junior Research Project Leaders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE/NARRATIVE A major challenge in identifying genetic variants contributing risk to complex disease is distinguishing genetic variants that disrupt biological function from those that do not. Approaches to distinguish these types of variants routinely take advantage of evolutionary information, either to prioritize variants that have been subjected to natural selection or to calibrate models of background genetic variation in the genome. This project is relevant to public health because it will greatly increase our knowledge of different types of deleterious mutations and, by doing so, will increase the utility of evolutionary information for identifying biologically relevant and pathogenic variants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE A functional cure of HIV-1, or the establishment of antiretroviral therapy (ART)-free remission, require novel approaches to prevent or delay rebound viremia following ART cessation. A critical barrier to developing such strategies is the lack of understanding of the viral and host effector mechanisms that control HIV-1 reactivation in vivo. We recently discovered that viruses that rebound from latency following treatment interruption display the highest levels of IFN-I resistance observed at any time during the infection course. Here, we will characterize the viral factors that contribute to this phenotype and dissect key host defense mechanisms that place pressure on the rebounding virus pool. Harnessing these defenses may translate into more effective HIV/AIDS cure strategies.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
ORG_NAME: RALPH H JOHNSON VA MEDICAL CENTER
PHR: Acute kidney injury (AKI) occurs in 1-7% of hospitalizations and up to 25% of intensive care unit (ICU) admissions. Mortality rates in AKI patients, especially in ICUs, can be as high as 50-70%. AKI is also a significant contributor to the progression of chronic kidney disease. Given that in FY17 there were 683,185 acute admissions to VA Hospitals, AKI affected up to 47,823 Veterans. There were also 38,991 ICU admissions to VA Hospitals in FY17, so AKI affected up to 9,748 Veterans. As a kidney doctor at the VA, and in the South Carolina Army National Guard, I frequently see patients with AKI, and it is difficult to tell them there are no approved treatments other than supportive care. One of the most common forms of AKI is acute tubular necrosis (ATN). We linked an organelle called the primary cilium to ATN, and showed that the exocyst complex and cilia are necessary for tubule formation in cell culture. Here, we will determine how the exocyst protects against injury and enhances repair in mice, and test possible treatments for AKI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: This project involves using engineered human blood vessels created with induced pluripotent stem cells as a model for disease processes and development of new therapies. Such an approach can be extremely useful for rare diseases for which developing new therapies is extremely challenging and the number of patients is insufficient for clinical trials. Specifically, we will attempt to cure a rare genetic disease using a novel gene editing approach.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Shift workers represent nearly 30 % of the US workforce, and this occupational hazard conveys increased risk for multiple pathologies liked to disrupted inflammation. Since minority groups are more likely to engage in shift work, quality research initiatives that seek to understand the mechanistic links between shift work exposure and disease may significantly impact both health equity and overall public health. Understanding these mechanisms is of paramount importance because it could lead to the identification of screening targets and clinical interventions that can help mitigate shift-work disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Survivors of heart attack or stroke-induced brain injury suffer from many log-term physical, cognitive, psychological, and emotional impairments. By focusing specifically on understanding injury mechanisms that leads to mitochondrial and ultimately cellular bioenergetics failure, the research in this grant will promote the development of treatments with the ability to improve the long-term clinical outcome for stroke victims.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Proposal Narrative  Vascular contributions to cognitive impairment and dementia (VCID) are known to be common causes of dementia yet remain poorly understood. Diffuse white matter disease (DWD) is a common manifestation of small-vessel cerebrovascular pathology and a key subtype of VCID. In these series of studies we propose to determine how placental growth factor (PlGF) causes DWD via formation of new, immature and leaky blood vessels in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative Delirium, an acute confusional state, is a common, serious, and potentially preventable condition in the older population, yet our ability to assess the severity of an episode of delirium is not well understood. Because the impact of a delirium episode may be even more important in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD), our goal is to develop new ways to measure delirium severity in persons both with and without ADRD. We cannot manage and treat a condition appropriately until we can measure its impact; thus, this application is a fundamental step to help develop and test new treatments for delirium in persons with and without ADRD, and ultimately, to improve healthcare and quality of life for older persons and their families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is aimed at elucidating how the multiple trafficking pathways inside cells are coordinated. Unobstructed flow of proteins and membrane through these pathways is required for proper functioning of all cells during normal growth and under stress, and even minor defects can result in severe acquired and inherited diseases. Conserved small GTPases that function as molecular switches are key regulators of these pathways and we will explore mechanisms by which these GTPases integrate cellular pathways into a dynamic network.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our work focuses on how signaling networks generate complex cellular behaviors such as cell movement and immune cell activation. The ability to control cell migration would be a valuable tool for combating atherosclerosis, inflammation, metastasis, and other pathological processes that occur upon the disruption of cellular guidance mechanisms. Our work on the mechanism of immune cell activation will directly impact our understanding of autoimmune disease, vaccine development, and immunotherapy-based cancer treatments.

PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE Tri-Institutional PhD Program in Chemical Biology (TPCB) Chemistry is at the heart of all biological processes and provides the basis for the vast majority of modern medicines. Established in 2001, TPCB is a leading chemical biology graduate program that provides comprehensive training at the interface of chemistry, biology, and medicine, enabling students to bring quantitative chemical approaches to forefront problems in biomedical research. The program is offered jointly by Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center, The Rockefeller University, and Weill Cornell Medical College, three premier research institutions that form a Tri-Institutional campus in the heart of New York City.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Methodologies will be developed for the automated synthesis of complex glycans with full control over branching of N-glycans, installation of bisecting GlcNAc, patterns of fucosylation, I-branching, and sulfation of poly-LacNAc chains. The new methodologies will be applied to prepare a collection of complex N-glycans that resemble structures expressed by respiratory tissue. The resulting compounds will be used to develop an integrated technology platform to examine host-pathogen interactions with a focus on Influenza A viruses. 1

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: Premature heart beats, so called “Premature Ventricular Contractions” (PVCs), are commonly seen in patients with heart failure. PVCs have been recognized to debilitate the heart and cause heart failure, called "PVC‐cardiomyopathy". This cardiomyopathy also carries significant financial burden in the care of our veterans. A PVC-Cardiomyopathy canine model has been developed and used to understand the mechanism of this reversible CM. The main purpose of this study is to validate a similar PVC- Cardiomyopathy model in the swine species. We anticipate that this study will help us understand the mechanism of this heart condition, leading to better prevention and treatment of PVC-Cardiomyopathy and identification of high-risk patients with significant impact in heart failure admission, mortality and VA healthcare spending.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: 2.0 Project narrative Chronic, non-communicable diseases (NCDs) now account for over half of morbidity and quality of life reductions in resource-limited settings. Of particular importance is the growing epidemic of multi-morbidity, or the accumulation of chronic conditions, including combinations of both non-communicable and communicable conditions on well-being and quality of life. However, the majority of disease treatment programs, donor funding mechanisms and research infrastructure focuses on infectious diseases, and most such programs are siloed. This D43 training program application will directly respond to PAR-18-901 (“Chronic, Non- Communicable Diseases and Disorders Across the Lifespan: Fogarty International Research Training Award”) by strengthening the capacity of Ugandan junior investigators to pursue research careers on NCDs and multi- morbidity through a proven co-mentoring model of sustained training. Our over-arching goal is to build a foundation of independent junior investigators upon which to build a regional center of excellence in the study of multi-morbidity in Uganda.

PHR: Project Narrative Beta cell dysfunction in diabetes results from prolonged hyperglycemia, termed glucose toxicity. In this proposal, we will explore specific molecular mechanisms of glucose toxicity in pancreatic beta cells and test therapeutic interventions to mitigate these effects. These studies could lead to the development of therapeutic strategies to treat beta cell dysfunction in diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: The repair of DNA double-strand breaks (DSBs) is essential to maintain genome integrity and to guard against cancer in humans. We will use the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae model system to address the mechanisms of DSB repair; specifically, we will determine how repair proteins interacts with chromatin remodeling complexes to process DSB ends, and define the roles of the Mre11 complex and nucleosome assembly factors in repair of collapsed replication forks. In the long term we believe that mechanisms under investigation in this proposal will provide new insight and fundamental knowledge for understanding disease caused by genomic instability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Pericyte-Macrophage Interactions Maintain CNS Immune Tolerance NARRATIVE The lesions that arise in the brain and spinal cord of patients with MS are associated with infiltrating T cells that initially accumulate at the borders of the central nervous system (CNS). Events at the borders of the CNS acts as critical checkpoints on the migration path of an autoreactive T cell. This project will investigate a novel cellular interaction between pericytes and macrophages at the borders of the CNS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Malaria is a leading killer of children worldwide, but efforts to develop a preventive vaccine have failed due to our limited understanding of the immune response to infection. We will investigate the role of gamma-delta T cells, a unique lymphocyte subset with innate reactivity to malaria, in protecting infants from malaria. We will determine how gamma-delta T cells respond to malaria antigens encountered before birth (using cord blood samples from infants with and without placental malaria) as well as postnatally, in response to malaria infections acquired during infancy.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE We have previously identified antiviral compounds targeting the HIV capsid protein (CA) that can stabilize or destabilize the capsid core. This project will help to understand the structural basis of HIV capsid core stability, which controls many steps in the virus life cycle. These studies should identify lead compounds with improved pharmacological properties, high potency, and improved resistance profiles.

PHR: The melanocortin pathway has been identified in mice and humans, to regulate obesity. This research project proposes to discover melanocortin-3 receptor (MC3R) selective molecules and study the role of the MC3R in energy/metabolic homeostasis. These goals are important for target validation and rational design and drug discovery of molecules as potential therapeutic agents regarding obesity, type 2 diabetes, and associated diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative This project addresses several issues of central importance to the understanding of how cardiac radiation treats ventricular arrhythmias, a significant cause of morbidity and mortality. This proposal tests the hypothesis that radiation treatment transcriptionally regulates the expression of ion channel subunits that regulate cardiac conduction. Defining the acute effects of irradiation on the electrical substrate is expected to facilitate clinical implementation of this promising new anti-arrhythmic therapy and advance the field of cardiac radiation biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PI: Claudio Punzo Project Narrative Retinal-pigmented epithelium atrophy (RPE) that results in geographic atrophy (GA) in humans is one of the leading causes for blindness in the industrialized world. This is because there is currently no treatment available for to prevent RPE atrophy and thus GA, which is an advanced form of Age-related Macular Degeneration (AMD). The disease is characterized by focal RPE cell loss. Because the RPE maintains photoreceptor homeostasis, photoreceptors die as well, which then leads to vision loss. Recently, it has been recognized that the high metabolic demands of photoreceptors may contribute to disease progression in AMD, in particular, because photoreceptors and RPE metabolism are tightly linked. To study how photoreceptor metabolism can affect the RPE we generated an animal model in which photoreceptor metabolism is altered. These mice develop AMD-like characteristics including focal RPE atrophy. In this project we propose to investigate what exactly causes the pathologies seen in these mice and how the RPE deteriorates over time. This will help us understand how altered photoreceptor metabolism can affect RPE health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The WHO currently recommends annual mass azithromycin distribution in trachoma-endemic areas until the district-level prevalence of trachomatous inflammation-follicular (TF) drops below 5%, an arbitrary threshold that has never been empirically validated and is now becoming more important as we approach the endgame. Our proposal assesses whether annual azithromycin distribution can be stopped in communities with TF prevalence in the range of 0% to 20%, and to evaluate alternative indicators of trachoma transmission. We anticipate that the results of this study will provide evidence that azithromycin distributions can be stopped earlier, thus reducing distribution of unnecessary antibiotic, and evidence that true infection can be locally eliminated even in the setting of a low prevalence of TF.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Hexanucleotide GGGGCC repeat expansion in the C9ORF72 gene is the most frequent cause of two neurodegenerative diseases, Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD) and Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS). Disease mechanisms include loss of C9orf72 function and gain of toxicity from the repeat containing RNAs. This project will determine cell-type-specific toxicity of C9orf72 repeat expansions in FTD and ALS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative (8 lines) With revised title “Emergent Properties of Complex Systems: From Atoms to Macromolecules; from Humans to Societies” this proposal uses data analysis and simulation to show how fundamental interactions lead to complex emergent behavior. Our half a century of experience on how atomic interactions lead to the complex molecular systems key to human health will be applied to protein structure refinement and ribosome function, two long-standing difficult problems. The scope of the work will be broadened to apply the same philosophical approach to a pressing public health problem: how viral diseases spread. Atoms will be replaced by people, atom type by their mobility, infectivity and recovery rate, and the “interatomic forces” by human interactions. Such ‘atomistic’ simulations are expected to reveal how spread can be controlled.

IC_NAME: Veterans Affairs
PHR: The Department of Veterans Affairs is the largest provider of medical care to people with HIV in the United States. The introduction of effective antiretroviral therapy (ART) for HIV infection has extended survival, but this success has been offset by a rising burden of obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus in Veterans with HIV. Notably, Veterans with HIV have a higher risk of developing type 2 diabetes compared to HIV-negative Veterans with similar age and body weight, but the reason for this higher risk is not clear. Recent studies show that treated HIV can cause changes in adipose tissue (body fat) that are similar to the changes occurring in obesity, which reduce the ability of adipose tissue to store energy and promote the accumulation of adipocytes (fat cells) infiltrating other organs and tissues such as the liver and skeletal muscle. The goal of this study is to understand if excess accumulation of fat in the skeletal muscle of obese Veterans treated for HIV promotes the development of mitochondrial dysfunction and glucose intolerance, information necessary for therapies to prevent diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Surgical site infections (SSIs) are associated with increased patient morbidity, mortality, and healthcare costs. ESKAPE (Enterococcus, S. aureus, Klebsiella, Acinetobacter, Pseudomonas, and Enterobacter spp.) pathogens are particularly pathogenic because they have increased capacity to acquire resistance and virulence traits. We have proven that a multifaceted program involving improved basic perioperative preventive measures can generate substantial reductions in S. aureus transmission and significant reductions in SSIs (88% reduction as compared to usual care). In this study, we aim to examine the relative effectiveness of each component of this program in controlling ESKAPE transmission and reducing SSIs and to identify an optimal implementation strategy for national dissemination. This work will improve perioperative patient safety for the 51 million patients who undergo surgery each year.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The work in this proposal is aimed at elucidating the basic molecular mechanisms of pathogenesis underlying neurodegenerative diseases that are associated with a genetic anomaly in C9orf72, including amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and frontotemporal dementia (FTD). Although these diseases are becoming an increasingly relevant public health challenge in our aging society, the mechanisms underlying most of these neurodegenerative conditions remain poorly understood. The biochemical, molecular, and genetic studies outlined in this proposal could lead to novel therapeutic interventions for those neurodegenerative diseases, for which effective treatments are still lacking.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: RELEVANCE The proposed research will give valuable information into the sensory mechanisms used by PAS and LOV domains, a widespread group of ligand-regulated protein/protein interaction domains used by organisms to sense and respond to changes in their environment. Common structural features of these systems make parallel studies particularly powerful to give insights into a diverse range of biological responses, from how nutrients stimulate human cells and yeast to how bacteria and fungi respond to blue light. Further, this mechanistic information is critical to the development of novel small molecule ligands and “optogenetic” light- regulated protein reagents, giving biomedical researchers new ways to control cellular function with unprecedented precision.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This MARC at CSU program seeks to enhance access of underrepresented students to advanced research training (PhD, MD/PhD, DVM/PhD) and successful careers in biomedical research. This will be achieved by 1) outreach and recruitment of underrepresented, socioeconomically disadvantaged, and disabled undergraduates into the Biomedical Sciences Major; 2) providing a supportive and inclusive environment; 3) providing academic support and laboratory-based research training; and 4) cultivating professional development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE (Overall) This project is investigating the human immune responses to infection by and vaccination against three of the most prevalent and devastating global diseases, malaria, HIV-AIDS, and Covid. It is doing so to elucidate detailed characteristics of these immune responses to aid development of needed vaccines and therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Abnormal activation of the complement pathway, which regulates innate immunity and inflammation, is associated with blinding diseases such as inherited and age-related macular degenerations. This research will investigate how a novel pathway of intracellular complement activation endangers the health of the retinal pigment epithelium, a key site of insult in macular degenerations. We will study the impact of intracellular complement on the function and integrity of the retinal pigment epithelium, and identify potential points of therapeutic intervention that can be targeted to preserve vision.

PHR: Project Narrative Humans carry enormous gut microbial communities that vary widely between individuals. The microbiome can metabolize chemicals we consume, including food and medical drugs. IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Household air pollution resulting from cooking with solid fuels (wood, charcoal, animal dung, coal), the primary household energy source for nearly 3 billion people, is responsible for an estimated 2.3 million premature deaths each year, primarily in low- and middle-income countries. The proposed work leverages the Household Air Pollution Intervention Network (HAPIN) trial in Guatemala to evaluate whether a liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) stove and fuel intervention to reduce this harmful exposure during early life (pregnancy and infancy) improves children’s lung function development and reduces respiratory disease episodes beyond the intervention period and until age 7 years, while exploring epigenetic biomarkers as research tools to understand the biological mechanism of effect. The proposed work will impact health and household energy policies by providing rigorous and generalizable insight to questions regarding the impact of air pollution exposure in early life on respiratory health later in childhood using a scalable household intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Whole-genome sequencing (WGS) studies of rare diseases typically fail to identify an underlying genetic cause in a majority of enrolled patients. Supplementing WGS with RNA sequencing of multiple blood cell types provides an opportunity for addressing this gap. We will develop approaches for exploiting such data, and apply them to discover new causes of disease in a unique cohort of a thousand rare disease patients, boosting the diagnostic power of genetic testing and broadening access to precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: The singular goal of most spinal cord injury (SCI) research programs is to repair the injured spinal cord and restore locomotor function. Unfortunately, restoration of walking is a low priority for most SCI individuals. In addition to impaired mobility, SCI causes slow and steady pathological changes in organ systems throughout the body. Failure to recognize and treat multi-organ system pathology as a standard of care may explain why survival rates have not improved for SCI patients (relative to able-bodied individuals) over the past 30 years. Experiments in this proposal are designed to study SCI as a disease of the entire body and will yield novel data that will ultimately promote recovery of function and quality of life (QoL) after SCI.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative No study has been performed to prospectively record the presenting complaints, signs, symptoms and comorbidities of children who raised the suspicion of pulmonary embolism (PE) in children. This lack of evidence puts children in jeopardy by causing both under diagnosis and over testing. Project BEEPER will assimilate the first ever multicenter prospective dataset that will allow better detection of PE in children and the potential to exclude PE without need for diagnostic testing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Patient-centered communication is associated with improved health-related quality of life and has been recognized as essential to high-quality gynecologic cancer care. The proposed research will refine and pilot test a novel, scalable intervention to promote patient-centered communication in ovarian cancer care. Further, the proposed research will address the need for efficient and accurate methods to identify patient-centered communication behaviors by assessing the feasibility of using natural language processing to analyze transcripts of audio-recorded clinic visits.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Malaria control is contingent upon interrupting transmission of the Plasmodium parasite by the mosquito vector. This project studies how processes triggered by blood feeding and leading to oogenesis affect Plasmodium falciparum development in the female Anopheles gambiae mosquito, the most important malaria vector. These studies will considerably increase our understanding of biological processes crucial to transmission of malaria and will generate new concepts that will inform current and future control strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes and associated diseases are major health concerns in today’s society. The proposed research is relevant to the mission of the NIDDK because it examines the therapeutic tractability of SWELL1 modulators for the treatment of Type 2 diabetes. Exploring this therapeutic approach and testing a series of SWELL1 modulators will expand our understanding of novel therapeutic avenues and delineate an innovative target for the treatment and prevention of diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project narrative The proposed research will provide critical information about effective Medicaid policies to improve health care utilization of Medicaid enrollees with opioid use disorder (OUD) and reduce the number of opioid-related overdoses among them. This knowledge will help inform state Medicaid policymakers who are seeking effective approaches in improving treatment for OUD among their Medicaid enrollees.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA viruses encompass both established and emerging pathogens, many of which cause significant morbidity and mortality worldwide and remain a constant threat to global public health, with antiviral therapies lacking for many of these viruses. The proposed study will define a new regulator of how the host senses RNA virus infection and activates the antiviral defense program, as well as defining how viruses use this new regulator for immune evasion. This study will reveal new targets that may be harnessed for the development of novel antiviral and immune therapeutics designed to limit viral infection, viral-mediated disease, and autoimmune disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: We propose a graduate research training program in Interdisciplinary Biomedical Science and Technology (I-BioSTeP) at the University of California Merced, a Hispanic-serving institution that opened in 2005. The major objective of this program is the establishment of the first doctoral level graduate training program at UC Merced in the biomedical sciences to train diverse cohorts of students to identify and solve pressing biological problems using quantitative interdisciplinary approaches that prepare them for competitive careers in the biomedical field. There are many unique aspects of our proposed program that specifically address our objectives including the diversity of our current student body and applicant pool that we target for recruitment, a core interdisciplinary curriculum of courses with lab components, a summer bridge program that addresses retention by bringing students out two months before classes and immersing them in hands-on training, mentoring and professional development such as fellowship proposal writing, an interdisciplinary multiple mentor structure, and a unique career development program that focuses on specific skills that are important in the biomedical research workforce such as business/entrepreneurial skills and science communication skills.

PROJECT_TITLE: G-RISE at UC Merced

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Radiation metabolomics is a well-established field in biomarker discovery and in assessing changes associated with metabolic perturbations, whether in tissues or biofluids. We have developed a rich database of radiation biomarkers in urine, blood, and saliva and we now plan to develop multiplex assays that are highly quantitative and can serve as the first step towards a deployable assay using commercially based instruments. Additionally, we will further develop membrane-based technologies that will aim to eliminate the pre-processing steps, thereby jump-starting the sample processing step and enrichment for specific classes of metabolites and stabilizing the biosignature during transport. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute alcohol intoxication is a robust predictor of intimate partner violence (IPV) perpetration for young adult men and women; therefore, interventions delivered proximally to drinking episodes – a period of high risk – are needed to reduce alcohol-facilitated IPV. This project seeks to improve public health by delivering a just-in-time text messaging intervention proximally to drinking episodes and evaluating the impact of the intervention on alcohol-facilitated IPV in a sample of at-risk young adult men and women. Additionally, through an innovative design this project is poised to answer these important questions: whether receiving a message, when, for whom, what type, and under what conditions this just-in-time messaging intervention leads to reductions in alcohol use and IPV perpetration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT) During normal conception as well as with the use of artificial reproductive technologies, a receptive uterus is key to a successful pregnancy, but it is not known what makes a uterus structurally competent for implantation. We have developed a technology to visualize and analyze the mouse uterus in three-dimensions during conception and establishment of pregnancy and we observe dynamic changes in the uterine structure that correlate to the rising levels of progesterone. This proposal will address the effects of progesterone and the embryo itself on endometrial structure, thus providing novel structure based insights into uterine receptivity during assisted reproduction and in conditions of subfertility.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: NARRATIVE Autoimmune and autoinflammatory diseases afflict 7-9% of the world population, and the goal of this project is to understand how the cytosolic cGAS/STING DNA sensing pathways contributes to these potentially devastating diseases so that we can better control them. This project draws on investigators with complementary expertise and will apply exciting new tools and strategies to study how innate immune responses in non-hematopoietic cells can promote lung complications. Insights resulting from this project should give us an opportunity to develop better treatment strategies for the many patients who suffer from interstitial lung disease.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK STATE PSYCHIATRIC INSTITUTE DBA RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR MENTAL HYGIENE, INC
PHR: A Mental Health Implementation Research Training Program will continue to prepare scientists to develop effective and feasible mental health interventions that are adapted to a specific culture and context, making more efficient use of less specialized human resources available in various low-resource systems of care that can help increase access to effective treatments and reduce the mental health treatment gap. In Mozambique, an expanding mental health service infrastructure will require implementation science research guiding the implementation and scale up of evidence-based interventions capable of reaching those often excluded from care. As a clear leader in the Portuguese speaking African countries (PALOP – Países Africanos de Língua Oficial Portuguesa), Mozambique can be a model to other PALOP and sub-Saharan African countries as well as other to low-resource settings, including the US, and thus help decrease the global mental health research and treatment gap.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative The overarching scientific premise of this application, which is a competing renewal application of an NIA-funded R01 (AG060737), entitled the “Wisconsin Longitudinal Study-Initial Lifetime’s Impact on ADRD (WLS-ILIAD)”, is to evaluate how the accumulation of social advantage and adversity over the full life course impacts risk and resilience against Alzheimer’s Disease and Related Dementias (ADRD). This project began tracking AD and related dementia onset in 2019 as WLS participants reached ~age 80, and would continue into the proposed grant period, thus building an invaluable and uniquely comprehensive dataset to allow for us—and our broader user base—to characterize the AD biomarkers, cognitive, social, behavioral, and medical profile of participants at risk or resilient to dementia.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Commensal microbes are already perfectly suited for safe and effective colonization of various physiological niches; what remains is to take advantage of their incredible genomic plasticity and ability to function as robust biochemical factories. This project will develop human commensal microbes as vehicles for delivery of therapeutic compounds directly to the site of disease in the gastrointestinal tract. To achieve this, we will engineer gut bacteria to produce and secrete targeted biological therapeutics such as antibody fragments in situ, with the goal of addressing critical issues in human health, including antibiotic resistance, toxicity, and rapid response to emerging threats.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pathogenic variants in the USH2A gene are the most prevalent causes of autosomal recessive retinitis pigmentosa and Usher syndrome, the leading cause of inherited deaf-blindness. Due to technical limitations of viral mediated gene delivery, conventional gene augmentation therapy is not amenable for treating USH2A- related disorders. This project aims to explore and evaluate the therapeutic potentials of CRISPR/Cas9-based gene editing strategies for correcting or repairing the pathogenic variants in the USH2A gene.

ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Relevance: Entry of a virus into host cells, which can occur at different subcellular locations, is the first and essential step in virus infection. The goal of the proposed research is to determine how HIV-1, which causes AIDS, enters its natural host CD4+ T cells and thus establishes productive infection. Knowledge obtained from the proposed studies will help us develop novel antiviral strategies that may inhibit spread of this virus to uninfected host cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative/Relevance We propose to develop a transmembrane sensor nanoarray platform that, if successful, will allow rapid, ultrasensitive, and specific detection and quantification of exosomal micro-RNA at the level of single exosomes. We will design Aampanying isothermal signal amplification strategies to detect the low abundance of nucleic acid biomarkers in exosomes. If successful, the proposed work will provide scientists, physicians, and clinicians with a means for rapid, ultrasensitive, highly-specific, cost-effective prognosis and diagnosis of cancer patients without surgical tissue biopsies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: FPIES is a non-IgE-mediated food allergy with unknown pathophysiology, and the only diagnostic test is an oral food challenge performed in a hospital setting which can result in severe symptoms. In this project, we propose a new low-dose multi-day food challenge protocol that we anticipate will generate milder symptoms, and will release mucosal T cells into the periphery for high dimensional single-cell analysis. This clinical and mechanistic study will improve care for patients with FPIES by improving diagnostics and revealing novel immune pathways of disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Narrative Among the 2.4 million Americans living with chronic HBV (HBV), Asian Americans are disproportionately impacted with the highest rates of HBV infection and liver cancer. Through this multilevel, longitudinal study, we will leverage our existing partnerships with Regional Cancer Health Disparities Networks of CBOs and clinical partners to examine the impact of structural racism and discrimination on HBV screening and linkage to care among Asian American ethnic groups: Chinese, Korean, and Vietnamese. Findings will inform the development of culturally appropriate, multilevel SRD interventions to improve quality of care and reduce Hepatitis-related liver disease and cancer disparities.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Sleep is beneficial to learning in early childhood, which leaves open the question of why children transition out of naps at such a critical developmental time for learning. The overarching objective of this proposal is to understand how maturation of the brain during early childhood results in more information being retained without interference, reducing the need for frequent consolidation that takes place during naps. Such information has translational and theoretical significance, enhancing understanding of the mechanisms underlying sleep regulation and the consequences of sleep on health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: Offspring of obese mothers have a high risk of asthma later in life, but the mechanism of this occurrence is unclear. This study will investigate changes in airway nerve function and innervation, both leading to the development or exacerbation of asthma, in offspring of obese mothers, and the role of insulin in these changes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The zebra finch courtship song shows striking similarities to human speech, and the zebra finch system provides a well-controlled animal model with exceptional behavior to understand the neural circuit mechanisms of vocal learning and motor control. We will develop next generation connectomics and spatial transcriptomics methods to simultaneously measure connectivity, gene expression, and activity of single neurons in the zebra finch song control system during singing. The proposed research paves the way for future R01 applications investigating the role of diverse HVC neurons in producing acoustic structure in the brain and is relevant to NIH's mission by furthering our understanding of the neuronal mechanisms underlying skilled motor behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Our project will develop methods for the nonparametric estimation of heterogenous treatment effects (HTEs). IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Islet transplantation replaces the lost insulin-producing pancreatic islet beta cells due to type 1 diabetes. However, this therapy is not widely used because of its variable efficacy and the requirement for life-long immunosuppression that can lead to a whole host of problems. We will tackle these issues using genetic engineering to help islet to withstand the stress of transplantation and resist immune attacks. The goal is to develop strategy for highly efficient islet transplantation without the need of immunosuppression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Tight regulation of coenzyme A (CoA), a cofactor that plays a key role in energy metabolism, is essential to maintain normal organ function and is achieved by balancing its synthesis and degradation. CoA degradation is a poorly characterized process and the research proposed herein will determine the importance of two CoA- degrading enzymes, Nudt19 and Nudt8, in the regulation of the CoA pools and CoA-dependent metabolic pathways within peroxisomes and mitochondria, respectively. This knowledge will establish the potential of targeting CoA-degrading enzymes to manipulate specific subcellular CoA pools and correct deranged metabolic processes with more selectivity.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Maternal morbidity and mortality in sub-Saharan Africa are driven by causes that are largely preventable with early recognition and timely interventions. Easy-to-use, wearable, continuous physiological monitoring devices could increase access to care and improve outcomes for postpartum women in low-resource settings. In this application, I propose a series of related studies to evaluate the feasibility and implementation of postpartum physiologic monitoring to prevent severe maternal morbidity and mortality.
