IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intellectual disabilities are group of debilitating conditions causing life-long cognitive and behavioral defects that often remain undiagnosed and untreated. Advances in genetic studies have uncovered that defects in chromatin regulation during cerebral cortex development significantly contribute to the pathogenic mechanisms leading to intellectual disability. Our goal is to uncover the role of the chromatin modifier Enhancer of Zeste Homologue 1 (EZH1) in cortical neurogenesis that will ultimately provide new insights into the mechanisms and treatments for a novel intellectual disability syndrome caused by mutations in EZH1.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Currently the identity of dormant but autoagressive CD4+ cells that remain subdued by peripheral tolerance is unknown. In this proposal we will reveal clonal diversity and specificities of autoreactive CD4+ clones entrenched in CD4+repertoire of healthy mice. This research will help us to understand the basis of self-reactivity, revisit the relative significance of thymic and peripheral tolerance, and can lead to the development of new therapeutic protocols to treat autoimmune diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Nearly half of adults in the United States have hypertension. Abnormalities in vascular smooth muscle cell Ca2+ signaling mechanisms have been linked to increased arterial contraction and elevated blood pressure in hypertension. We have identified two new Ca2+-signaling pathways in vascular smooth muscle cells that exert opposing effects in the control of blood pressure. The proposed studies will investigate the individual components of these pathways under normal conditions and in hypertension. These studies will advance our understanding of blood pressure regulation by vascular smooth muscle cells and identify novel therapeutic targets for treating elevated blood pressure in hypertension.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Atherosclerosis, a disease in which lipids build up inside the arterial wall, can lead to serious problems, including heart attack, stroke or even death. Major complications occur when the atherosclerotic artery ruptures and the arteries cannot deliver enough oxygen-rich blood to the heart muscle or brain. The overall goals of this project are to better understand the mechanisms leading to lipid accumulation in the arterial wall and identify new therapeutic targets to mitigate atherosclerosis development and prevent plaque rupture.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research aims to determine the effects of a whole-diet intervention (the Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension (DASH) diet vs. a typical U.S. diet) and lower vs. higher sodium intake on the gut microbiota, the ensemble of microorganisms living in our intestinal tract, and their metabolites (i.e. metabolome) in a randomized controlled feeding trial of racially diverse adults with type 2 diabetes. The study will also assess whether the gut microbiome and metabolome modify, or mediate, the effects of dietary patterns and sodium on blood pressure, thusly helping to inform whether the microbiome can be leveraged for precision nutrition approaches to prevent cardiovascular disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: This proposal leverages the Drosophila model system to address the neural mechanisms underlying social interactions, from processing of cues emitted by a communication partner to generating complex behaviors in response to those cues. Impairments in processing sensory information or generating motor behaviors, particularly in the context of social interactions, underlie several human disorders including Parkinson's disease and Autism spectrum disorder. This proposal will uncover general principles of neural circuit function that will inform studies of sensorimotor integration in more complex systems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal will explore the synthesis and application of 1-sulfonylcyclopropanols as stable precursors of chiral cyclopropanone derivatives in the development of biologically relevant synthetic methods, such as rearrangements initiated by the addition of nucleophiles, transition metal-catalyzed C– C activation reactions and radical ring-opening and deconstruction strategies. Moreover, extension of this approach to 1-sulfonylcyclopropylamines and hydrazines as precursors of cyclopropanimines and hydrazones, respectively, is proposed and will allow novel access to chiral amine-containing scaffolds as well as strained chiral carbene equivalents. The preliminary data presented demonstrates that the substrates studied are both more stable yet more reactive than existing cyclopropanone precursors, which have led to the discovery of unprecedented reactivity; this work will lead to novel key synthetic disconnections available for chemists to use in the production of pharmaceuticals and other biologically relevant organic compounds, and in the long-term, to the establishment of cyclopropanone as versatile high-energy intermediate applicable to bio-imaging via ‘click chemistry’.

PROJECT_TITLE: Unlocking Access to Cyclopropanones as Divergent Reactive Intermediates in Synthesis

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: More than 750,000 individuals in the U.S. have a stroke each year, and as many as 94% of stroke survivors exhibit reduced use of one arm, with adverse consequences for disability, caregiver burden, and quality of life. Approximately 40%-80% of individuals who fail to use the affected arm in daily life possess adequate sensorimotor capacity to do so. The disparity between actual arm use and capacity remains a perplexing and urgent problem in neuro-rehabilitation. The proposed research will determine the underlying behavioral and neuroanatomic substrates of arm use/capacity disparity (UCD) and will validate a novel virtual reality assessment tool for detection of UCD. The investigations are designed to serve as a well-planned stage in the translational pipeline and will thus provide a critical bridge to developing a large-scale randomized control trial in at-risk individuals using a targeted treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Relevance  Using new multiscale biomolecular modeling and simulation methods that can yield mechanistic insights, Schlick's multidisciplinary team will address fundamental challenges in biology in relation to human disease: genome reorganization in cancer processes and RNA co-transcriptional folding in viral mechanisms. A linking of the many relevant biological scales and heterogeneous features of each is essential for understanding the complex biological activities of these macromolecules in the cellular environment and how they aﬀect gene expression, cancer progression, and viral infection. Such an improved understanding of the organization and transition mechanisms associated with the genetic material and its RNA cousin, together with establishment of systematic methods for their study, has direct medical ramiﬁcations by suggesting speciﬁc molecular design and targeted therapies for the treatment of genetic syndromes, degenerative diseases, cancers associated with chromosomal or epigenetic abnormalities, and viral infections like Covid-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Reversible protein phosphorylation established by a ‘tug of war’ between kinases and phosphatases controls most cellular processes and is often deregulated in human diseases. The long-term goal of our research program is to uncover the mechanisms that coordinate and integrate phosphatases and kinases and their shared substrates in signaling networks. This knowledge will help us understand how disruption of the phosphorylation balance contributes to disease and identify new drug targets and points of therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Title: Development of personalized healthy food incentives to improve diet and cardiovascular risk PROJECT NARRATIVE Diet has emerged as the leading risk factor for cardiovascular diseases responsible for substantial morbidity and mortality among US adults. Despite the enormous human toll and fiscal burden of diet-related chronic disease, population interventions have insufficiently addressed the complex determinants of this behavioral risk factor. The proposed research strives to improve public health by applying advancements in machine learning and qualitative research to better understand drivers of dietary decisions and using that insight to refine and test an automated personalized healthy food incentive platform to improve healthy food purchases, diet quality, and cardiovascular risk factors.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE  Building on the strong training track records of and successful collaborations between UNC-Chapel Hill, the Malawi College of Medicine, the Malawi Ministry of Health, and many other partners, we will accelerate mental health research capacity across the lifespan in Malawi by employing a model that emphasizes three complementary dimensions: depth (in-depth investment to create a core of skilled researchers and thought leaders), breadth (engagement of a wide range of stakeholders in mental health research), and reach (building links between research, policy, and practice to maximize impact of research). The Malawian Program for Mental Health Research Training (WARMHEART) will have a tremendous impact on mental health research in Malawi, creating an expert pool of young mental health researchers trained as leaders and able to collaborate with other disciplines and policymakers to address the role of psychiatric illness across the lifespan.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Premature babies born less than 3.3lbs are not able to gain weight after birth. Current nutritional strategies fail to meet the needs of premature babies leading to malnutrition, growth failure, and short- and long-term health deficits. This study will identify fundamental new associations between fat absorption, gut bacteria, and bile acids relative to neonatal morbidities and growth failure.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract (CAKUT) are the most common cause of chronic kidney disease in the first three decades of life. However, therapeutic interventions remain limited, and many children progress to end-stage renal disease. Recent studies have revealed over 40 novel monogenic causes of human CAKUT, the majority of which coalesce into pathways that regulate nephrogenesis. Monogenic causes of lower urinary tract disease are largely unknown. The aim of this career development grant is to discover novel monogenic causes of bladder dysfunction and to explore the molecular mechanisms by which mutations in these genes cause human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The only approved molecular targeting agent in the treatment of head and neck cancer (HNC) is cetuximab, an antibody directed against the EGFR. The vast majority of patients are either intrinsically resistant or acquire resistance to this promising agent. We have identified the receptor tyrosine kinase AXL mediates resistance through the c-Abl kinase and together function as a major driver of resistance. We will investigate how AXL and c-Abl mediates resistance, whether c-Abl targeting can re-sensitize tumors to cetuximab in a clinical trial and if AXL and c-Abl association can serve as a biomarker to predict cetuximab resistance in HNC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Lymphedema is the leading cause of morbidity and mortality in the USA; however, clinical therapies aiming to grow lymphatic vessels in the body are currently lacking. Recently, we developed innovative technologies for directly reprogramming somatic cells toward lymphatic endothelial cells (rLECs), bypassing a stem cell stage. In this proposal, we will develop clinically compatible ETV2 vector and rLECs, and determine the therapeutic effects of direct delivery of ETV2 gene aor transplantion of rLECs on lymphedema animal models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project represents an important step towards understanding how nicotine and tobacco products (NTPs) and cannabis differentially influence emerging adult brain development when used together versus separately. Advanced multimodal neuroimaging techniques, cognitive assessment, and bioassays of circulating blood endocannabinoids will prospectively identify neural, cognitive, and stress and reward system alterations among young adults that play a role in the development of substance use disorders and psychopathology into adulthood. Elucidating the neurobiological consequences of emerging adult cannabis and NTP use will help inform the regulation of cannabis and NTP products and the development of novel neuroscience-informed prevention and intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIV OF N.J.
PHR: NARRATIVE We will ascertain and genotype large cohort of Pakistani individuals with (n=10,000) and without (n=2,000) Bipolar Disorder (BPD). Added to Pakistani samples we are already collecting for the GEN-SCRIP project, a total of 10,000 BPD cases and 12,000 controls will be included in genome-wide association studies and these data will be contributed to the Psychiatric Genomics Consortium (PGC) and to the Database of Genotypes and Phenotypes (dbGaP). In Pakistan, consanguineous marriages are common and as a result we will be able to examine recessively inherited variants, in addition to additive model of inheritance.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: This competing renewal resubmission for continued NIH support of the Columbia University Graduate Training Program in Microbiology and Immunology is relevant to the public health mission of NIAID in its support of research into microbial systems and immune responses that are mounted to counter host perturbations including infection, cancer, and transplantation. Our predoctoral trainees receive a unique opportunity to obtain individualized training within a broad yet cohesive program of scientific inquiry into the immune system, host response to infection, pathogen biology, systems approaches to microbiology and immunology, cancer immunology, human immunology, and processes of microbial and immune cell replication. Our PhD program is designed to provide trainees with the skills and knowledge needed to become future innovators in microbiology and immunology and to contribute to the NIH mission to improve human health through scientific research.

PHR: Project Narrative Synaptic zinc is a powerful neuromodulatory neurotransmitter. Since disruptions of synaptic zinc signaling lead to a range of sensory and behavioral deficits and mutations in zinc transport proteins are linked with schizophrenia and autism, we seek to uncover mechanisms by which synaptic zinc shapes neuronal processing.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The role of the rich vestibular efferent innervation, which provides feedback inputs from the brain stem to the vestibular peripheral sensory epithelia is not known. The present proposal uses new methods to investigate changes in afferent response properties mediated by the cholinergic and GABAergic inputs at the cellular, systemic and behavioral levels. Results will provide a better understanding of the function of the efferent vestibular system and the basis for new pharmacological approaches for improving compensation in patients with vestibular dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  This fellowship application proposes training and research to understand how people form impressions of one another when they interact through text or video, in behavior and in the brain. These processes pose critical difficulties for a range of psychiatric illnesses, such as autism spectrum disorder, schizophrenia, and depression. Understanding the cognitive and neural mechanisms in healthy individuals will provide the applicant with important tools and background for future studies in psychiatric populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Aberrant glycosylation is a hallmark of cancer and contributes to the ability of transformed cells to escape immune surveillance and proliferate uncontrollably. However, mechanisms underlying these processes are not well understood, in part because glycosylation is exceptionally difficult to study. To bridge this disparity, we strive to understand how glycosylation contributes to downregulation of immune signaling, how altered glycans vary spatially within and around tumors, and how data processing can be streamlined in glycoproteomic experiments. .

PHR: Project Narrative In proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) of the human brain, signals arise both upfield (UF) and downfield (DF) from the water resonance and while UF MRS have been extensively studied in humans over the last 30 years, there have been very few DF studies and all of them used single voxel localization. The proposed career development activities will establish a smooth transition to an independent scientific career in biomedical imaging and bioengineering including the research project for development of novel MR spectroscopic imaging (MRSI) techniques and clinical applications. Brain metabolism in DF will be assessed in a cohort of healthy subjects to provide a normative database and brain tumor patients to predict tumor recurrence versus radiation necrosis using multimodal metabolic imaging approach (MRSI and chemical exchange saturation transfer, CEST), and modern statistical techniques in a combined software framework for the ultimate translation into clinical practice as well as identification of biomarkers for personalized evaluation of patients for improved diagnosis and treatment monitoring (precision medicine).

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF BIOMEDICAL IMAGING AND BIOENGINEERING
PHR: Project Narrative RNA-targeting gene therapies that precise tune gene expression at the transcript level can address the shortfalls and challenges of current gene therapies, but the large size and microbially-derived nature of existing programmable RNA-targeting systems preclude broad clinical utility. Constructed from human protein parts, CIRTS (CRISPR/Cas-inspired RNA targeting system) offers a therapeutically actionable solution to these hurdles. Here, we will use biochemical engineering approaches to generate highly efficient RNA-targeting CIRTS activators and degraders and prioritize those with optimized performance parameters using a combination of disease-relevant target gene assays and in vivo immunogenicity studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Relevance Statement Leptin is unquestionably a major driver of systemic metabolic well-being. However, the use of recombinant leptin as a therapeutic agent is extremely limited. This is due to widespread leptin resistance, observed even after moderate increases in leptin. We determined that reducing leptin concentrations in circulation results in a dramatic improvement in leptin sensitivity, which leads to an immediate increase in insulin sensitivity. The studies we propose here are aimed to a) better understand the mechanistic aspects of this leptin sensitization; b) determine which anti-diabetic pharmacological treatment regimens rely on a leptin-lowering effect to achieve their established action, and c) gain a better understanding of the regulation of leptin production at the level of different fat-pads. As such, the proposed studies are of immediate relevance for both clinical applications of neutralizing leptin antibody preparations, as well as the basic understanding of leptin production and action.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  Heart failure is associated with unacceptably high morbidity and mortality worldwide despite currently available medical and device therapies, highlighting the need for deep mechanistic research in this field. Dead box helicase (Ddx) proteins play important roles in RNA splicing and processing. A key member of this protein family, Ddx5 has not been studied in the heart, and in this proposal, we will elucidate its role in cardiac function and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Autophagy is a lysosomal degradation pathway that is essential for neuronal homeostasis and survival. Deficits in autophagy lead to neurodevelopmental abnormalities and neurodegeneration in mammals, but little is known about the functions and regulation of autophagy that provide neuroprotection. This proposal will determine the roles and regulation of neuronal autophagy that facilitate neuronal function and survival, and inform strategies to therapeutically modulate autophagy for beneficial outcomes in disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative  We propose to develop an intelligent-augmented risk assessment system for breast cancer management based on multimodality image and clinical information with deep learning and data mining techniques. Using mammographic or breast ultrasound BI-RADS reporting signatures and radiomics features, a more precise and clinically relevant predictive model will be developed to target well-characterized and defined specific biopsy patient subgroups rather than a broad heterogeneous biopsy group. The more reliable stratification of BI-RADS subtypes for breast cancer risk assessment will reduce the number of unnecessary breast biopsies and save billions of dollars in medical costs annually.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE The mammalian brain and spinal cord consist not only of neurons, but additional specialized cell types called oligodendrocytes and astrocytes. These cells play critical roles in regulating neurological function and there is strong evidence that their loss or dysfunction contribute to an increasing list of diseases including multiple sclerosis, pediatric leukodystrophies, and Alzheimer’s disease. The goal of this proposal is to leverage the innovative approaches developed in our lab to define the mechanisms that regulate oligodendrocyte and astrocyte function and discover new therapeutic approaches to restore neurological deficits in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: When faced with a crisis, some people but not others transition from thinking about suicide to acting on these thoughts. This project will use a formal theoretical framework combined with electroencephalography to test the hypothesis that individuals at risk for suicide become cognitively overwhelmed under challenging life circumstances and make poor choices as a result. The anticipated impact of this proposal includes the identification of more precise targets for cognitive clinical interventions.

Therefore, this proposed research is relevant to the NIH mission to reduce the burden of neurological injury and promote functional recovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  This proposal studies Cryptococcus neoformans, a leading cause of fungal infections acquired by inha- lation and responsible for hundreds of thousands of deaths yearly, towards which there is no adequate treatment. Many factors contribute to a high medical burden, but one of them is an incomplete understanding of its intracel- lular pathogenesis. By understanding the mechanisms used by this fungus to cause disease we may be able to develop new more effective treatments, making this research relevant to NIH’s public health mission and a spe- cific priority for various institutes such as NHLBI or NIAID. Lastly, this work will also contribute to basic science knowledge, informing studies of other pathogenic microbes and areas of cell biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the interaction of biological and behavioral risk factors for HIV/STI transmission caused by methamphetamine use is imperative for effective HIV/STI interventions. This innovative project will evaluate the joint effects of methamphetamine use, HIV, sexual risk behavior, and rectal GC/CT on systemic and rectal inflammation – a key step in designing potent prevention interventions. Findings from this project will be important toward the development of effective interventions that combine methamphetamine reduction with STI screening and HIV prevention.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Group B Streptococcus (GBS) causes serious infections during and shortly after pregnancy, which endanger mothers, fetuses, and newborns. GBS is exceptional in its ability to persist and grow in the pregnant uterus, and existing evidence suggests that one reason for this is that GBS can suppress and evade components of the gestational innate immune system, which typically serve to clear bacterial invaders while supporting healthy fetal development. In this project, our collaborative group will use novel genetic tools to examine how GBS affects key immune cells—called macrophages—in the placenta. We are searching for new targets on the surface of GBS cells that participate directly in subverting immune defenses, and which could pave the way for new preventative or therapeutic strategies to protect pregnant women and their newborns from these dangerous bacteria.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Aggregating across biological datasets reveals a patchwork of different technologies and conditions of interest; however, several holes exist in this patchwork, hindering our ability to entirely utilize biological datasets that currently exist. We propose to use a special class of methods, called domain adaptation methods, that can leverage the local patterns in the patchwork to build models that can either work around the missing pieces or fill them in. To show the strength and flexibility of these approaches, we apply our methods to three biomedical application areas: 1) inferring missing cell-type-specific treatment responses in Rheumatoid Arthritis; 2) predicting the tissue-of-origin of cell-free DNA (cfDNA) from a model trained on a different but complementary data type to cfDNA; 3) predicting gene expression patterns in the bone marrow from cfDNA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Human cytomegalovirus infects the majority of the American people and although it typically establishes a quiescent infection with little to no disease in most individuals, the virus is responsible for a variety of devastating sequelae in immunocompromised adults and in developing babies. Therefore, identifying the viral properties essential for replication, spread and horizontal transmission are important areas of medical science. Our studies aim to use novel cellular models to investigate the molecular mechanisms by which cytomegalovirus replicates in the salivary gland where it then gains access to fluids centrally important for horizontal transmission.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Splicing is the process by which introns are removed from precursor mRNA to generate productive transcripts but, if performed incorrectly, can lead to aberrant transcripts and many human diseases. The goal of this project is to understand how RNA structure influences recognition of regulatory elements. Ultimately this research strives to identify elements within precursor mRNAs that regulate splicing and develop tools that can modulate splicing in a predictable manner, revealing more about the role of RNA splicing in disease and leading to therapeutics for splicing-related disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Project Narrative  This project seeks to extend the investigator’s successful preliminary work that developed a Continuing Care mobile application (app) for probationers and parolees with substance use disorders (SUDs) who are at elevated risk of adverse health consequences such as relapse, re-arrest, and incarceration. The proposed project will enhance and finalize app development and evaluate its effectiveness in a randomized controlled trial. The project has high public health significance due to its potential to provide an accessible, easy to use recovery support tool for individuals on probation or parole that could improve their SUD treatment outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: SARS-CoV-2, MERS-CoV and HCoV-OC43 represent three different betacoronavirus subgenera and cause a wide spectrum of disease from asymptomatic to upper respiratory to lethal pneumonia. The proposed study of betacoronavirus interactions with double-stranded RNA induced antiviral pathways and the PKR-like ER kinase (PERK) pathway will reveal a more comprehensive picture of virus-host interactions and how they are similar or different among the betacoronaviruses from different subgenera. This information will aid in developing antiviral strategies to target both host pathways and viral proteins, to combat current coronaviruses and to prepare for future coronavirus spillovers into humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Diabetes Endothelial Keratoplasty Study (DEKS): Impact of Diabetes on Corneal Transplant Success and Endothelial Cell Loss As individuals with diabetes comprise an increasing proportion of the donor cornea pool as well as the recipients of the donor tissue, questions continue to arise regarding the suitability of tissue from donors with diabetes for corneal transplantation, a major health concern considering nearly 50,000 tissues were distributed by United States eye banks and used for corneal transplants by United States surgeons in 2018. The DEKS will conduct a large, prospective, multi-center, masked clinical trial assigning corneas from donors with or without well characterized diabetes status to patients undergoing corneal transplantation, also characterized by diabetes status. The study will examine transplant success and the loss of endothelial cells after surgery, definitively determine the impact of donor and recipient diabetes on these outcomes, and thus help guide the eye banking and surgical community as to the safety and effectiveness of transplanting donor corneas from individuals with diabetes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH While there is general agreement that T effector cells of the adaptive immune system are important in controlling Alzheimer disease Aβ plaque removal, the role of T regulatory cells in controlling Aβ pathology is actively debated. We have found that T regulatory cells rely on mitochondria for energy while T effector cells utilize glycolysis, and that underlying mitochondrial defects predispose to Alzheimer disease and also regulate T regulatory cell capacity to modulate T effector cell antigen rejection. By combining our unique collection of mouse mitochondrial DNA variants with the classical APPswe predisposing AD mutant gene from the Tg2576 mouse, we propose to demonstrate the importance of mitochondrial variation in predisposition to Alzheimer disease and also to demonstrate how mitochondrial variation can modulate T regulatory cell regulation of T effector antigen rejection thus accounting for the variable results observed for T regulatory cells in Alzheimer disease mouse models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative Tuberculosis is a major global health burden, killing more than 1.5 million people every year, despite the availability of therapy. Finding more effective therapeutic strategies could transform the epidemic, but that will require a better understanding of the fundamental biology of bacterial growth, metabolism and interaction with the host of the causative agent – Mycobacterium tuberculosis (Mtb). This proposal aims to make advances toward this goal, utilizing innovative techniques to understand therapeutically relevant pathways in Mtb.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Osteoporosis and osteoporotic fractures continue to remain a clinical challenge that disproportionately affect females. Loss of ovarian function due to pre-mature ovarian failure or menopause are key underlying factors in the development of osteoporosis in women. Alternatives to traditional hormone therapy (estrogen alone or with progesterone) that can deliver hormones while reducing/eliminating safety risks such as cardiovascular disease or cancer would provide an alternative to existing pharmacological treatments including pharmacological hormone therapy and the bisphosphonates. We will assess the ability of a biomimetic ovarian cell encapsulation system developed by our team to regulate female endocrine hormone pathways in a manner that is safer and more effective at achieving bone health than pharmacological agents in a rat ovariectomy model. These studies will also allow determination of how the female endocrine regulatory pathways are impacted by the cell encapsulation strategy to yield these outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE The impact of cannabis use (CU) on public health has become an increasingly pressing concern, particularly among emerging adults, who evidence tremendous plasticity in neurophysiological functioning but are at increased risk for both elevated rates of CU and trauma exposure. Little is known about how acute posttraumatic stress symptoms, as well as alterations in fear response and physiology, impact cannabis use behavior, especially during the days and weeks immediately following trauma exposure. The present investigation examines in vivo momentary and biological processes implicated in the development of negative outcomes of trauma including cannabis misuse and posttraumatic stress disorder among emerging adults during the acute posttrauma period.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The role of lipid homeostasis in aging and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is poorly understood, which is notable because lipid droplets (LDs) were included in the very first histological descriptions of brain tissue from patients with AD. We will produce the first high molecular specificity and high spatial resolution isomer-resolved lipidomic survey of brain regions and cell types involved in LD dysregulation as it relates to normal aging and AD. Using adaptive image fusion and machine learning methods, we will produce dense lipid fingerprints with regional and cell type specificity that will be incorporated into existing atlases and will be available to the community as a resource.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative This study will use novel methods and extensive data sources to: 1) Examine the relationship between regional exposure to structural racism (defined as: historic redlining) and present-day social risk factors, human capital, and health care resources; 2) examine the direct and indirect effects of regional exposure to structural racism on health outcomes via social risk, human capital, and healthcare resources; 3) assess policy levers of federal, state, and local governments that can be used to reduce area vulnerabilities to historic structural racism, and that can reduce present-day racial/ethnic disparity gaps in health outcomes; and 4) Engage a diverse set of key stakeholders to identify and prioritize strategies for mitigating social risk, building human capital, and improving health care resources and outcomes for regions exposed to structural racism through historical redlining.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: Individuals with a history of adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) are more likely to smoke cigarettes than those without, but little is known about the factors that account for this increased risk. This research will examine reward-related brain function and reactions to initial nicotine exposure to help explain why ACEs lead to increased risk for smoking. This research will also examine whether these processes differ between men and women.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Surging evidences support the notion that hypoperfusion is an early symptom in Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD). However, the mechanism underlying hypoperfusion in ADRD remains to be determined. This project will use cutting-edge physiology imaging techniques, behavior-test methods, and immunohistochemistry to systematically investigate the pathophysiological mechanism of hypoperfusion in two representative mouse models of ADRD with both cross-sectional and longitudinal settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE This study will determine neuronal vulnerability to lipid droplets (LD) and cholesterol, and the underlying molecular changes associated with Alzheimer's disease (AD) risk alleles. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Invasive fungal infections are a global health problem. We have found that small soluble fungal ligands that are immunosilent in the periphery, become potent immunogens once they reach the draining lymph node (dLN) and outcompete the activity of classical adjuvants. Here, we hypothesize that the anatomical restriction to the dLN of the initial innate response elicited by soluble fungal ligands instructs a potent adaptive immune response. Also, that this response can be leveraged to protect against invasive fungal infections and anticipate that these studies will be foundational for developing novel and effective therapeutic interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The basolateral amygdala (BLA) is a neural hub that receives diverse inputs that drive its ability to control fear and anxiety-related behaviors. A lack of understanding of how neuromodulatory signaling molecules control BLA function has hindered the development of effective therapeutic strategies. Here, we will use a battery of novel optical techniques to probe how specific G protein-coupled receptors modulate cortical inputs to the BLA and control fear and anxiety-related behaviors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project narrative We propose new multimodal imaging technologies based on a visible-light optical coherence tomography (VIS- OCT) platform to quantitatively image the fundus autofluorescence emitted by lipofuscin in the retinal pigment epithelium, and the spectral reflectance of the retinal nerve fiber layer. These novel imaging technologies will add a significant clinical tool for diagnosis, staging, and follow-up of retinal degenerative disorders and glaucoma, and will have a great impact on patient care and clinical trials for potential treatments.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative Genes within humans and other mammals are marked with chemical tags that direct normal embryonic development. Assisted reproduction technologies that help infertile couples conceive may disrupted these chemical tags in resulting embryos. This research proposal will identify chemical signatures that discriminate embryos with and without errors and noninvasive approaches to distinguish between these embryos.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Lowering triglycerides (TGs) for preventing coronary heart disease is a rapidly growing area of research and several drugs that target particular TG genes are in development. However, other than lowering TGs, we don’t know what the long-term beneficial and harmful effects of these drugs will be. We propose to define the pleiotropy of new TG-lowering drugs and to identify new drugs in large electronic health records (EHRs) using genetic approaches.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Chiral molecules have impacted human health in the form of chemical tools to study biological systems and pharmaceutical drugs to treat disease (for example many top selling drugs in the US are chiral and are marketed as enantiopure chemical entities). Although several environmentally friendly photochemical methods exist for the stereoselective synthesis of molecules, many chiral structures still present unique challenges in synthesis. We believe there is great potential for discovering conceptually novel photochemical catalytic reactions for the stereoselective synthesis of medicinally valuable chiral molecules, and the development of these reactions is the focus of this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Neurotransmitter receptors form higher-order clusters at synapses to enable signal transmission, and the disfunction of which leads to neurological diseases such as hyperekplexia, chronical neurological pain and reduction in cognitive abilities. Despite their importance, the physical organization, the functional significance, and whether clustering of receptors provides additional mechanism of functional regulation is not known. We will use the state-of-the-art methods and develop novel technologies to characterize receptor assemblies, first using glycine receptor-gephyrin clusters as an example, and open new research area in other assemblies ubiquitously found in signal transmission.

PROJECT_TITLE: Understanding higher-order glycine receptor assemblies in neurotransmission

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In order to address problems associated with reduced efficacy of the current BCG vaccine and the spread of tuberculosis (TB), we have generated newer strains of BCG engineered to express molecules that promote robust anti-bacterial responses. Based on our preliminary studies, we hypothesize that our BCG strains promote long-term functional changes in specific immune cells through a newly discovered phenomenon called “trained immunity”. In order to translate these findings into potential clinical benefits, we propose to first examine the efficacy of these strains in models of TB established in non-human primates and mice, and to examine myeloid cells derived from them, and from human peripheral blood treated with these BCG strains, for established markers of trained immunity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Wilms tumor 1 (Wt1) mutations result in severe defects in the developing kidney and predispose to Wilms tumor, demonstrating a link between the dysregulation of normal development and tumorigenesis. While reciprocal signaling interactions are known to play critical roles in normal kidney development, such cell-cell communication has been largely unexplored in the development of Wilms tumor. The goal of this application to determine how loss of Wt1 in the nephron progenitor lineage non-autonomously affects the developing stroma to identify mechanisms in which NPC signaling regulates the stroma in normal development and uncover a novel role for Wt1 mutations in disrupting cell lineage crosstalk in the embryonic microenvironment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Neurodegenerative disease incidence is increasing as our population ages, yet we lack effective treatments for these diseases. While the social behavior changes that occur across many dementias, particularly frontotemporal dementia (FTD), account for a tremendous portion of disease burden, these behavioral sequelae have been understudied as a mechanistic entity or therapeutic target. The proposed project will develop a novel animal model to examine the genetic, molecular, and neural circuit factors that underlie social attachment deficits in FTD and other neurodegenerative diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Brain Computer Interfaces (BCIs) are innovative and cutting-edge technologies that measure and interpret brain signals to interface with a device that allows users to perform a task, and while BCIs hold great promise in their transformative potential for patients with neurologic disability, there are critical unaddressed ethical challenges that have the potential to limit their adaptation. This project will use innovative approaches including structured vignettes, video-supported interviews, and deliberative democracy to qualitatively evaluate end user perspectives about the benefits, risks, and ethical challenges of BCIs. Our transdisciplinary research team and the diverse input from patients with neurologic disability and their family/caregivers, clinicians who care for patients with acute neurologic injury, and BCI researchers and engineers will inform future decisions and policies about ethical and equitable adaptation of BRAIN-funded BCI technology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Hi-C is a popular technology to map how DNA folds and affects gene expression and diseases in the nucleus. However, high resolution Hi-C analysis requires ultra-deep sequencing, which is a major financial burden and often not feasible for low-input or single cell samples. This project will use deep- learning techniques to reduce such burden by more than 10-fold, and also enables high-resolution analysis with single cell Hi-C data.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The KCNH2 gene encodes the Kv11.1 membrane protein that transports potassium ions out of cardiac muscle cells to maintain normal heart rhythm and dysfunction of the Kv11.1 protein causes long QT syndrome, a cardiac disorder characterized by severe arrhythmias and sudden cardiac death. The goal of present proposal is to study post-transcriptional regulation of Kv11.1 protein expression and to investigate a novel mechanism of drug-induced long QT syndrome. Elucidating these mechanisms is important for understanding of Kv11.1 protein expression in normal and disease conditions.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dilation & curettage (D&C) is one of the most common surgical procedures performed on women throughout the World, with resulting intrauterine fibrosis developing in ~40% of women who undergo D&C in the postpartum (6wk period after birth), but is very rare after D&C in nonpregnant women (<1%). While stem/progenitor cells are crucial for endometrial repair, the role of these cells and underlying molecular mechanisms in this susceptibility of the endometrium to fibrosis and abnormal repair are unknown. This work will have an important impact on the reproductive field by revealing mechanisms underlying abnormal uterine repair, and on the medical field at large by providing insights into the body’s physiological anti-fibrotic wound healing mechanisms, leading to a deeper understanding of the pathogenesis of fatal idiopathic fibrotic diseases in other organs.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE East Africa is one of the fastest growing regions of the world, with an increasing burden of non-communicable diseases, including cancer. Cancer research in the region is nascent; however, the rising disease burden urgently demands development of research skills and capacity to establish context-specific cancer control plans. The overarching goal of our proposed Cancer Research Training Program in Tanzania (CRTP-TZ) is to train and mentor a cadre of investigators in East Africa who are capable of conceptualizing, achieving funding for, implementing, analyzing, and publishing original research focused on cancer.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Project Narrative. Alcoholic cardiomyopathy (AC) can result from chronic alcohol use; this process progressively damages the heart and decreases the heart’s function. In this study, we aim to define part of the molecular phenomenon occurring in AC using genetically altered mice, cells, and a novel drug that inhibits the action of key components in the underlying molecular process. This study may open new therapeutic options for those suffering from AC.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Summary The research goal of this application is to use health IT to reduce preventable readmissions for heart failure (HF) among patients with low health literacy, through a text-based messaging application. We will conduct qualitative work to gain insights into how to adapt an extant text messaging intervention to improve its use among patients with low health literacy, conduct usability testing and iterative revision of the application, and conduct a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) to evaluate the acceptability, feasibility, and preliminary efficacy of using behavioral interventions to increase the application use for patients with heart failure post- discharge. The training from this mentored career development award will provide skills in behavioral science, implementation science, health literacy, and RCT design and conduct, to provide the foundation for my career as an independent clinician investigator.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Male infertility is a devastating problem that impacts 7% of all men and has been shown to significantly impact somatic health, particularly risk for both individual and familial cancer. Despite this association, the mechanism driving it remains unknown. We seek to perform a study examining complex pedigree data to assess how infertility can impact familial cancer risk among high risk pedigrees and then use high depth and coverage DNA sequencing to determine if elevated de novo mutation rates in both the germline and somatic tissue are what drive the association between male infertility and poor somatic health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pacemaker cells are responsible for faithfully initiating every heartbeat, yet the mechanisms responsible for their formation and maintenance are not well-understood. Direct reprogramming of fibroblasts into functional cardiomyocytes, including pacemaker cells, has recently emerged as a viable approach for studying lineage specification, but many details of the process remain poorly characterized. Using an innovative and multi- disciplinary approach, we propose to examine pacemaker reprogramming mechanisms to better understand pacemaker formation and to eventually develop cellular replacement strategies for patients with sinus node dysfunction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual minority adolescents (SMA; ages 13-17) are more likely to experience intimate partner violence (IPV) than their heterosexual peers. However, research on the relationship between IPV and individuals who identify as a sexual minority has largely focused on adults. The overarching goal of this study is to explore the prospective relationship among IPV experiences, risk and resilience factors, and other behavioral health outcomes in a diverse cohort of SMA.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Digital mental health interventions are a cost-effective and efficient approach to expanding the accessibility and impact of psychological treatments; however, little guidance exists for selecting the most effective program for a given individual. In the proposed study, we will use machine learning to create decision rules for selecting the digital program that is most likely to be the optimal intervention for each user. These treatment recommendations can be implemented in the context of large healthcare delivery systems to improve the delivery of digital mental health interventions at scale.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Genetic evidence implicates dysregulation of lipid metabolism and immune function in the neurodegenerative pathogenesis of Alzheimer's disease (AD), what is less clear is how these different factors combine to affect brain aging and AD risk. In this project we will combine highly validated state-of-the-art lipidomic profiling with genetics and brain imaging data to identify both peripheral and central lipid metabolic pathways contributing to AD risk and resilience allowing for identification of new biomarkers to identify those at high risk of developing AD as well as new therapeutic targets for the prevention and treatment of AD.

PHR: Project Narrative The Preventing infant infections by Implementation Science in Malawi (PRI3SM) project will conduct 3 related studies addressing the main reasons for pediatric HIV infections in Malawi, supported by administrative, implementation science and data science and analytical cores. Project 1 and Project 2 focus on preventing new infections in Mothers during pregnancy and breastfeeding and Project 3 focuses on promptly testing infants born to mothers with potential higher risk to transmit based on missing key services. PRI3SM has potential to reduce pediatric infection in Malawi and may provide a successful model for other countries to follow.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Trypanosoma cruzi is an obligate intracellular parasite of the kinetoplastid family that infects upwards of 10 million people in the Americas with approximately 30% developing life-threatening clinical disease. As part of its basic nutrient acquisition strategy, T. cruzi directly ingests extracellular material via an enigmatic endocytic structure known as the cytostome/cytopharynx complex (SPC) and this study seeks to characterize the molecular machinery responsible for constructing, powering and regulating this endocytic organelle. Our work seeks to address a longstanding question regarding the primary role of the SPC in the parasite life cycle as it serves as one of the major points of contact in the host-pathogen interface during infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This research proposal seeks to augment immune therapy responses in high-risk neuroblastoma, an aggressive pediatric solid tumor, by validating tumor cell lineage state as an indicator of immunogenicity and by developing strategies to relieve the epigenetic repression of tumor cell-intrinsic immune response genes. These studies have the potential to enable the stratification of patients who are most likely to benefit from immune therapy and to stimulate the design of clinical trials involving combinations of epigenetic and immune-based therapies to target the specific immune evasion mechanisms utilized by neuroblastoma cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cocaine (COC) use disorder (CUD) remains a significant concern for which there is no FDA-approved medication treatment. Preclinical studies provide ample support for the potential clinical utility of stimulating the glucagon- like peptide 1 (GLP-1) receptor (GLP-1R) to treat CUD. The design of the current human clinical pharmacology study will accurately predict the potential clinical efficacy of a GLP-1R agonist for reducing COC use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glaucoma is a leading source of vision loss worldwide and is frequently associated with elevated intraocular pressure (IOP). This study aims to investigate the actin cytoskeleton and extracellular matrix of normal and glaucomatous trabecular meshwork cells at two dynamic cellular structures important for regulating IOP. Results may provide new information about how normal eyes regulate IOP, while providing new avenues to explore to develop novel therapies to reduce elevated pressure in glaucoma patients.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Long acting injectable Cabotegravir (CAB-LA) was recently approved for pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) among at those at higher risk of HIV acquisition including pregnant and breastfeeding women. However, questions remain on the safety of this drugs during pregnancy and breastfeeding population. In this project, we aim to compare the safety of CAB-LA and oral TDF/FTC with respect to adverse pregnancy outcomes and infant development both through a surveillance registry of PrEP users who become pregnant and through an in-depth safety cohort.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Gastrointestinal parasites are widely present in humans globally and may paradoxically drive both strong anti- parasite immune responses and prevent unwanted responses to self and environmental antigens through induction of tolerance mechanisms. We will use two parasitic infection models in mice that drive opposing Th1 or Th2 responses and ask how these anti-parasite T cell responses are generated by tracking parasite-specific T cells, and how they impact on responses to food antigens. These studies will provide novel and important insights into how parasites promote tolerogenic or pathogenic responses to gut antigens.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: This project seeks to connect cellular function to gene expression during the maturation of human stem cell- derived islet organoids (SC-islets), with the goal of building better human models of islet development and physiology and new transplantation therapeutics for type 1 diabetes. To do so, it will develop (1) soft, stretchable tissue-embedded sensor arrays to chronically trace how individual endocrine progenitors develop, mature and form coordinated 3D islet networks; (2) tissue clearing and spatial-omics methods to map hormones, biomarkers, gene expression, and infer cell identity from intact SC-islets; and (3) computational methods to integrate single- cell functional and transcriptional data. Ultimately, these technologies will allow us to address major challenges for generating of functionally mature SC-islets for biomedical research and human therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Glaucoma is the second leading cause of blindness in the US and worldwide, and the only available treatment is reduction of intraocular pressure. Papilledema is optic nerve swelling caused by increased intracranial pressure, which has the potential to cause significant vision loss. Based on our promising pilot studies, we will develop and refine USVE for assessing glaucoma and papilledema as they are both dependent on the biomechanics of ocular tissues, including the posterior sclera surrounding the optic nerve head and USVE may have the ability to stratify the risk of glaucomatous damage and the propensity toward the development of papilledema and vision loss.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE With improved HIV treatment outcomes for HIV-infected pregnant and breastfeeding women, an increasing proportion of new infant infections stem from incident maternal infections; in Malawi, one third of infant transmissions are due to HIV infections that are acquired during breastfeeding. Linking breastfeeding women to effective HIV prevention, specifically HIV pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP), is necessary to decrease postpartum HIV incidence, but PrEP uptake and persistent use has been limited by poor implementation of postpartum HIV testing and fragmented PrEP service delivery. In this project, we will evaluate an integrated postpartum prevention package intervention consisting of HIV testing, male partner engagement, integrated PrEP services, and community-based follow-up for defaulters, examining effects on PrEP uptake, persistence, and associated costs to inform HIV prevention programs and policies in sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: NARRATIVE Normal brain function depends on the orderly development of circuits in the cerebral cortex and on their intact function. Knowledge of the normal circuitry provides a foundation for understanding the causes of impaired brain function and developing corrective measures. Our studies of the normal circuitry between early visual cortical areas will provide greater insight into the causes and effects of central vision defects when these circuits are damaged by stroke or other neurological or developmental cause. In particular, our studies of feedback circuits between different visual cortical areas will help our understanding of how these pathways mediate the influence of stimulus context on neuronal responsivity, spatial integration, and changes in visual sensitivity associated with top-down attention. Moreover, understanding how these circuits operate in normal vision will provide a foundation for understanding the consequences of their dysfunction in neurological and psychiatric disorders, such as autism, schizophrenia and attention deficits disorders, which have been directly linked to abnormalities in inter-areal connectivity [e.g. Belmonte et al. J. Neurosci. (2004) 24:9228-9231; Lynall et al. J. Neurosci. (2010) 30:9477-9487].

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: At least more than one million individuals may have suffered a mild traumatic brain injuries (mTBIs) in the US in any single year, and the long term neurological consequences are devastating. Our proposal focuses on the molecular intersection of mild TBI with neuropathological signs of dementia. Given our expertise in the molecular pathways converging on the endoplasmic reticulum, we are optimally position to successfully complete the proposed work and identify novel therapeutic intervention strategies.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Globally, entrenched barriers to HIV testing for infants and young children exposed to HIV have left more than two-fifths of children living with HIV undiagnosed and one-half without access to life-saving antiretroviral therapy, perpetuating a widening treatment gap between adults and children living with HIV. To address this glaring gap, and optimize HIV treatment for the mothers of these infants and young children, we have developed a new and integrated differentiated service delivery model, coined PAC-Man, to bring a package of evidence-based elimination of mother-to-child transmission (EMTCT) of HIV services out of the clinic and into the community for mother-infant pairs at the highest risk for poor HIV outcomes. In this project, we will use established implementation science theories, strategies, and outcomes to integrate the PAC-Man model into routine HIV care settings in Malawi, and rigorously evaluate the model using a pragmatic, stepped-wedged trial design in hopes of demonstrating its impact for use in real-world EMTCT programs in sub-Saharan Africa.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Screening for the early detection of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma and its precursors requires tests which are sensitive, feasible, and acceptable to a wide population base while easily administered outside of high- volume referral centers. The OHSU Research Unit proposes two complementary approaches to screening, one using a novel extracellular vesicle-based assay that can be obtained rapidly and with very low blood volumes, and a second that modifies standard magnetic resonance imaging techniques to detect subtle evidence of focal fibroinflammatory changes in the pancreas, a common feature of pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia, using a quantitative technique called magnetic resonance fingerprinting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE. Leakage of the tricuspid valve, which is located between the right atrium and right ventricle, is extremely common and, if not treated, can significantly impact the health of patients. The current gold-standard for treatment is a surgical approach known as tricuspid annuloplasty, which unfortunately does not have high long-term success rates and fails in approximately one third of patients. This proposal is relevant to public health as we aim to better understand a new tricuspid valve disease mechanism, tricuspid valve maladaptation, that could be used as future therapeutic target toward improving the currently poor outcomes for patients with tricuspid valve regurgitation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative  Effective diagnosis and treatment of depression in people living with HIV (PWH) is a critical public health issue, and HIV infection and depression may act through common myeloid mechanisms to exacerbate behavioral and functional changes. Outlined in this K01 application is a multifaceted series of experiments designed to investigate the effects of in vivo and in vitro antidepressants on viral dynamics and inflammation in peripheral and CNS myeloid cells in multiple models (clinical cohorts of PWH and iPSC-derived mono and co-cultures). These studies will significantly advance our understanding of the antidepressant-mediated cellular mechanisms in HIV neuropathogenesis, guiding personalized medication in depressed PWH, and this opportunity will provide comprehensive training and a solid foundation on which to build a successful and independent research program.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Narrative This project seeks to understand how the activity of tandem pore (K2P) potassium channels is modulated within the cell. K2P channels have been implicated as possible targets for treatment of several diseases, including chronic pain, arrhythmia, and depression, though there are currently no medications that primarily target K2Ps. We aim to investigate the ways in which K2P channel activity is modulated, in the hope that these findings will uncover avenues to develop drugs that target this ion channel family.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Carotenoids such as lutein and zeaxanthin are probably the safest and most cost-effective nutrients available to prevent retinal disease such as age-related macular degeneration (AMD), but their incorporation into practice sometimes precedes basic and clinical support for their usage. The results of our studies will advance mechanistic knowledge of their physiological functions at a molecular level, which will enable basic studies that account for their roles in retinal neuroprotection, as well as clinical studies that will lead to rational, scientifically supported decisions about treatments to prevent visual loss throughout a person’s lifetime.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Majority of patients who are resuscitated from sudden cardiac arrest have poor neurological outcomes. Although virtually all comatose post-cardiac arrest patients are sedated after successful cardiopulmonary resuscitation, the effects of sedation on the brain function of post-arrest patients are unknown. This study will seek to elucidate the effects of post-cardiac arrest sedation on recovery of brain function using advanced electrophysiological and genetic tools in male and female mice subjected to experimental cardiac arrest.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposal aims to characterize gene-environment interactions (i.e., genetic effects modified by environment) underlying complex traits in humans. We will develop statistical tests to identify historical genetic responses to the Agricultural Revolution during human evolution, which will inform our understanding and study of the current epidemics of complex diseases because they are likely results of gene-lifestyle mismatches. We will develop computational tools and perform large-scale empirical analysis in large population cohorts to characterize gene-environment interactions, to prioritize actionable environmental exposures for clinical intervention, and to improve genetic prediction for precision medicine.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative People post-stroke retain the capacity to modify walking patterns explicitly using biofeedback and implicitly when encountering changes in the walking environment. This proposal will assess changes in muscle activation patterns associated with walking modifications driven explicitly vs. implicitly, to determine whether individuals generate different amounts of co-contraction during explicit vs. implicit walking modifications. Understanding how walking modifications driven explicitly vs. implicitly influence co-contraction will allow us to identify approaches that can more effectively restore muscle activation toward pre-stroke patterns, promoting mechanism-based recovery of walking function.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Liver transplantation is the standard treatment for end-stage liver disease; yet, many procured livers are discarded due to ischemia-reperfusion injury (IRI), perpetuating a vast donor shortage that increases waitlist times and patient mortality. This proposal seeks to utilize small RNA drugs to silence known mediators of IRI in liver grafts during the transplantation process. Findings from this study will inform the development of therapies that increase the number of viable liver grafts, saving the lives of thousands of liver disease patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative: The proposed research aims to develop and translate a novel 3D prompt gamma imaging system for in-vivo dose verification of proton radiotherapy. This technique would allow us to image the actual in-vivo proton beam range and dose distribution delivered during treatment. Such capabilities would allow for monitoring of the accuracy of treatment delivery (via measured changes to the delivered beam range/dose) on a daily basis, providing a means to ensure proper dose delivery is maintained over the course of treatment, thus minimizing the negative effects that current range uncertainties have on treatment delivery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL EYE INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Cataracts remain as the leading cause of blindness in the world. Lens transparency relies on a bulk of elongated and interlocked fiber cells, coupled into a syncytial unit by gap junctions. This project will elucidate the gap knowledge about the mechanistic regulation of fiber cell interlocking structures including protrusions and ball-and-sockets and lens calcium homeostasis. This project will further identify novel genetic variances that are essential for the formation and maintenance of lens transparency throughout lifetime.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Cytokinesis, the physical division of one cell into two daughter cells, is a highly conserved process central to development and tissue maintenance. Cytokinesis is tightly regulated so that it occurs only after chromosome replication and segregation to prevent catastrophic genomic instability and cell death. The goal of the Gould lab is to advance understanding of how the molecules essential for successful cytokinesis are assembled into an actin- and myosin-based macromolecular structure and regulated so that assembly occurs only at the correct time and place in the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE It has become increasingly clear in recent years that metabolism exerts a profound influence on the behaviors of cells, tissues and organisms. We posit that much of this effect is mediated by direct physical interactions between metabolites and macromolecules, like proteins and RNAs. We have developed and validated a platform technology that enables the discovery of such interactions, and now propose to implement if in a more systematic way to define mechanisms whereby metabolites signal to influence normal and disease physiology.

PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The goal of our research program is to develop and validate new sampling, scoring, and chemical searching techniques, for more accurate prediction of molecular recognition at the atomic level, to enable greater understanding of biological systems relevant to public health. IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Given that American Indian (AI) persons experience one of the most extreme smoking inequities, a scalable and culturally-aligned smoking cessation intervention could have a meaningful public health impact in this population. Through engagement with tribes and AI serving clinics and nationally drawn community advisory boards (CABs), our team has conducted multiple preliminary studies to culturally tailor NCI’s Smokefree TXT and QuitGuide smartphone app for AI persons. The present study will culturally-align the final Smokefree resource (Smokefree.gov) and then utilize mixed-methods to evaluate the efficacy of Smokefree for Natives, a suite of culturally-aligned digital cessation resources, among AI persons who smoke.

PHR: Project Narrative  Synthetic methods that rapidly generate complex organic molecules are critical for the development of selective biological probes and therapeutics. The overarching goal of this project is to explore transition metal redox catalysts for the reductive generation of carbene equivalents from readily available gem-dihalo starting materials. PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE These studies investigate the essential mechanisms underlying how the actin and microtubule cytoskeletons are assembled and coordinated by the individual and combined effects of several disease-relevant regulatory proteins. This research uses biochemical and cell-based analyses to assess how profilin and specific biomolecular condensate forming proteins impact the individual assembly and coordination of cytoskeletal polymers. These studies will provide new insight into the underlying shared features of several cancers and severe neurological disorders.

PHR: Project Narrative Protein-nucleic acid interactions are central to many biological processes, including the defense mechanisms in prokaryotes against invading DNA and translesion synthesis (TLS) mechanisms in eukaryotes for replicating through DNA lesions. We will uncover the role of protein nucleic acid interactions in these basic cellular processes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE This research program aims to discover the three-dimensional structures and to understand the fundamental mechanisms of two classes of proteins that reside within cellular membranes: ion channels and enzymatic membrane proteins. The ion channels under study regulate the flow of potassium, calcium, and chloride across cellular membranes and they are thereby involved in cognition, neuronal signals, muscle contraction, cellular motility, fluid secretion and a host of other processes; the enzymatic membrane proteins under study catalyze crucial post-translational chemical reactions in the cellular construction of signaling molecules (such as hormones and protein signaling complexes) that act to control cell growth and cell differentiation in normal tissues and can contribute to cancer progression when mutated or coopted by oncogenic signaling networks. The molecular, structural, and functional principles obtained from the studies will provide fuller understandings of the inner workings of these intricate protein machines and may inspire new approaches to intervene in diseases that include cancer, cystic fibrosis, immune disorders, and obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative: Protein misfolding is associated with numerous devastating neurodegenerative, cardiovascular, and kidney disorders, as well as certain forms of cancer. We seek to understand the role of protein disaggregases, which can solubilize misfolded proteins and restore the proteins to their native folds and functions. We seek to better understand how these agents maintain cellular health and how they counter cellular stress, because with this understanding we might gain new insights into how they fail in disease, ultimately leading to new insights into how disaggregases can be modulated to develop new therapeutics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Planar cell polarity (PCP) signaling controls the polarization of cells within the plane of an epithelium, orienting asymmetric cellular structures, cell divisions and cell migration, and is well conserved from Drosophila to vertebrates. This proposal aims to dissect the essential logic and underlying molecular and cell biological mechanisms of PCP signaling by leveraging the experimental tractability of the Drosophila model system, combining novel genetic tools, single molecule imaging and powerful biochemical approaches to probe previously inaccessible problems in PCP signaling. The proposed work will both enhance our knowledge of fundamental mechanisms as well as lay the groundwork for potential therapeutic interventions for PCP related pathologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE This project will investigate how Gram-negative bacteria transport lipids across their envelope to build their outermost layer, the outer membrane. Our work will generate fundamental knowledge about the mechanism of function of transporters that are potential targets for new antibiotics. In the long term, this knowledge will help in the development of much needed novel antimicrobials that can treat infections caused by Gram-negative bacteria, which pose a serious threat to global health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA nucleoside modifications are universal modulators of post-transcriptional gene expression, impacting protein synthesis in all organisms . Despite decades of study and established links between the dysregulation of RNA modifications and disease, the molecular level function of most individual rRNA, tRNA and mRNA modification sites remains to be discovered. Our work will establish relationships between cellular components that shape the RNA modification landscape, evaluate the impacts of discrete tRNA and mRNA modifications on translation, and open new avenues of investigation into how RNA modifications broadly influence cellular stress responses.
