PHR: Development and Applications of Bioorthogonal Chemistry Narrative This application seeks to combine the powers of genetic code expansion with bioorthogonal chemistry to develop new tools and capabilities for the studies of transmembrane receptor dynamics, intracellular enzyme functions, and antibody-based diagnostics in living systems. The demonstration of these new capabilities and their use in biomedical systems are expected to provide novel mechanistic insights into three major classes of drug targets crucial for clinical translation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cellular communication initiated by members of the Transforming Growth Factor beta (TGF-β) family of secreted signaling molecules plays important roles in normal and pathological biological processes. Signaling components mediate diverse outcomes that depend on the context, but how these outcomes are differentiated is poorly understood, increasing the likelihood of causing unintended consequences during the management of diseases and disorders. In this project, we will exploit the advantages of a simple model organism to uncover the conserved mechanisms that distinguish the roles of TGF-β signaling in fat metabolism and immunity from those in development.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE - OVERALL Skeletal muscle dysfunction represents a significant and growing public health concern due to reduced quality of life and loss of independence for those affected. Muscle dysfunction and degeneration result from numerous pathological conditions including genetic diseases like muscular dystrophy and systems level conditions like diabetes, cancer and aging. The UW Resource Center for Translational Muscle Research (CTMR) will provide access to, and training on state of the art tools to recruit new investigators, accelerate research and disseminate news of exciting new successes in understanding and treating skeletal muscle dysfunction to improve the health status of the U.S. population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Transcriptional regulation of gene expression plays a critical role in many cellular processes, but its fundamental mechanism is not fully understood. The main goal of the proposed research program is to develop statistical models and computational methods to predict functional transcriptional regulators from cross- platform multi-scale omics data and to study transcriptional factor binding activities in mammalian genomes. The anticipated outcome will provide useful tools to the biomedical research community and unique insights into understanding fundamental mechanisms of gene regulation in biological processes and human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Coordinated gene expression of the correct target genes is essential for all organisms and to prevent the formation of disease states from cancer to neurodegeneration. We will define the mechanisms by which pioneer transcription factors and long non-coding RNAs function together to coregulate genes across time and space in diverse cell types. By determining these new mechanisms for coordinated gene expression, we will inform efforts to correct misregulation of genes in disease contexts.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative While it is clear that small molecules are central to orchestrating all cellular processes, we know relatively little about the functions of many metabolites. To address this gap in our knowledge, this proposal aims to explore protein-metabolite interaction networks to identify and functionally characterize regulatory metabolite-protein pairings. The results of this research will inform our understanding of how organisms exploit metabolites to regulate cellular functions; the long-term outcome of the proposed research will lead to innovation in the form of small molecule-based strategies aimed at improving plant and animal health /resilience.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE Bacteria make a number of flagella inserted in a particular pattern according to their species. Here we propose to study how flagellar number is controlled in response to environmental stimuli and how flagella are positioned in space and time during cell growth. Our work contributes to the understanding of bacterial self-organization and the regulation of flagella and other virulence-associated nanomachines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Narrative Neural tube defects (spina bifida and anencephaly, for example) constitute the second-most common class of birth defects, resulting in significant suffering and monetary costs: ~$1 billion total in hospitalization costs for all US patients annually. This proposal seeks to understand mechanisms of apical constriction, a change in cell shape that contributes to successful neural tube closure, using C. elegans as a model for efficient investigation of cellular and molecular mechanisms. The long-term goal of the work is to understand fundamental mechanisms that can lay a foundation for future diagnosis and prevention of neural tube defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: NARRATIVE Long noncoding RNAs (lncRNAs) play critical roles in health and homeostasis by regulating gene expression, but their mechanisms of action are poorly defined. Our research will determine how lncRNAs and proteins interact to achieve specific gene regulatory outcomes and will develop new ways to predict the presence of regulatory function in lncRNAs. We expect our work to reveal new and conserved mechanisms of gene regulation as well as disease etiologies and therapeutic opportunities in many settings.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Enhancers are short non-coding DNA sequences that act to drive transcription of their target genes, often at long genomic distances and in a highly tissue-specific manner. The goal of the proposed research is to understand fundamental principles of long-range gene regulation by enhancers. This knowledge is important to identify new types of therapeutic strategies for human disease and for realizing the promise of precision medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA binding proteins control the processing of RNA, often in a cell-specific or tissue-specific manner, as evidenced by the disease Spinal Muscular Atrophy wherein mutation of a ubiquitously-expressed RNA binding protein (SMN-1) causes cell-specific defects in motor neurons. We aim to use the genetic and molecular strengths of the nematode C. elegans to dissect the reasons why broadly-expressed RNA binding proteins have tissue-specific effects, and moreover to investigate new and emerging types of RNA regulation controlled at the tissue-specific level.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The formation of biomolecular condensates is emerging as a unifying mechanism underlying the formation of many membraneless organelles that perform essential biological functions, such as transcription, genome organization, stress response, and DNA repair. Aberrant phase separation has also been linked to diseases such as a number of sarcomas and neurodegenerative diseases, e.g. ALS, Alzheimers, and FTD. Thus, generating a molecular framework of phase-separated assemblies is vital to a mechanistic understanding of their function and dysfunction.

PHR: Project Narrative Organic molecules containing oxygen and nitrogen are ubiquitous in biomedical research and in the treatment of a range of human ailments including mental health conditions, conditions associated with inflammation, cancer and diabetes as well as cardiovascular, infectious and neurodegenerative diseases. This project is centered on the development of efficient, catalytic and selective methods for carbon–oxygen, carbon–nitrogen and carbon– carbon bond formation, useful in the efficient construction and structural optimization of bioactive organic molecules. This project includes applications of the developed chemical methods to the synthesis of select natural products, drugs, and derivatives thereof to enable their structural assignments, mechanism of action and metabolism studies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project narrative There are tens of millions of human genetic variants in protein coding genes, most of which are so rare in the population that for any given variant, little to nothing can be said about its impact upon gene function and disease risk. We develop methods to experimentally test many thousands of variants, but to date this approach is generally limited to genes affecting cell growth in culture, which is poor proxy for the mechanism by which many genetic disorders act. Here we develop and apply models to make entire classes of human disease genes newly accessible to these methods, improving our understanding of how those genes function, and proactively mapping which of their variants can cause disease.

PHR: The export of mRNA from the nucleus to the cytoplasm is an essential step of gene expression in eukaryotic cells and thus fundamental for all cellular functions. This mRNA export process is often targeted by viruses to suppress host gene expression and facilitate viral replication. The proposed work will provide significant insights into the mechanisms and regulation of mRNA export in health and during viral infections.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative An adult human being has approximately 100,000 billion cells comprised of more than 200 cell types, which all originate from a single cell—a fertilized egg. Therefore, a fundamental question to understanding any complex living organism is how cells become different while faithfully maintaining the same genetic material. In this application we plan to systematically study how epigenetic information is established and partitioned into daughter cells in development, homeostasis and regeneration, which will have broad impaction on stem cell biology, developmental biology, chromatin biology, and regenerative medicine.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In order to carry out processes essential for life, molecular complexes are in constant motion in the cell. Although our understanding of the structural dynamics and heterogeneity of molecules has increased dramatically in recent years, researchers currently lack tools to readily create dynamic molecular models. Taking advantage of our decades of experience creating visualizations and developing software, we propose to launch a free and open-source suite of tools that will enable molecular biologists to create, share, and annotate animated three-dimensional models of molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Voltage gated K+ channels (Kv) play important roles in human physiology and mutations in Kv channels can cause diseases such as epilepsies and cardiac arrhythmias. In this proposal, we use a multidisciplinary approach that combines unnatural amino acid mutagenesis with structural and functional studies to investigate the mechanisms of voltage gating and C-type inactivation that regulate the flux of K+ through Kv channels. Understanding the mechanisms of voltage gating and C-type inactivation is essential for the development of therapeutics that target Kv channels.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Epigenetic processes provide a layer of regulation that is above the genetic sequence and are essential to understand health and disease. In model organisms, such as yeast and flies, noncoding RNAs play important role in regulating the flow of epigenetic information, but their contribution to these processes in mammals remains poorly understood at a mechanistic level. We will leverage our expertise in RNA biochemistry, functional genomics, and mass spectrometry to identify and characterize RNAs that shape transitions in epigenetic states that accompany the differentiation from embryonic stem cells to neurons.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The goal of the proposed research is to create new directions for catalytic regioselective dicarbofunctionalization of unactivated alkenes. We will develop these processes through photoredox and transition metal catalysis by intercepting carbon-centered radical and alkylmetal intermediates, formed upon the addition of alkyl sources to alkenes, with different organo-reagents. This research program will invent new methods for rapidly constructing complex molecular motifs present in pharmaceuticals, bioactive molecules and drug targets, and will make significant impacts on the biomedical mission of the NIH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Biology and Biochemistry of the Microtubule Cytoskeleton The microtubule cytoskeleton is essential for a wide range of biological processes in all eukaryotic cells. The functions of microtubules are facilitated by microtubule-associated proteins (MAPs) and molecular motors that organize microtubules in three-dimensional space or use them as tracks for intracellular trafficking, and are extended by a constellation of tubulin post-translational modifications that act to regulate MAP/motor protein-MT interactions. We work to establish how the cellular system of MAPs, motor proteins, and tubulin PTMs organize MTs to drive essential cellular processes such as mitosis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Cytokinesis and the septin cytoskeleton play essential roles in cell proliferation and differentiation and are required for the survival of all organisms. Defects in cytokinesis or septins cause lethality or serious diseases including cancer, infertility, and neurodegenerative diseases. Thus, mechanistic study of cytokinesis and the septin cytoskeleton is important not only for understanding basic biology but also for developing new strategies to treat human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: This proposal is concerned with conserved signaling systems that convey information between cells, tissues, and organs during animal development. This work on the simple model system C. elegans will provide fundamental knowledge that is relevant to human biology and health, because aberrations in the same conserved signaling systems that regulate development in this model and indeed, in all animals, can cause congenital developmental disorders and cancer in people. Understanding these processes and the genes and genetic interactions that mediate them is critical for precision medicine and the development of diagnostic and therapeutic tools for human disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative G protein-coupled receptors are important drug targets that can exhibit preference for signal transduction pathways, a phenomenon known as biased signaling. To design pathway-selective drugs, mechanistic understanding at the molecular level is required to identify structural motifs that govern biased signaling. Using chemical and structural biology approaches, this project focuses on uncovering these structural motifs by employing structure-based mutagenesis, biased ligands, and in vitro assay platforms to identify common mechanisms of ligand bias at key receptor targets. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Natural products offer unmatched chemical and structural diversity compared to any other small molecule families and remain the best sources of drugs and drug leads, but most gene clusters encoding natural product biosynthesis are silent when the microorganisms are cultured under standard laboratory conditions. This proposal aims to discover new natural products by mining actinobacterial genomes, develop enabling technologies to produce them in enough quantities for structural elucidation and biological evaluation, and study their biosynthetic machineries to inspire new chemistry, biology, and medicine. The long-term goal of our research program is to understand at a molecular level how microorganisms synthesize complex natural products and to exploit this knowledge to discover novel natural products and engineer their analogues for drug discovery.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: The design and synthesis of new medicines requires access to a diverse array of chiral building blocks. This proposal describes mechanistic analysis and engineering of enzymes that can synthesize such molecules by overcoming classical limitations to forging carbon-carbon bonds. This research will yield generalizable insights into enzyme activity and advance our understanding of how to rapidly engineer new enzymes for the construction of medicines and diagnostics.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR ADVANCING TRANSLATIONAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  The ability to use in vitro cellular data for efficacy assessment will create drug development opportunities for rare diseases that were previously considered too challenging due to the small number of patients. This proposal will aim to establish “clinical trial in a dish” using induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) that capture patient- specific genetic diversity as a tool for evaluating clinical trial readiness to accelerate, de-risk, and streamline drug discovery for rare diseases. We will also combine artificial intelligence and machine learning to identify safe and effective compounds to test in iPSC models and validate in mouse models to demonstrate the effectiveness of iPSCs in determining clinical trial readiness of a candidate drug.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE RNA and DNA form stable structures that must be transiently disrupted in many essential cellular processes. All human cells have proteins that promote disruptions or changes to RNA and DNA structures, and defects in these proteins are linked to many diseases including cancer. We are striving to understand how these proteins function to gain insight into why malfunctions in them lead to diseases and to improve treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cells, organs and organisms are to a great extent susceptible to osmotic stress caused by unbalanced water content or dehydration, with hyperosmotic stress having been linked to several human diseases. This research program will make use of a powerful unbiased genetic screen and time-resolved signal transduction analyses to dissect molecular and cellular mechanisms mediating hyperosmotic and dehydration stress sensing and signal transduction. This research will leverage an easily manipulated and highly developed model system to develop an in-depth understanding of eukaryotic osmotic stress response mechanisms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The cellular genome is compacted in the basic repeating assembly called chromatin, the anomalous regulation of which is characteristic of many diseases and cancers. Viruses hijack and manipulate host cells, including cellular chromatin, to exploit cellular resources and produce viral progeny. In this proposal, we will employ multiple nuclear-replicating viruses to identify commonly used chromatin vulnerabilities that will allow us to pinpoint new targets for the development of innovative therapies for cancer, inflammation, and viral diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The ends of telomeres, the DNA-protein complexes that cap our linear chromosomes, are maintained by telomerase that synthesizes the G-strand and CST–Polymeraseα-Primase that synthesizes the C-strand. Telomerase is a highly regulated determinant of aging, stem cell renewal, and tumorigenesis, and mutations in telomerase and telomere binding or associated proteins can lead to aplastic anemia, dyskeratosis congenita, pulmonary fibrosis, myelodysplastic syndromes, Coats plus syndrome, and other telomere biology disorders. We propose to use an integrative structural and molecular biology approach to investigate their mechanisms of action and regulation of telomere synthesis, which should reveal the structural basis of mutations leading to disease and for drug targeting.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Cells in the human body link to one another via protein complexes that respond to mechanical force in order to maintain tissue integrity, and to remodel tissues during embryonic development. We will determine how key proteins in cellular adhesion complexes and the cytoskeleton respond to force, and how their molecular behavior contributes to processes that shape living tissues. This study will significantly advance our understanding of the molecular events that drive cancer metastasis, in which the loss of cell-cell contacts is a key step, as well as the causes of cardiomyopathies and skin diseases in which cells lose their mechanical integrity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative Fruit flies are a powerful model for evolutionary studies because many species exist whose genomes have been fully sequenced and can be analyzed using experimental genetics. This study will use evolutionary genetic methods to investigate why different fruit fly species cannot form viable progeny, how correct transmission of their chromosomes can sometimes go awry, and how different genetic systems may be used to form males and females. The results of this study will reveal processes that are relevant for understanding how animals evolve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Our project aims to develop cutting-edge technologies for analyzing the immune system. We will use nanomaterial-based sensors and advanced computer algorithms to measure key immune proteins and track how immune cells behave and communicate. This project will provide critical insights into the immune system and help improve the diagnosis and treatment of immune-related diseases. Our goal is to make these new technologies widely available to researchers and clinicians, enabling better patient care and outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Calcium (Ca) is a ubiquitous second messenger in all eukaryotes ranging from budding yeast, plants, to human. Defects in Ca signaling cause numerous human diseases including Alzheimer’s disease, heart failure, metabolic diseases, immune disorders, neurodegenerative diseases, and cancer. Proposed research will contribute to the understanding of the basic conceptual framework of calcium signaling mechanisms highly relevant to human health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: NEW YORK UNIVERSITY SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE World Trade Center (WTC) site destruction caused an intense particulate matter (PM) exposure. Since PM is responsible for a high percentage of cardiorespiratory disease/death we propose to investigate the development of WTC-PM induced cardiorespiratory and vascular dysfunction (WTC-CaRVD) in the FDNY cohort. Our proposal will identify biologically plausible therapeutic targets of oxidative stress and clinical phenotypes of WTC- CaRVD; which falls squarely within the purview of the James Zadroga 9/11 Health & Compensation Act.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: World Trade Center Particulate Matter Induced Cardiorespiratory and Vascular Dysfunction:  a MultiOmic Approach

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE FOR OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Common sleep disorders like obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) may represent risk factors for cognitive decline. We have found a very high prevalence of OSA in the World Trade Center responder population, and the present work will evaluate the impact of OSA on early markers of Alzheimer 's Disease using plasma biomarkers, PET/MR and cognition using a visual-spatial memory test. This study has the potential to identify the mechanisms by which sleep disruption contributes to Alzheimer's Disease neurodegeneration and guide therapeutic interventions in the future in the aging WTC responder population.
PROJECT_TERMS: NA
PROJECT_TITLE: Role of Sleep Apnea in Cognition and Alzheimer's Disease Biomarkers in WTC Responders

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Precise and robust regulation of gene expression through chromatin regulation is critical for proper human development; disruptions to regulation of chromatin regulatory proteins is at fault in a number of human diseases. Heterochromatin gene repression, one of the focus areas of this proposed research is at fault in multiple developmental disorders, neurological diseases, as well as cancer thus our findings could lead to a better understanding of human disease. In this work we explore multiple mechanisms contributing to heterochromatin gene repression as well as develop new chemical-based technologies that use bifunctional molecules to alter chromatin structure as an approach to learn more about chromatin regulation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE The Indiana Medical Scientist Training Program (MSTP) is strongly supported by the Indiana University School of Medicine and by several Foundations to train the next generation of physician-scientists, placing graduates in top residency and research programs across the nation and preparing graduates to be leading investigators and innovators in academia and industry. It is particularly focused on training physician-engineers, in partnership with – and strongly supported by - the Purdue University Weldon School of Biomedical Engineering. We emphasize both strong mentorship training and a culture of diversity and inclusiveness, being one of the most diverse programs in the Midwest and having recently received substantial grants further to increase diversity in Indiana STEM education and recruitment of MSTP scholars and mentors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY NEW YORK STONY BROOK
PHR: We propose to develop artificial intelligence (AI) enhanced fluorescence and optical Doppler microscope for imaging of astrocytic Ca2+ (Ca2+A), neuronal Ca2+ (Ca2+N) activities and cerebral blood flow velocity (CBFv) of awake animals. AI frameworks will be used to effectively minimize motion artifacts and denoise time-lapse images, from which spatiotemporal analyses will be applied to derive Ca2+A, Ca2+N, CBFv synchronization via their resting-state low-frequency oscillations (<1Hz) in medial frontal cortex (mPFC) of naïve mice and mice with chronic administration of cocaine. Successful completion of the proposed research and development will have a broad impact on neuroscience and drug addiction that require high-resolution, simultaneous imaging of neuro- astroglio-vascular effects in the brain of awake animals. This translational research is of clinical relevance to drug addiction – a highly prevalent public health problem.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HUMAN GENOME RESEARCH INSTITUTE
PHR: Hundreds of thousands of genomic regions have been associated with human traits and diseases, yet in few instances do we know the identity of the exact causal mutation nor the molecular mechanism behind its function. This proposal aims develop new tools to mutagenize gene regulatory elements in the genome and build a catalog of epigenetic and transcriptional phenotypes from over 300,000 mutations. This catalog will be used to augment advanced machine learning models to better understand the underlying rules of how variants function, as to better predict the impact of individual mutations linked to human health and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MIAMI SCHOOL OF MEDICINE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE  Opioid use disorder (OUD) represents an urgent public health crisis for which available therapeutics have proven insufficiently efficacious. While most of the research surrounding opioid addiction has focused on how neurons communicate with one another, less attention has been given to other brain cell types and mechanisms that have also been shown to affect aspects of addiction, such as neuroinflammation induced by microglia – the resident immune cells of the central nervous system. Given that microglial activation is under epigenetic control, the proposed research seeks to understand the epigenetic mechanisms that govern microglial activation across different phases of OUD, with the goal of developing more effective therapeutics for this devastating disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Understanding how the right ventricle (RV) adapts to the increased pulmonary vascular resistance in pulmonary hypertension and which molecular mechanisms and structural changes lead to RV failure, will help us develop novel therapies to strengthen the RV and prevent RV failure. We will test two repurposed drugs, Tacrolimus (FK506) and Enzastaurin in our mouse model of RV pressure- overload, to evaluate whether they can prevent and reverse RV failure. Given that these two drugs are ready to be tested in clinical trials, our research is in line with the NIH’s mission to increase knowledge to enhance health, lengthen life, and reduce illness and disability by applying fundamental knowledge of RV adaptation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Some bacteria release ribotoxins that target protein translation system for cell killing, and others have acquired RNA repair systems to neutralize the toxic effect of ribotoxins for survival. The RNA repair systems appear to be concentrated on pathogenic bacteria. Therefore, blocking RNA repair in these bacteria with small-molecule inhibitors may lead to their demise, resulting in potential prevention and treatment of human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Systemic lupus erythematosus afflicts young women and is frequently devastating. We now understand that the disease is heterogenous and we need to understand better the diverse mechanisms that are involved in the expression of the disease. In this proposal we plan to understand how an expanded subpopulation of lymphocytes known, as double negative T cells, contributes to the expression of the disease. The gained knowledge will enable the consideration of effective individualized treatment of patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Native Americans face significant disparities in cardiovascular incidence and mortality rates, but effective hypertension (HTN) self-care behaviors can reduce their healthcare burden and suffering. We propose a randomized controlled trial of a culturally adapted sensor-controlled digital game intervention, to improve NA individuals’ knowledge, skills, and motivation to engage in critical HTN self-care behaviors. This project will generate insight and guidance regarding the use of digital gaming as an affordable, portable, and scalable technology to potentially reduce the burden of HTN among Native Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: NARRATIVE: This proposal focuses on the mechanism of Wnt signal transduction, which plays an essential role in embryonic development and in adult stem cell maintenance. Our current work focuses on control of Wnt coreceptor stability by the USP46 complex, the role of the tumor suppressor, APC, in regulating Wnt receptor activation, the establishment of bistable behavior by the - catenin destruction complex, and the regulation of Wnt-mediated transcription by the proteins, USP47 and STK38. We now propose to reconstitute LRP6 ubiquitylation, uncover compensation mechanisms that activate signaling in APC mutant cells, determine the contribution of APC in Wnt pathway bistability, and characterize the role of a newly identified component of the Wnt pathway, TRIP12.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative.  DNA-directed RNA Polymerase II (Pol II) is one of the most important molecules in biology. Pol II is highly- conserved among eukaryotic organisms and plays a fundamental role in cellular life; specifically the transcription of genes into messenger RNA. Pol II studies, and RNA polymerase studies in general, lag the diverse and extensive studies on DNA polymerases where high resolution, atomic level data on conformational changes and chemical groups that drive catalysis and translocation have been revealed. Catalysis and translocation of multi-subunit RNA polymerases underlie all cellular RNA synthesis. Advancing our knowledge will be hugely significant for understanding how these enzymes work and are potentially regulated by initiation and elongation factors. Our preliminary experiments reveal “snapshots of the transcriptional process at different time points”. The studies proposed in this renewal will uncover (for the first time) a “molecular movie” of nucleotide addition and will lead to the fundamental understanding of the mechanisms of DNA mediated transcription. We propose to “direct and produce” a movie of Pol II in the act of transcription that will illuminate the intricacies of one of the most fundamental process in biology.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
ORG_NAME: TEXAS A&M UNIVERSITY HEALTH SCIENCE CTR
PHR: This research is relevant to public health because of its conceptual novelty and its broad impact on chemosensory research. It is proposed to examine the molecular and cellular basis of a novel taste modality in Drosophila larvae, the taste of RNA and ribonucleosides, which are essential nutrients during the fast- growing larval life stages. The taste of RNA is conserved across a range of insect species, including disease transmitting mosquitoes, and therefore, elucidating the mechanism of this taste modality may lead to new approaches and strategies for insect pest control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project narrative: Chlamydia trachomatis (CT) is the most common bacterial sexually transmitted infection in the U.S.; consequences of untreated CT infections include pelvic inflammatory disease, ectopic pregnancy, as well as increased healthcare costs. We seek to assess how the vaginal microbiome, characteristics of the infecting CT organism, and immune responses affect spontaneous clearance of CT (without antibiotics). This proposal is in response to PA-19-096 (“Control of Sexually Transmitted Infections (STIs) Through a Comprehensive Understanding of the Natural History of Infection”) and is fully responsive to the program announcement's objective and NIH mission of identifying biological and clinical factors that influence spontaneous clearance of a STI in order to support the development of novel interventions such as live biotherapeutics drugs and vaccines.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: In order to better understand how HIV affects the brain in the era of combination antiretroviral therapy, and in order to improve current treatment options, we will study the cell susceptible to HIV infection--human microglia--, in the mouse brain. This includes novel experimental therapies of antiretrovirals combined with Cannabinoid receptor-specific drugs that could lower the extent of inflammation and infection in the brain.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative RNA molecules are vital to many cellular functions in biology. Telomerase RNA is a class of long noncoding RNA (lncRNA) that plays an essential role in telomerase function, telomere maintenance, and chromosome stability. This research program aims to understand an unprecedented mRNA-derived biogenesis pathway of telomerase RNA in a fungal model organism, which will provide unforeseen insights into how mRNA may be processed to generate lncRNA and have broad impacts on RNA biology and human diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Copy number variations (CNVs) are a significant source for diseases in the human population, including cancer and autism. The cellular mechanisms that contribute to CNV formation and their phenotypic consequences are not well understood, particularly in disease-relevant diploid genomes that have higher structural plasticity than conventional haploid model systems. Our research will contribute to a broad investigation of fundamental CNV mechanisms in diploid yeast cells, thus opening an avenue for uncovering risk factors that may lead to CNV formation in humans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON ALCOHOL ABUSE AND ALCOHOLISM
PHR: Narrative This NRSA F30 fellowship will provide an invaluable training opportunity for a future physician scientist as she develops into an emerging leader in immunology related research. The proposed studies will investigate the role of lymph contents from alcohol-treated animals in PLAT fTreg expansion and subsequent immune and metabolic dysregulation. Findings from this study will further our understanding of the negative consequences of alcohol-associated lymph leakage and how its constituents impact PLAT immune cell milieu, specifically fTregs, contributing to development of PLAT IR and potentially systemic IR.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pro-inflammatory T cell responses in the central nervous system are causally associated with multiple demyelinating and neurodegenerative diseases, including Multiple Sclerosis, Parkinson's Disease, Alzheimer's Disease and age-associated cognitive decline, which collectively affect over 7 million Americans and requires annual health care costs approaching one trillion dollars. The focus of this proposal is to define the role and regulation of a novel pathway that critically controls T cells in neuroinflammation, and determine its therapeutic potential to limit disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: Due to the rapidly growing importance of antibody-mediated drug delivery, there is a critical need for simple and efficient site-specific conjugation techniques that do not require extensive antibody engineering efforts. The goal of this proposal is to optimize and demonstrate the utility of a new site- specific conjugation technology that places payloads within a conserved hydrophobic pocket of IgG antibodies. We will demonstrate the broad utility of this method through the preparation and evaluation of antibody conjugates for oncology, immunology, and imaging applications.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative HLA-F is a nonclassical MHC class I molecule that likely plays a role in cancer, HIV infection, autoimmunity and reproduction. It was previously thought to exist only as a heavy chain, without association with the 2microglobulin (2m) subunit or bound peptide. We have recently shown that HLA-F can associate with both 2m and peptide, these two states of HLA-F confer differing reactivity to receptors expressed on effector cells. The goal of this proposal is to understand, at the molecular and functional levels, how HLA-F engages with these receptors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative The maintenance of quiescent cell populations in the body is essential to repair wounds, maintain healthy tissue and for pathogen defense, and once cells enter quiescence, they must also be able to re-enter the cell cycle and divide again. This project will investigate multifaceted cellular pathways regulated by E2F and APC/CCdh1 activity and how they synergize to create two pathways into S phase that must be suppressed to allow cells to enter quiescence, and how this synergy allows for the licensing of origins of DNA replication in G1. Completion of this study in single cells will support the identification of potential treatment targets for quiescent cancer cell populations and pro-proliferative treatments for increased cellular regeneration.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Racial and ethnic disparities in health care services cause many Non-Hispanic Black and Hispanic children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) symptomology to go undiagnosed and under-represented in research studies generated from those clinical databases. Yet, many epidemiologic studies use healthcare databases to examine etiologic questions about ASD, often without necessary consideration of potential biases. Thus, this project will use quantitative bias analysis methods to examine the impact of information and selection bias in ASD research, with an application to the association between epidural analgesia use and ASD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Public Health Relevancy This proposed research will establish the molecular mechanisms underlying the response to inhaled corticosteroids and adrenal suppression, a potentially severe adverse effect of corticosteroid therapy, in asthma patients. This proposal has the potential to generate a significant clinical impact through the identification of asthma patients who would either benefit from switching to alternative treatment(s), or who may require more intensive monitoring of adrenal function to avoid adrenal suppression. Ultimately, this research has the promise to revolutionize asthma treatment, help to offset the mounting costs of asthma management, and improve outcomes for patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Brain metastasis (BM) frequently arises from non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) and represents the most common cause of cancer related death in the US, yet our understanding of BM biology is rudimentary. Our group has identified excessive chromosomal instability (CIN) as a hallmark of BM and as a putative characteristic of NSCLCs harboring mutation in STK11 (encoding LKB1), a subtype of lung cancer associated with increased risk of brain metastasis (BM) and immunotherapy resistance, and thus a relevant archetypical disease that may broadly inform the role of CIN in BM biology. This proposal seeks to identify tumor-cell intrinsic and extrinsic adaptations to CIN that enables immune evasion and BM in LKB1-deficient NSCLCs; because CIN is pervasive in cancer and particularly high in brain-metastatic lesions across different cancer types, this work will have implications for our broader understanding of BM biology and pave the way for future therapeutic development of CINhigh tumors.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF MASSACHUSETTS MED SCH WORCESTER
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD)—one of the most common and severe genetic muscle disorders—is characterized by progressive muscle weakness. This proposal seeks to develop a safe, flexible, muscle-specific gene editing strategy that improves muscle strength by encouraging cells to ignore DMD-causing gene mutations. Completing this work will inform the development of a one-time treatment for DMD, and potentially other genetic muscle diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CENTER FOR COMPLEMENTARY & INTEGRATIVE HEALTH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Cannabidiol (CBD) is a promising, complimentary treatment for pain, particularly for patients with chronic neurological conditions such as multiple sclerosis (MS), but research that increases our understanding of analgesic mechanisms of CBD is sorely needed to maximize its benefits. Sleep shares a close bidirectional relationship with pain, and may be a key mediator in the analgesic effects of CBD. The proposed research will study the effects of CBD on sleep in persons with MS and chronic pain, and explore changes in sleep as a mediator of the analgesic effects of CBD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative Sustained immunosuppression due to lymphocyte cell death and dysfunction exacerbates sepsis-induced mortality. Based on my preliminary results, I aim to study the role and mechanism of an immune inhibitory molecule, SUSD2, in promoting T lymphocyte cell death and dysfunction during microbial sepsis. Understanding the function of SUSD2 in sepsis-induced immunosuppression will be instrumental for the generation of new strategy targeting the prevention and/or treatment of this complex syndrome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Macroautophagy and methionine sulfoxide reductases (Msrs) are two important pathways for degrading and repairing damaged proteins, and their impairments have been associated with a number of neurodegenerative disorders. Here, we will investigate the role of macroautophagy and Msrs in maintaining cellular homeostasis within cells. Our results will provide important insights into the mechanism by which these two important pathways select specific proteins for degradation or repair.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: Non-Communicable Diseases (NCD) continue to dominate as a major cause of Health-related morbidity, chronic disabilities, and mortality, exceeding 50% worldwide; the Middle East and North Africa region are no exception. The Scholars in HeAlth Research Program is an interfaculty collaborative initiative that provides short, intermediate, and long-term training, to health professionals engaged in population- based and clinical translational NCD research. Its multidisciplinary and cross-cutting approach integrates a solid curriculum in quantitative skills, advances in science and technology, hands-on applied training, thus providing the basis for effective public heath interventions to promote Health across the life course.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE

PHR: Project narrative Our proposed research is to evaluate the effectiveness of using an existing implementation strategy infrastructure at academic centers in delivering best-practice communication interventions to increase HPV vaccination rates in rural primary care clinics. The project is relevant to public health because it aims to increase HPV vaccination rates and reduce cancer inequities in rural populations by addressing the context- specific communication needs of both rural providers and parents, especially those parents who are vaccine hesitant. The proposed research is relevant to the NCI because it aims to improve implementation of effective interventions that are responsive to behavioral and sociocultural factors in cancer prevention among rural populations, an understudied area in cancer prevention research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: NARRATIVE The U.S. healthcare system cares for increasing numbers of older adults, including those with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, who require surgery with anesthesia. Regional social inequities, measured by spatial indices such as area deprivation and social vulnerability indices, independently contribute to differences in perioperative and neurodegenerative outcomes. Via the K07 mechanism and associated institutional support, the applicant will develop transdisciplinary research training and infrastructure involving geospatial data, social determinants of health, and artificial intelligence to address these challenges. This proposal will ultimately reduce disparities in postoperative outcomes in older adult surgical patients, including those with Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias, with a particular emphasis on outcomes pertaining to postoperative pain and cognitive decline.

ORG_NAME: UNIV OF NORTH CAROLINA CHAPEL HILL
PHR: Project Narrative Alpha-gal syndrome is an allergic condition with global reach; there are reports from around the world describing these patients with delayed allergic reactions to mammalian meat, and yet, we have limited understanding of the mechanisms underlying this condition. The proposed research will explore the role of glycolipids and unconventional T cells in this allergy with the vision of broadening our understanding of their roles in hypersensitivity disorders. It may also link tick exposure to a gene expression and cytokine profile in unconventional T cells that promotes allergic responses.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Perineuronal nets are complex extracellular matrix structures found exclusively surrounding a subset of neurons in the central nervous system and are established key regulators of developmental neural plasticity and cognitive functions. Despite the importance of perineuronal nets, there is little understanding of their specific functions, which is driven in large part by an incomplete understanding of their molecular composition and of the protein- protein interactions that underlie the assembly of these structures. Here, we propose to identify and undertake a structure-function analysis of the main components of perineuronal nets to understand the mechanisms that guide net formation, with the ultimate goal to identify proteins that are critical to net formation in order to design tools to manipulate these structures to promote recovery from neural injury and disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative: It is crucial for human health that cells always maintain the correct concentration of proteins, as such there are various mechanisms to control protein production and degradation. The goal of this work is to understand the general principles by which protein degradation can be controlled by protein acetylation and to develop chemical tools to manipulate the acetylation status of proteins. We anticipate this will provide insights into fundamental biological processes and provide a new therapeutic approach for a variety of diseases.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE / RELEVANCE  A wide array of scientific disciplines (including biology, biochemistry, pharmaceutical chemistry, bioinorganic chemistry, chemical biology, and organic chemistry) make use of organic compounds, especially enantiomerically enriched compounds (due to the "handedness" of the molecules of life, e.g., peptides, DNA, RNA, and carbohydrates). The development of powerful new methods for organic synthesis, particularly enantioselective synthesis, facilitates progress in biomedical research by providing access to compounds that enable the exploration of new hypotheses and the discovery of new bioactive molecules.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Acute Graft-versus-Host Disease (aGVHD) is a common and frequently lethal complication, occurring in >50% of allogeneic stem cell transplants, limiting survival and the success of a curative therapy for hematologic diseases. The proposed study will examine the underlying effects of Bromodomain and Extraterminal (BET) domain inhibition on T cell and dendritic cell immunobiology both in preclinical and clinical studies and assess synergy of dual BET/JAK1/2 inhibition for treatment of aGVHD. Our studies will determine the safety and feasibility of a novel therapy for steroid-refractory aGVHD and establish the biological rationale for single agent and combination therapy for future clinical studies.

The primary goal of this proposal is to define mechanisms by which iron modulates the activity of a family of RNA binding proteins which double as intracellular iron chaperones. This research program is highly relevant to public health because it will uncover basic mechanisms that become dysregulated with iron deficiency.

PHR: Project Narrative Environmental health has been recognized as one of the most pressing problems of our time because pollution and environmental degradation has an immense impact on human health, especially in developing countries. This program will build on existing strengths at the Icahn School of Medicine and at the National University of Costa Rica to improve opportunities for research and collaboration. The training program will have impacts at the individual, institutional, national and regional levels by building on evidence gathered from previous experiences in research training programs by both institutions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Public Health Relevance Statement The goal of this project is to identify mechanisms by which immune checkpoint programmed death ligand 1 (PD-L1) regulates mRNA homeostasis of anti-apoptotic genes. Immunotherapies targeting surface PD-L1 expression have shown impressive clinical results in many cancers, but only a fraction of patients achieve durable responses, highlighting our incomplete understanding of the mechanisms of PD-L1 functions. This project will advance our understanding of the immune-independent, intracellular PD-L1 functions by identifying mechanisms by which it regulates mRNA homeostasis, and may lead to the development of novel therapies that target PD-L1 anti-apoptotic functions in cancer cells.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Sexual and gender minority (SGM) youth in the United States are disproportionately affected by HIV. As HIV vaccines are in development, understanding biomedical HIV prevention concerns and misinformation among SGM youth can inform messaging interventions that proactively address such issues and increase awareness, intentions, and uptake. This proposal aims to develop youth-centered video messages that preemptively debunk misinformation regarding multiple biomedical HIV prevention methods (e.g., vaccines, PrEP) and to test them in an online randomized trial versus an information only control (e.g., CDC consumer-oriented information about vaccines and PrEP) on outcomes such as vaccine knowledge, intentions, and attitudes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: NARRATIVE The “Clinical High Risk” (CHR) for psychosis syndrome in young people represents an opportune window for early intervention to prevent the onset of psychosis and other disorders, and to forestall disability; however, clinical heterogeneity and the paucity of biomarkers have hampered the development of effective intervention. To address these challenges, working with NIMH and key stakeholders, we will harmonize and aggregate existing “legacy” CHR data, and guide and coordinate the collection of new data across a network of sites, to develop biomarker algorithms that can predict individual trajectories for diverse outcomes. This proposal leverages a multidisciplinary team with broad and CHR-specific experience in large-scale multisite and multimodal studies (including clinical trials), along with expertise in data type-specific processing, coordination, analysis, and computational analyses (e.g., machine and deep learning tools from artificial intelligence, and advanced statistical approaches), ethics, community outreach, and data dissemination, all of which will ensure the success of this project.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The nucleus accumbens is an essential hub in the reward system integrating cognitive, contextual, sensory and affective information into behavioral outcomes. The proposed work will test the hypothesis that feed forward microcircuits within the nucleus accumbens regulate reinforcement behavior and are hijacked by drugs of abuse. By defining circuits and synaptic mechanisms necessary for reward processing, the proposed research is relevant to the NIH and NIDA's mission that pertains to developing fundamental knowledge that will help reduce the burdens of addiction.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: NARRATIVE We propose a program to establish novel EEG biomarkers and computational tools that will enable rapid and accurate diagnosis of epilepsy followed by a rapid path to an effective treatment. Such a program entails major advances in conceptual knowledge of how epileptic cortical networks behave and change during drug and stimulation treatment, gleaned from dynamic network models (DNMs). Our lab has pioneered derivation of novel EEG biomarkers for epileptogenicity from DNMs and is well positioned to address major pain points in the workflow of diagnosing and treating epilepsy.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: The Loneliness Pandemic began decades ago due to changes in social lifestyle, dramatically accelerated during the COVID-19 pandemic, and threatens to propagate in the future. Feeling lonely slowly kills people, by increasing chronic disorders, the risk for depression and for suicidal ideation; consistently, people with autism die much younger than the average population. We propose to investigate brain mechanisms for voluntarily engaging in positive social interactions, with the focus on oxytocin circuits, and with the aim of refining their therapeutic potential.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DENTAL & CRANIOFACIAL RESEARCH
PHR: Project Narrative In this proposal, we seek to fit the Nr2f family of nuclear receptors into the role of differentiating the cranial neural crest into facial ectomesenchyme. We also study their conservation as an inhibitor of the Edn1 pathway later in vertebrate jaw formation. Completion of the proposed studies will deepen our understanding of cranial neural crest development, contributing to the pool of knowledge needed to develop non-surgical therapies for craniofacial birth defects.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative A number of viruses like hepatitis B virus (HPB), herpes simplex virus-1 (HSV-1) and Thogoto virus (THOV) target the general transcription factor TFIIB to regulate expression of viral-specific genes during pathogenicity. TFIIB has also been implicated in neurodegenerative disorder, spinocerebellar ataxia, and cardiac hypertrophy. With a view to understand functioning of TFIIB in a cell, our focus in this grant proposal is elucidation of the overall role of TFIIB in transcriptional regulation in the cell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
PHR: Project Narrative There is a critical need for oral healthcare among Medicare-eligible older adults, particularly those from underserved groups who experience oral health disparities. In this exploratory study, we will evaluate whether Medicare Advantage is facilitating equitable access to and utilization of oral health services among all demographics of enrollees. We will examine utilization of dental services by individual-level demographics, and identify community-level factors associated disparities to help inform future research and policies to achieve health equity in the Medicare population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative Glioblastoma (GBM) is a highly aggressive, common malignant brain tumor that has a dismal prognosis of only 14 months despite aggressive standard treatment with radiation and temozolomide chemotherapy. Pharmacological ascorbate (IV vitamin C reaching ≈ 20 mM in plasma) is a novel, redox active iron dependent therapy that safely complements and potentially enhances GBM standard therapy. Therefore, due to the iron dependence of ascorbate, supplementation of pharmacological ascorbate with redox active iron (ferumoxytol) may further enhance the observed ascorbate response; this idea will be investigated in a phase 1 clinical trial.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: This study will develop valid, actionable evidence about which drugs, when given together with second-generation antipsychotic agents, lead to an increased rate of out-of-hospital sudden cardiac arrest and ventricular arrhythmia. This evidence will improve the safety of drug therapy for millions of persons with mental health conditions who take second generation antipsychotic agents.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE There is mounting concern that the cardiovascular health of low-income working-age adults (18 to 64 years) may be worsening in the United States. We will combine multiple sources of information, including national surveys from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, health care data from Medicaid and other insurers, and population-level death data to 1) characterize the epidemiology of cardiovascular risk factors, acute cardiovascular events (heart attack, heart failure, stroke), and cardiovascular deaths in low-income working-age adults on a national scale, 2) evaluate changes in health care coverage, access, and affordability, as well as cardiovascular morbidity and mortality, in the years that follow the Covid-19 pandemic, and 3) determine the potential effects of expanding the Medicare program on the cardiovascular health of this population. This research will provide critical information that informs public health and policy strategies to improve cardiovascular outcomes and health equity nationwide.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative Bacterial communities react to environmental stressors, the presence of oxygen in the gut, for example, by changing their transcriptional landscapes, and these responses underlie microbiome-related disorders such as inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), and colorectal cancer (CRC). Although RNAseq has been used to profile community function to obtain dynamic functional information not captured by metagenomic DNA sequencing alone, RNAseq is unable to capture real-time dynamics due to the varying stability of RNA, requires additional steps to remove ribosomal RNA, and isoften insensitive to short non-coding or modified RNA. We propose the development of Precision Run-On and SEQuencing (PRO-seq) as a promising method to capture transcriptional dynamics in cultured prokaryotes and in complex microbial communities, such as the human microbiome.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: TITLE: CAFFEINE AND POSTOPERATIVE NEUROCOGNITIVE RECOVERY PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE The proposed project is relevant to public health because delirium is a common complication of surgery for older adults that is distressing for patients and their families. The proposal will determine whether caffeine helps reduce risk of delirium and related complications after surgery. The analysis of brain activity during impaired cognition is also relevant to public health because results may provide insight into the mechanism of delirium and Mild Cognitive Impairment, which are syndromes that increase risk of future Alzheimer’s Disease- Related Dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative This grant examines the roles of ciliary neurotrophic factor (CNTF) and focal adhesion kinase (FAK) inhibition on olfactory neuroplasticity and function. We will use behavioral, genetic and pharmacological approaches to define the roles of CNTF and FAK inhibition-induced CNTF expression in regulating olfactory neuroplasticity and function following acute and chronic olfactory epithelium injury. We expect to identify a novel target, FAK, for injury-related loss of the sense of smell.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative Compared to healthy controls, patients with various mental disorders (e.g., schizophrenia, ADHD, etc) show slower improvement and worse peak performance during the learning of new tasks. Declines in task learning may reflect disruptions in long-term memory and executive control, but little is known about the neurocognitive mechanisms underlying the roles of the hippocampal memory system in the encoding of new task information. Using a combination of advanced behavioral methods and brain imaging in healthy young adults, the proposed research program will advance understanding of how the hippocampal memory system supports task learning and will provide valuable new insights into how decreased task learning in mental disorders may be linked to previous findings of hippocampal abnormalities in these disorders, which will further inform us how to better detect and restore declines in task learning and improve quality of life in patients.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Modified Public Health Relevance Section  Proteinuric kidney disease is one of the most common non-communicable diseases that cause substantial morbidity and mortality worldwide. Many patients with proteinuric kidney disease will eventually have kidney failure and need dialysis or kidney transplantation to survive. Successful development of kidney podocyte-specific anti-proteinuric novel therapeutics will delay or halt the progression of proteinuric kidney diseases and kidney failure in patients and change the current standard of medical care.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Overall) The proposed “Center for Team Effectiveness to Accelerate EBP Implementation in Children’s Mental Health Services (TEAMS)” will leverage organizational team effectiveness research (TER) to develop and test novel team-based implementation strategies, methods, and tools to improve the reach, quality, and effectiveness of care delivered in public systems serving children with mental health needs - specialty mental health, schools, pediatric healthcare, and child welfare. The TEAMS Center will create the essential administrative and scientific infrastructure to conduct team-based implementation research to improve children’s mental health outcomes. It will bring together experts in children’s mental health implementation research, EBPs for children and adolescents, implementation strategies, models, and methods, TER, and computer science.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a worldwide prevalent neurodevelopmental condition causing impairments in several life contexts. People with ADHD are at increased risk for poor school performance, educational underachievement, and unemployment, which is related to the elevated economic burden of ADHD. The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will help to disentangle the biological mechanisms involved in the interplay between ADHD and educational attainment, and it was designed to decrease the Eurocentric bias seen in genomic and epigenomic studies in mental health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding the mechanism of Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma progression is expected to deepen our understanding of how developmental transcription factors are reactivated in disease, and to provide evidence that targeting these developmental genes (which are no longer required in most differentiated cells) may be a novel means to inhibit RMS without the associated toxicities of most therapies. Such toxicities can be particularly devastating to children, and thus novel therapies, developed through the generation of unique animal models such as human xenograft into mice and zebrafish models, are clearly needed to identify new means to treat the disease. Thus, the proposed research is relevant to the NCI mission that pertains to advancing scientific knowledge and helping all people to live longer, healthier lives.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative This study will evaluate the long-term effectiveness of an economic intervention designed to facilitate maternal adherence to pumping and providing mother’s own milk to very preterm infants by covering the costs that serve as barriers to sustained mother’s own milk feedings during the neonatal intensive care unit hospitalization. Additionally, the study will assess the relationship between the total duration mother’s own milk is received during the first year of life and early childhood outcomes in this population of vulnerable infants.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The COVID-19 pandemic significantly impacted the United States’ health care system and disproportionately affected vulnerable populations (i.e., elderly people of color and rural). Home healthcare agencies (HHAs) and nursing homes (NHs) provide essential care for a large number of elderly patients post hospital discharge. This study will examine the impact of COVID-19 pandemic on care transitions between hospitals, HHAs and NHs as well as patient outcomes. The study also examines the effectiveness of infection prevention and control practices in HHA and NHs in reducing the impact of COVID-19.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE – OVERALL Genome editors make targeted changes in the genome and hold great promise in translational research but moving them into investigational new drugs has been slow and challenging. The majority of products in development target the liver or utilize viral vectors. Because these strategies are limiting for many diseases, especially those that affect post-mitotic cells in complex tissues like the eye, the CRISPR Vision Program seeks to develop novel human genome editing therapeutic platforms for transient, localized, and nonviral treatment of multiple inherited retinal disorders, specifically channelopathies affecting the retinal pigment epithelium.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Narrative Lung inflammation in response to pulmonary infectious agents is characterized by an acute potentially damaging phase and a resolution phase. Extension of the acute phase may lead to pulmonary tissue injury and acute respiratory distress syndrome, a highly lethal condition. This proposal seeks to test the idea that reactive oxygen species (ROS) produced in the nucleus of macrophages prevent the transition of inflammation from the acute to the resolution phase increasing the risk of ARDS in patients prone to develop oxidative stress (i.e. elderly, smokers, patients with underlying metabolic conditions). It also advances the idea that targeted antioxidants may be used as therapeutics in these patients to prevent ARDS.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE In principle, stem cells can be directed to produce desired cell types for transplantation, disease modeling, and drug testing, which is the basis for their tremendous scientific and therapeutic potential. However, we have not yet realized this potential because we do not fully understand the regulatory mechanisms that maintain stem cells and instruct their differentiation. The research outlined in this proposal will define the regulatory role of methylation at two key histone residues, H3K9 and H3K36, in directing differentiation, both in vitro and in vivo.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Cell growth triggers human cell division at the G1/S transition before DNA is replicated, but our molecular understanding of this process is poor. Here, we propose to definitively test molecular models for how cell growth triggers division both in cell culture and in vivo in mouse epidermal stem cells. Determining how cell growth triggers cell division will impact our understanding of developmental biology and cancer, where it is misregulated.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative relevance  Alternative polyadenylation (APA) is an elusive process observed in virtually all metazoans that produces genes with different mRNA 3’end isoforms and allows genes to escape the negative regulation exerted by miRNAs and RNA binding proteins.  Is unclear how these regulatory networks functions in cells, how APA is achieved, and which elements miRNA specifically target, but disruption in these basic processes has been implicated in a broad array of human diseases such as cancer, Alzheimer’s, and muscular dystrophies.  The experiments described in this research grant use a unique combination of genetics, biochemistry, bioinformatics and HT genomics taking advantage of the extensive genetic knowledge of the round nematode C. elegans to shed light on these important processes, produce unparalleled amount of information regarding APA reaction, and provide an unprecedented resource for the worm community. 1

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative Microtubule networks, known as main highways for intracellular transport, organize multiple cellular processes, which often occur simultaneously and in concert with each other. A subset of microtubule-dependent events is needed for an efficient response to cell-cycle or metabolic signaling and thus involve rapid microtubule reorganization. The goals of the Kaverina laboratory are to establish mechanisms whereby initial signals are translated into geometry and biochemistry of microtubule networks and to elucidate how the resulting networks impact cell physiology.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
ORG_NAME: STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK AT ALBANY
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed project will elucidate the intra- and intergenerational health consequences of life course stress exposure for maternal-infant health in Black U.S. families. This study will identify what stress exposures are most important to intervene with, when in the life course they should be targeted, and how best to do so (e.g., family interventions, community programs, policies). Knowledge gleaned from this research will help to promote maternal-infant health in generations of Black U.S. families.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS) is a common, life-threatening condition with no approved drug treatments. Pulmonary edema is a cardinal feature of ARDS and is mirrored closely by edema fluid collected passively in the Heat Moisture Exchanger (HME) filter; thus HME filter edema provides a novel and completely non-invasive window to the alveolar microenvironment. This proposal seeks to understand whether molecular characteristics of HME filter edema predict prolonged respiratory failure and could facilitate enrollment of high-risk patients into ARDS clinical trials.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative The human microbiome plays a vital role in health and disease; however, the ways in which the bacterial guests interact with and affect the human host at a molecular level are poorly understood. Here, we propose to use a chemically guided approach to uncover how bacterial transformations of host- and diet-derived metabolites affect host physiology, and in particular, host metabolism, immune response, and neurological function. The research will shed light on fundamental processes underlying obesity and type 2 diabetes, inflammatory bowel diseases, and steroid-modulated mood disorders and will help lay the groundwork for the rational manipulation of the microbiome to treat these conditions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative: Relevance to Human Health Understanding the pathophysiology and development of new therapeutics for ALS, ALS/FTD and FTD has been an enormous challenge. Recently the development of human disease induced pluripotent cell lines representing the natural disease in the most relevant cell types, motor neurons and glia, along with rodent and drosophila models, representing an in vivo system, provides unprecedented tools to 1) study the underlying disease process, 2) allow for identification of disease markers of pathology and of drug actions and 3) provide critical tools for future drug discovery and drug action validation. These ALS/FTD model systems, especially those derived from sporadic ALS patients, along with parallel studies of astroglia, combined with analysis of human brain tissues will be useful to compare common and uncommon pathways between ALS and other neurodegenerative models.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS HLTH SCI CTR HOUSTON
PHR: RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Brain blood flow declines in aging and in Alzheimer’s disease (AD) and Alzheimer’s disease-related dementias (ADRD). We have new evidence showing a critical role for Piezo1 (an ion channel activated by blood flow/shear) in blood flow regulation in the brain and further evidence that this ion channel is impaired with amyloidosis, a common occurrence in many forms of AD/ADRD. We now propose to 1) define the role of Piezo1 dysfunction in aging and AD/ADRD pathology and 2) determine if enhancing Piezo1 function can restore normal blood flow regulation and reduce pathology in the aged and AD/ADRD brain.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Project Narrative The UC San Diego Womens Reproductive Health Research (WRHR) Career Development Program provides rigorous interdisciplinary research training and career development to prepare physician-scientists in Obstetrics and Gynecology to become leaders in Women's Health research. Exceptional junior faculty OB/GYNs with MD, MD/PhD, MD/MPH, and other dual degrees participate in a structured program that includes relevant didactic training, as well as intensive project-based training in basic, translational, or clinical research under the guidance of a well-established primary research mentor with domain expertise and an Individual Mentorship Team, with oversight by Internal and External Advisory Committees. The world-class intellectual environment at the University of California, San Diego enables the UC San Diego WRHR program to offer WRHR scholars access to a team of experienced and dedicated faculty mentors and collaborators with diverse but complementary expertise, primarily from the Departments of OB/GYN and Reproductive Sciences, Medicine, Pediatrics, Family Medicine, Pathology, and Public Health.
