IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: The Training Program in Alzheimer's Disease and AD-Related Dementias at Indiana University School of Medicine (IUSM) will train 4 predoctoral and 4 postdoctoral trainees in the biology of these disorders and in the use of contemporary investigative methodologies with an emphasis on the integration of data science and -omics approaches. The program integrates the multidisciplinary resources of several NIA-supported Centers at IUSM, including the MODEL-AD and the Alzheimer's Disease Drug Discovery Centers. The 25 participating faculty support the trainees in basic, translational, and clinical research to produce the skilled workforce required for developing treatments for AD and related dementias.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative This proposed project will improve the measurement of HbA1c for optimal clinical and diagnostic use. Preservation of beta cell function in type 1 diabetes has been identified as an important goal in delaying progression of the disease at onset and also for therapeutic intervention. Accurate, standardized measurement of C-peptide will aid in this goal and is also the subject of this proposal.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL LIBRARY OF MEDICINE
PHR: Project Narrative Tumor-stroma/immune cell signaling communications within tumor microenvironment (TME) play important roles in tumor development and responses to targeted and immunotherapies; whereas, the complex and essential signaling communications within TME remain mysteries. Herein, we aim to develop novel systems biology models, combining cutting edge technologies, i.e., artificial intelligence (AI) models, pooled-library crispr, single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq), and 3D scalable tumor-stroma/immune cell co-culture assays (tumor-on-a-chip), and state-of-the-art cancer genetic mouse models to uncover novel tumor-stroma/immune cell signaling communications. And, we will identify novel therapeutic targets, drugs/drug combinations, inhibiting the tumor-stroma/immune signaling communications, to improve treatment response of targeted and immunotherapies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Abnormal spinal reflexes impair walking and other motor functions in many people with incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI). New therapies are needed. Spinal reflex conditioning is a novel noninvasive therapy that modifies these spinal reflexes to reduce spasticity, eliminate limping, and increase walking speed. This project will result in a robust, validated, clinically practical reflex conditioning system that enables this powerful new therapy to complement traditional therapies and enhance functional recovery for people with SCI and other disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The older Alaska Native/American Indian (ANAI) population is increasing at more than twice the rate of the general population and has higher rates of chronic illness. Yet, older ANAIs are only half as likely to have advance directives (AD), indicating a need for advance care planning (ACP) to ensure that care aligns with patients’ values and goals. This project will implement and evaluate a culturally tailored ACP intervention to increase ADs among seriously ill ANAI patients and provide evidence for improving palliative and end-of-life care delivery to this rapidly rising population of Americans.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Understanding the generation and maintenance of immunological memory is the foundation of effective vaccine development. We will contribute to this understanding by developing quantitative models for how immune responses are generated and boosted, and how immunological memory is maintained. This quantitative framework will help in the development of universal vaccines that provide broad protection against influenza. !

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although the Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) has been extensively studied for nearly two decades, we still do not fully understand the HIV replication cycle. We have identified the sphingomyelin hydrolase, neutral sphingomyelinase-2 (nSMase2), as an obligate cellular regulator of late-stage viral assembly. In this application we propose to determine the molecular mechanisms by which nSMase2 regulates HIV assembly and will validate the critical role for this cellular enzyme using molecular interference and structurally novel small molecule inhibitors of nSMase2 in a humanized mouse model of HIV infection.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed project aims to investigate the brain network interactions supporting memory for the specific details of events. We will examine the network processes that contribute to the binding and specificity of event details, building a model explaining how these key aspects of memory quality vary across events and across individuals. Delineating these mechanisms will improve our ability to understand and intervene on qualitative memory changes associated with psychiatric and neurological disorders, such as reductions in memory specificity observed in affective disorders.

PHR: Current treatments for advanced colorectal cancer have limited efficacy, in part because they do not target the cancer stem cell populations that drive tumor relapse, chemoresistance, and metastasis. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Humans cannot repair injury or cell loss in the nervous system very well, so new therapeutic approaches could improve health outcomes after stroke, neurodegenerative disease, and traumatic injury. Our group seeks to understand how successful nervous system regeneration occurs in nature, with the goal of uncovering fundamental principles or even specific pathways that could be manipulated to improve regenerative therapies. The goal of this project is to use worms called planarians with extraordinary regenerative ability to reveal how neurons are born after injury.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Project Narrative: Overall Component The proposed research is relevant to public health because understanding leptospiral virulence factors and the host response to leptospirosis is expected to give rise to new types of rapid biomarker diagnostic and triage tools to identify serious infections at an early stage when antibiotics and other interventions can prevent and/or treat critical illness including fatal hepatorenal failure. IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DEAFNESS AND OTHER COMMUNICATION DISORDERS
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed research is relevant to public health because it aims to determine the best treatment approach to ameliorate grammatical weaknesses, a core deficit, of young children with developmental language disorder. Findings from this study will help to significantly improve the clinical services offered to children with language impairment. The project is focused on improving the long-term grammatical weaknesses of children with significant language impairment and is thus, central to NIDCD’s mission to improve the lives of individuals with communication disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Human response to Influenza virus infection varies dramatically between individuals, from mildly symptomatic to death. We will systematically measure and model the innate immune response to IAV at the molecular network level: from host-virus protein-protein interactions through cellular signal transduction to changes in gene expression in human cells. The resulting mathematical model will help identify network vulnerabilities to be exploited for IAV therapy and help predict differences in IAV response in the human population.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Although favorable responses have been attributed to recently approved targeted agents for the treatment of hematologic malignancies, such as acute myeloid leukemia (AML), the diversity of genetic mutations within blood cancers limits the curative potential of targeted monotherapies. However, hematologic malignancies are especially vulnerable to radiation, and thus genetically diverse sub-clones may all be eliminated by targeting radiation directly to the sites of disease through the powerful technology of radioimmunotherapy. This grant proposes to improve outcomes for AML by: 1) identifying synergistic combinations of radioimmunotherapy approaches with highly effective, but not yet curative, targeted agents; 2) correlating efficacy with the extent of DNA damage achieved by synergistic combinations; and 3) by comparing these radioimmunotherapy combinations as preparative chemotherapy prior to allogeneic bone marrow transplantation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project narrative (Public health relevance statement) Mitochondria are indispensable organelles that generate energy and perform other vital functions for eukaryotic cells. Human health therefore depends on the proper function of mitochondria, and we are studying the processes that maintain mitochondrial function in cells. In the long-term, advances from these studies can be used to improve mitochondrial function and mitigate disease.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON MINORITY HEALTH AND HEALTH DISPARITIES
ORG_NAME: WEILL MEDICAL COLL OF CORNELL UNIV
PHR: Project Narrative There is evidence that improving diversity in the surgical workforce offers an opportunity to improve the quality of care for underrepresented minority patients, as patients have improved outcomes, satisfaction, and compliance when cared for by a diverse group of physicians. Unfortunately, the current surgeon workforce does not parallel the general population’s race and gender composition; to address this disparity, we have developed a multi-organizational collaboration looking to define the landscape of diversity in surgery. Using a deviance approach and mixed methods, we will study programs that have been successful at retention and promotion of minority and women residents and faculty to define best practices and potential interventions.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: NARRATIVE Abuse of prescription opioids is a major health problem characterized by the persistence of opioid use despite negative consequences. Although opioid abuse is related to altered dopamine release in the mesolimbic and cortico-striatal system, the functional connectivity abnormalities within these systems in opioid users are not well understood. This research will use a novel method, concurrent TMS-fMRI, to examine the functional connectivity alterations between the mesolimbic and cortico-striatal system among opioid users and demonstrate the efficacy of rTMS in the treatment of opioid use.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PUBLIC HEALTH RELEVANCE STATEMENT/NARRATIVE Interactions between mutations (epistasis) and between mutations and changing environments (pleiotropy) are  central to the evolution of many complex microbial phenotypes that directly affect human health, such as  compensated antibiotic resistance and the adaptation of pathogens to immune selection. This project will  provide a broad survey of the statistics of epistasis and pleiotropy, and will explain how these effects constrain  the evolution of microbial populations. This will provide a basis for predicting the conditions under which  complex microbial phenotypes relevant for public health are likely to evolve.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: Project Narrative Pulmonary fibrosis is a devastating disease associated with debilitating shortness of breath and a rapid progression to death. Because current treatment options are limited, it is critical that new therapies are identified. We propose experiments to determine how lung epithelial cell injury/death, a common feature of fibrosis, drives lung fibrosis with the goal of identifying novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NURSING RESEARCH
ORG_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN AT ANN ARBOR
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Complex chronic conditions account for a large portion of disease, death, and disability in the US. However, progress in finding effective solutions to these health problems are thwarted by the lack of nurses with skills to address these complex problems in the context of the team scientific processes that will be necessary. The proposed project will contribute to the health of the Nation by supplying nurse-scientists who are prepared to become innovative and successful scientists who will leverage team science approaches to promote health for individuals with or at risk for complex chronic conditions.
PROJECT_TERMS: Health Promotion;innovation;Science
PROJECT_TITLE: Complexity: Innovations in Promoting Health through Team Science

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE For the growing population of children with medical complexity, many medical decisions have no clear best treatment option; such decisions should be guided by individual patient preferences and values and clear communication of decision-related uncertainty through the use of shared decision making. This proposal develops a decision support tool for parents and providers of children with neuromuscular scoliosis who are deciding whether to undergo spinal fusion, a potentially life changing surgery but one that has significant complications. This work will serve as the foundation for using shared decision making to improve outcomes for children with medical complexity by supporting informed health care decisions and by using implementation science to develop scalable decision support tools that improve shared decision making.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: Project Narrative Adolescence is an understudied life stage during which profound brain remodeling and behavioral development can be influenced by early life environmental factors such as metals. We propose that exposure to a mixture of neuroactive metals in early life (age 0-2 years) impacts brain development manifesting as maladaptive trajectories of executive function, specifically involving attention and working memory.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Knowledge about environmental epidemiology - the study of the determinants and distribution of environmental causes and contributions to disease in human populations - has grown exponentially. With major advances in methodology, exposure assessment tools, toxicology, and genomics, and the increasing appreciation for multidisciplinary expertise, the need for well-trained highly skilled researchers and clinicians in this area has never been greater. We propose, through the continuation of this training grant, to continue to provide high quality training in environmental epidemiology and related disciplines to educate the next generation of outstanding scholars and public health researchers in this vital field.
PROJECT_TERMS: Environmental Epidemiology;Training Programs
PROJECT_TITLE: Training Program in Environmental Epidemiology

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Germline RUNX1 mutations establish a preleukemic state in hematopoietic stem and progenitor cells that predispose affected individuals to developing acute leukemia. We will identify how transcriptomic changes and an inflammatory microenvironment alter hematopoiesis in germline RUNX1 mutation carriers. These data will provide a roadmap to monitor asymptomatic family members, devise therapeutic strategies to prevent or improve patient outcome, and will facilitate translation of these findings to other leukemia predisposition syndromes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) is a progressive disease of lung arteries that causes shortness of breath, heart failure, and death. C-terminal Src kinase (Csk) is a protein that may contribute to lung artery damage early in the course of disease. Treatments blocking Csk are anticipated to stop lung artery destruction and prevent shortness of breath, heart failure, and death from PAH.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
ORG_NAME: UNIV OF ARKANSAS FOR MED SCIS
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Victims of a nuclear event can be exposed to ionizing radiation, which has long-term adverse effects on their immune system. This application will investigate 2 mechanisms of radiation-induced immune dysregulation: 1) the interaction between platelet receptor glycoprotein Ibα (GPIbα) and leukocyte Mac-1 and 2) the production of platelet-derived microparticles (PMPs). We will test whether exogenous administration of GPIbα and blocking PMP production are viable strategies to mitigate the adverse effects of ionizing radiation.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Obesity and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) results in perturbed liver function which can be improved by lifestyle interventions. The pathophysiology of NAFLD and its treatments, such as exercise, are associated with changes in sympathetic nervous system activity. The purpose of this proposal is to elucidate the role of liver sympathetic nervous system in control of hepatic metabolic flux during obesity in vivo and to determine how it is modulated by exercise, with a particular focus on mitochondrial function, hepatic glucose and ketone production.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Dysregulation of inhibitory synapses, specifically GABAARs, alters excitatory-inhibitory balance and has been implicated in a number of neurological disorders, including ischemia. GABAAR trafficking regulates overall inhibitory synaptic strength and is influenced by phosphorylation status of the receptor. Here, I propose to test the hypothesis that GABAAR trafficking during OGD is differentially regulated based on neuronal populations, and this contributes to defined synaptic and cellular alterations based on the susceptibility of these neuronal populations.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The proposed research is relevant to public health because it focuses on the clinical translation of a new antibody-based optical fluorescent technology for ultrasensitive detection of occult pancreatic cancer in vivo. The anticipated validation of this intraoperative molecular imaging method in identifying very small (1-3mm3) pancreatic cancer deposits will not only enhance surgical staging and outcomes for this highly lethal cancer, but can also lay the foundation for the development of new horizons for earlier detection of this challenging malignancy. As essentially every patient diagnosed with pancreatic cancer currently will eventually die of this disease, the proposed research is relevant to the part of the NIH’s mission that pertains to reducing illness and disability.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
ORG_NAME: ICAHN SCHOOL OF MEDICINE AT MOUNT SINAI
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Research in cancer prevention and control is a key to combat both the incidence of and suffering associated with cancer, particularly among `priority' populations such as racial/ethnic minorities, low-income, and older adults. Our program has been highly successful in its first funding cycle with recruitment of a very diverse group of trainees, having 100% of graduates in full-time academic research careers focused on cancer prevention and control, and 75% having already obtained external K (or equivalent) funding. We are applying for a renewal of this postdoctoral research training program to train the next generation of independent cancer researchers through tailored curricular and research experiences that promote interdisciplinary approaches to cancer prevention and control.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The mammalian target of rapamycin complex 1 (mTORC1) integrates multiple signals in order to control cell physiology. Increased mTORC1 activation is frequently observed in human disease, including cancer, type 2 diabetes, metabolic disorders, and neurodegeneration. The goal of this MIRA is to elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which mTORC1 is regulated by upstream stimuli. Completion of this project will provide valuable insight about mTORC1 biology and will uncover novel therapeutic targets.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE (Relevance Statement) Just as individual genetic variation can affect risk of obesity, so too can individual epigenetic variation. In particular, special genomic regions called CoRSIVs, which we recently discovered by screening in Caucasians, offer the best opportunity to advance our understanding of epigenetic etiology of obesity because their stable and systemic nature means that – like genetic polymorphisms – they can be assessed in any easily obtainable tissue sample, such as peripheral blood. Since we know there are many more human CoRSIVs to discover, and given that African Americans are disproportionately burdened by obesity, it is now urgent to screen for CoRSIVs directly in African Americans, and determine whether interindividual epigenetic variation at these regions affects risk of obesity.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative Spinal cord stimulation (SCS), a pain-relief technique that delivers electrical current continuously to the spinal cord to mask pain signal before it reaches the brain, is a transformative therapy for hundreds of thousands of people suffering from chronic pain; taking on an extra urgency given the pressures from the ‘opioid epidemic’ and the substantial harm addictive drugs may have on patients. This proposal will provide the first comprehensive mechanism of action (heating-base gate-control) for a clinically transformative innovation in SCS: high frequency (kHz) SCS that provides pain relief (analgesia) without the tingling side-effects (paresthesia). The proposed research is relevant to public health because it will provide a detailed and experimentally-buttressed mechanism for kHz SCS thereby enhancing ongoing use and improved technology, and highly relevant to the BRAIN initiative’s mission by accelerating the development and application of innovative perturbation technologies.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative BRCA1 is a well-established tumor suppressor that is frequently mutated in sporadic and hereditary breast and ovarian cancer. BRCA1 plays a critical, but poorly understood role in regulating various chromatin-signaling pathways that control access to genomic DNA. Understanding how these pathways normally protect the genome and the consequences of their dysfunction will provide important insight into how cancer cells develop and respond to specific chemotherapeutic treatments.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: Project Narrative  Despite the potential for generativity interventions to improve health and well-being in older adults, this has been a highly understudied area of research. As such, the goal of this project is to test the effect of a writing-based generativity intervention on well-being and inflammatory markers in a sample of older adults, as well as to examine the neurobiological mechanisms behind any observed effects. The results of this study may inform a low-effort, low-cost tool to improve well-being in older adults and thus may have broad implications for public health.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Despite our reliance on pancreatic cyst fluid biochemical and cytological analyses to guide clinical decision- making for patients with pancreatic cystic lesions, little effort has been directed toward optimization of biospecimen processing for pancreatic cyst fluid. We will systematically (1) evaluate the impact of preanalytical variables on pancreatic cyst fluid biochemical and cytological analyses and (2) identify strategies to mitigate the small volumes of available pancreatic cyst fluid in order to (3) develop a streamlined, reproducible protocol that improves the reliable early detection of pancreatic cancer. By improving the reproducibility and diagnostic yield of our assays for the detection of mucinous pancreatic cysts, we will increase the proportion of patients with pancreatic cystic lesions that undergo complete diagnostic testing, thereby improving the early diagnosis of pancreatic cancer while avoiding the burdens of overdiagnosis and overtreatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF MENTAL HEALTH
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/PUBLIC HEALTH SIGNIFICANCE The proposed research is relevant to public health because new neurotechnologies in development represent the most promising pathway to much-needed new treatments for neuropsychiatric disorders, but existing disparities and research practices raise concerns about whether new advances will be developed for and disseminated to groups of greatest need. A rigorous examination of disparities and other ethical challenges in dissemination is critical to ensure that the public investment in BRAIN Initiative-funded neurotechnology achieves the broad aim of improving treatment for brain disorders.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: Narrative Liver transplantation (LT) is the only effective cure for end-stage liver disease. Post-LT NASH fibrosis is a major concern for patient health. Our goal is to develop new computational and experimental methods and discover new biomarkers for post-LT fibrosis that can efficiently identify at-risk individuals. A second goal of the project is to identify molecular mechanisms of post-LT fibrosis, which could be targeted therapeutically.

ORG_NAME: LOUISIANA STATE UNIV A&M COL BATON ROUGE
PHR: NARRATIVE Many hearing and language disorders arise from pathological alterations to the central auditory pathways. This study is relevant to public health since it will investigate the hitherto overlooked contralateral auditory tectothalamic pathways as a neural substrate in these disorders. Therefore, this research is relevant to part of NIH’s mission, since it develops the basic knowledge that will lead to improved methods for diagnosing, preventing, and treating auditory disorders associated with aging, development, trauma, and neurodegeneration.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The purpose of this application is to continue a highly successful training program of nearly 25 years in translational and interdisciplinary research on substance use disorders and offers research training on bio- behavioral factors in substance use disorders at the pre-doctoral and post-doctoral levels. Graduates of this program are actively involved in research, teaching, publishing articles, and becoming independent addiction researchers. We aim to continue this record of success in the next funding period because the need for a translational or interdisciplinary program is greater today than ever before, and the proposed training program fills a unique niche in substance use disorder research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Postural Tachycardia Syndrome is a disabling condition that affects 3 million young people in the US. This project will test the novel idea that GIP, a hormone that is released after meals, contributes to the presyncopal symptoms, and increased upright heart rate in these patients. The results from these studies will inform the public on the cause and potential treatment for these symptoms.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ARTHRITIS AND MUSCULOSKELETAL AND SKIN DISEASES
PHR: NARRATIVE Painful disc degeneration is a major public health concern with few minimally invasive and effective treatments available. This study identifies the role of the phosphatase PHLPP1 on nucleus pulposus tissue during disc degeneration and 1) investigates if PHLPP1 inhibition can delay disease progression via suppressing inflammation and matrix degradation using conditional Phlpp1 knockout mice and PHLPP1 gene knockdown in human nucleus pulposus cells, and 2) develops nanoformulations for controlled PHLPP inhibitor release into degenerated Wildtype mouse IVDs. This study addresses a highly significant clinical problem, identifies a novel mechanism for disc degeneration and investigates drug delivery vehicles for developing novel minimally invasive treatments.

PHR: Project Narrative Beyond its role in noncoding RNA processing, we find Integrator, an RNA polymerase II- associated complex, regulates the 3’-end processing and termination of a set of protein coding genes. Unexpectedly, we further uncover a role for Integrator in regulation of NFκB signaling, a critical mediator of inflammatory response. Our studies will provide fundamental insight into regulation of gene expression, which will be the basis for development of rational therapies against pathogenic gene expression.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL HEART, LUNG, AND BLOOD INSTITUTE
PHR: Project Narrative The proposed study is a multi-center phase III trial that compares the percentage of newly diagnosed SAA patients with immune suppression-free survival with adequate counts (ISFS-AC) at 2-years between those randomized to Immune Suppression Therapy (IST) vs 9-10/10 HLA matched unrelated donor (URD) bone marrow transplant (BMT). The study will also address patient-reported outcomes and markers of fertility in each arm and explore critical biological correlates including assessing for germline genetic mutations associated with pediatric SAA that may affect response to BMT or IST and the development of clonal hematopoiesis following IST vs BMT. The study would represent the largest randomized study in pediatric SAA ever attempted with the goal of providing practice-altering conclusions to the field.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF DIABETES AND DIGESTIVE AND KIDNEY DISEASES
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Acute kidney injury (AKI) is an independent risk factor for death that affects 10-15% of hospitalized patients and more than 50% of patients admitted to the intensive care unit. Sepsis is the most frequent cause of AKI, affecting 48 million people worldwide every year, and accounting for approximately 11 million of annual global deaths. Despite these figures, there are no known therapies to prevent or reverse septic AKI; hence this study aims to establish the safety and feasibility of the implementation of metformin in the treatment of AKI in patients with sepsis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Parkinson’s Disease (PD) is the second most common neurodegenerative disease, affecting nearly one million Americans and ten million people worldwide. This proposal aims to understand how the LRRK2 kinase, mutation of which is the most common genetic cause of PD, works at the molecular level. We believe that the outcomes of our research will provide the conceptual framework for novel drug discovery strategies to combat PD.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE The integration of sensory and cognitive information streams is critical for complex behaviors. While the breakdown of this interaction is thought to underpin numerous neuropsychiatric disorders, our understanding of how individual neurons combine sensory signals with cognitive inputs remains limited. Here, we propose a comprehensive experimental and computational approach to determine the principles guiding pathway integration in individual neurons, establishing the foundation for future basic and translational research.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE Intellectual disability, characterized by an I.Q. less than 70 and significant impairments in intellectual and adaptive behavior, affects approximately 1-3% of the world population. Despite the heterogeneous and genetically complex nature, recent studies have led to the discovery that many genes linked to intellectual disability converge on a limited set of molecular pathways, suggesting that distinct intellectual disabilities are unified by common underlying molecular dysfunctions. Here we utilize the fruit fly Drosophila as a system to model a heritable form of intellectual disability by exploring the intersection of specific factors and RNA modifications to define molecular mechanisms underlying intellectual disability disease pathogenesis.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF ALLERGY AND INFECTIOUS DISEASES
PHR: Narrative T cells are a class of immune cells that fight diseases and cancer, whereas regulatory T cells (Tregs) are an opposing class that are essential to prevent autoimmune disease and rejection of organ or bone marrow transplants. Our project aims to understand how DNA methylation and demethylation affect T cell expansion and regulatory T cell function. This may give us new methods for improving how T cells and regulatory T cells function in the body to improve the efficacy of patient treatment.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL CANCER INSTITUTE
PHR: The proposed research is relevant to public health as inflammation has long been considered to play a causative role in colon cancer development and druggable targets involved, however, remain largely unknown. This application will test the hypothesis that p38 MAPK activation converts inflammation responses to colon tumorigenesis. Thus, by demonstrating the essential role of p38 in intestinal tumorigenesis in mouse models and the therapeutic activity of its pharmacological inhibitor pirfenidone, the proposed research is highly relevant to the NIH’s mission of extending healthy life and reducing the burdens of illness.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative This work seeks to define the role of developmental context in oncohistone-mediated glioma initiation and maintenance using a novel inducible transgenic cerebral organoid system. The overall approach is to alter the timing and sequence of oncogene induction during human cerebral organoid development, interrogate the functional consequences at single cell resolution, and evaluate the impact on tumor phenotype and maintenance. The long-term goal of this research program is to identify better therapeutic targets for oncohistone-driven pediatric high-grade gliomas, one of the most lethal childhood cancers.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Project Narrative While all cells contain the same genetic information, control of gene expression is crucial for defining unique cell types. The nuclear lamina contributes to gene repression by compacting and repressing approximately one third of the genome in heterochromatin at the nuclear periphery, yet it remains a mystery how association with the nuclear lamina confers repression. The overarching goal of my research program is to resolve this mystery by defining how components of the lamina and chromatin communicate to mediate gene repression.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative The goal of this renewal application is to continue Vanderbilt Department of Pediatrics mentored training program for early career pediatricians possessing both the aptitude and passion to become a new generation of basic and translational physician scientists. We will focus on career development areas where Vanderbilt has internationally recognized programs of discovery combined with a record of sustained excellence in research mentorship. Each pediatric K12 scholar will have an individualized training program developed by the PI and Training Directors in collaboration with a multidisciplinary mentorship team, and will be supported by a broad array of institutional and departmental resources.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON DRUG ABUSE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE More than 76 million Americans use opioid drugs as analgesics for the treatment of long-term pain, and more than 2 million Americans now have opioid use disorders. This research program will study genetic and molecular mechanisms with important implications for treatment of chronic pain and management of problematic opioid side effects, such as tolerance, addiction and withdrawal. Thus, this project has long-term potential to contribute significantly to managing several major medical problems.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: Project Narrative – PI: C. Mac Donald – EVOLVE-10 Study The overall goal is to investigate long-term advanced MR imaging measures and clinical outcome of concussive traumatic brain injury (TBI) sustained during deployment in US military personnel. We will relate these findings to prospectively acquired longitudinal imaging and clinical data from the acute/sub-acute, and early chronic stages following combat concussion collected on these patients as part of previous collaborative efforts. We hypothesize that early clinical and imaging measures can be used to predict high risk vs. low risk for poor 10-year outcome which will offer important insight into the long-term impact of war-time mild TBI thereby guiding new recommendations for clinical management and therapeutic intervention.

IC_NAME: EUNICE KENNEDY SHRIVER NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF CHILD HEALTH & HUMAN DEVELOPMENT
PHR: Narrative The studies proposed in this application are focused on typical language development in infants and toddlers. The studies will measure infants’ use of statistical regularities in language input during predictive language processing, error-based learning, and infant-controlled exploration. The results will inform subsequent studies of children at risk for atypical language development, which is a significant public health concern, with the goal of promoting positive language acquisition outcomes.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF GENERAL MEDICAL SCIENCES
PHR: Narrative The proposed work aims at developing new methods for selective and efficient conversion of simple and abundant molecules into functionalized compounds of biological importance, as well as late-stage functionalization of complex molecules and drugs. The proposed approaches rely on employment of hybrid transition metal-catalyzed radical methodologies, including desaturation, atom transfer, cross-coupling, and cascade functionalization techniques. If fully developed, these methods would dramatically broaden the arsenal of synthetic tools available for medicinal chemists and biologists, and will most certainly impact drug discovery research and related health-oriented sciences.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE ON AGING
PHR: An increasing number of dominant mutations are found in adenine nucleotide translocase 1 (Ant1) to cause multi-systemic neural and muscular degeneration, but the underlying mechanism is poorly understood. We generated mouse models to test the hypothesis that the pathogenic variants of Ant1 affect mitochondrial protein import and cause mitochondrial Precursor Over- accumulation Stress (mPOS) in the cytosol. The studies may uncover protein import stress and mPOS as novel mechanisms of neural and muscular degeneration, and help the understanding and treatment of Ant1-induced diseases and possibly, many other clinical conditions that directly or indirectly affect mitochondrial protein import.

IC_NAME: FOGARTY INTERNATIONAL CENTER
PHR: NARRATIVE In this application to address the global epidemic of cardiometabolic disease, the University of Washington (UW) Department of Global Health (DGH) is partnering with two long-standing collaborators, Kathmandu University (KU) and University of Nairobi (UON), to facilitate cross-cultural training experiences for building future research opportunities. As a part of this training, we will support 6 students to complete MPH degrees at UW, 5 students to complete MSc degrees in Public Health at KU, and up to 40 trainees per site to complete online certificate programs. Workshops of special interest to research in cardiometaboic risk factors and conditions will also be offered at each site.

IC_NAME: NATIONAL INSTITUTE OF NEUROLOGICAL DISORDERS AND STROKE
PHR: PROJECT NARRATIVE/RELEVANCE TO PUBLIC HEALTH Science and medicine have revolutionized our ability to diagnose rare genetic diseases, but patients and their families still have vanishingly limited treatment options. This is because of the challenges in precisely correcting genetic diseases using gene therapies that are both safe and effective. This U19 program seeks to address this vexing gap for four neurological conditions, with the goal of bringing at least one gene-editing therapeutic to the FDA within 5 years. Success in our program could revolutionize treatment for at least one of the conditions we will study and pave the path for the others in the near future.
